content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
Long story short: Not as solid as a game as the other Bioshocks, but amazing at story-telling, even if it takes a bit too much from Half-Life 2's book. Excellent as a finisher for the trilogy's story.DISCLAIMER: I don't own the DLC for this title, so I can't give an opinion on it. I've heard the Burial At Sea episodes are really good though, possibly better than the main game. Check reviews for the season pass before you make your purchase.Bioshock Infinite was rated really highly for Game of the Year 2013. And rightly so, the game does an amazing job at wowing the player. The amazing visuals, spectacular voice acting, and brilliant underlying motifs and themes make this one of the most memorable games of the year. However, gameplay features have been stripped down from the original Bioshock, some for the better, but in general the gameplay has ended up being a glorified shooting gallery rather than the maze-like claustrophobia that is Rapture.Infinite takes place in Columbia, a city above the clouds, rich in detail as light floods the streets of moving buildings, vapour passes underneath, and zeppelins float by. The story goes like this (and I will keep this spoiler-free and brief): you play as Booker, a guy who is sent to capture a woman for someone else. That girl ends up being Elizabeth, who becomes your companion after about a quarter of the game. Her characterisation is great; she gives this sense of trapped freedom throughout the entire game. Certain scripted areas really bring out her personality a lot. In the meanwhile, the citizens of Columbia turn against you after discovering a mark of the False Prophet on your hand. This theme of religion is explored pretty well throughout the game as well.The story is told in a Half-Life 2 fashion: you move from locale to locale to progress the game, each place broken up by a "cutscene" like area where, while control isn't taken away from the player sometimes, you're contained in an area until the dialogue has finished. It's alright, even if the pace slows down a little bit too much. There's also hidden voice logs around in typical Bioshock fashion just to add a bit more lore to the world.The ironic part about Infinite is that, for a game that has risen from the ocean in terms of locale, it's also lost a lot of depth in gameplay. On surface-level, Booker can hold only two weapons, and can unleash any of his vigour powers (magic spells essentially) at any time in conjunction, such as shooting with a revolver and unleashing crows on enemies. Hacking is non-existent now, and has been pushed into a vigour of its own.Most of the enemies are gun-wielding humans, which means the combat is cover-based. The health accommodates for this by using an armour/health mechanic where armour is cheap but rechargeable, whereas health can only be restored with pickups, giving the player a bit of room for error (which is always nice) without being ridiculously forgiving. Some enemies, such as the Handyman are more tank-like enemies (like the Big Daddies from Bioshock 1), and involve a much different playstyle to take down. However, the gunplay doesn't entirely work in its favour: unlike the Big Daddies, you're more or so launched into arenas with the Handymen, so traps and clever planning cannot be used; a drop in depth.The combat itself is a bit more dynamic that other cover-based shooters, however. Elizabeth has the ability to pull in objects from alternate dimensions or time periods such as cover, grappling hooks, health packs, etc. It's neat the first few times, but it seems a bit too contextual as some areas lack these tears, and combat reverts to the standard peak and shoot strategy, rather than the dynamic cover-shifting that the developers tried to implement.Elizabeth also can sometimes find items throughout the game, which, again, feels contextual. A lot of the time, she'll give items when you need it, which makes her seem a lot more useful than she actually is. However, I think it's a mistep that Elizabeth will sometimes find money during gunfights, and think it's a good idea to hand over as bullets wizz past her head.Finally on combat, there's certain areas with skyhook rails, places where you can latch onto a rail and shoot along as you zoom down the line. The game makes it easy to hop on and off, and a couple of places in the game utilise this in a huge arena-like setting. Unfortunately, it makes gunplay a bit difficult, at least on PC, as you do not lock on to targets, making hitting them while moving a challenging endeavour. This is alleviated by the ability to crush enemies by landing on them, but it does make these sections seem a bit sporadic more than anything.Weapons and vigours can be upgraded throughout the game, and fortunately the amount of money given to you in the game is quite small, only allowing you to upgrade a fraction of the things you can upgrade. However, the fact that you can only wield two weapons means that you can decide on a favourite playstyle and run with that, utilising other weapons only when they're handed to you. The vigours also are not utilised as much as the predecessors (for example, the hacking vigour is used a lot less than I'd like it to be used (I think I used it about eight times in the game)). The biggest issue with Bioshock is that it's the third and final game in the series, yet a lot of its features seem a bit worse than the original titles. It's hard to discuss on its own just because I'm constantly reminded of what is missing, as opposed to what is there. However, the story is subjectively better than the previous titles: the land of Columbia is wonderous and well realised. It's also beautifully modelled and textured, and is a joy to look at.Bioshock Infinite is a very good story, but it's not as solid a game as its predecessors. I'd recommend grabbing the trilogy package if you're new to the series but like first-person shooter titles as, while it's worth playing, it's not as good as the original Bioshock. If you do own the previous games, this game is still worth your money.RATING: 2 UP, 1 DOWNMy up/down rating system tries to differentiate between games that are mediocre (less ups and downs total), and games that are interesting but flawed (more ups and downs totals). Ups relate to how much good a game has, and downs are how much bad a game has.[/table]  0 UPs 1 UPs 2 UPs 3 UPs   Not worth playing, skip it Alright, play it if you're into the genre Very good, play it if you're looking for something worth trying One to go down in history, a must have for everyone[/table]  0 DOWNs 1 DOWNs 2 DOWNs 3 DOWNs   Nothing detrimental in the game A few things wrong, but doesn't ruin it Kind-of broken or aggravating, you may not be able to put up with it Very, very broken, a lesson on what not to do

Posted: September 15, 2014
												The highly acclaimed Bioshock Infinite takes place in the sky town of spingleton, where the bad man Cornstarch wants to take the lady-lamb young Queen Elizabeth from your fingertips. The interesting thing about The Queen is she cries a lot and makes lots of tears that make black-and-white things appear like in the olden days. This is used as a very unique mechanic in battles to overcome Cornstarch's, Slater's and Mr. Vox Populi's men. Additionally, the town of spingleton has many sky train tracks that Booker can latch on an take The Queen on a sightseeing journey whilst being shot at. The enemies also vary quite a significant amount, from the fireman who ironically throws fire and explodes to the handyman who has hands.The special powers in this game, also knows as nigors, are as diverse as the number 8 and offer a great variation of gameplay. For example:In one instance you may step back and press the button for you nigor to fire birds at the enemies to finish them off, or perhaps you may choose a different route and stay back and press the button for your nigor to throw a fireball at the enemy, or maybe you might choose instead to stay back and press the button for your nigor to use the lightning on your enemy and give them a shock (get it?), or you might diverge and choose to stay back and use the nigor that throws a ball of energy at them or even choose to stay back and make horse sounds as they decide to float. The list goes on...The story of Bioshock is even more depthy, as the man Cornstarch and the relationship between him and The Queen becomes more evident. Trigger warning: Spooky ghosts are in this game.

Posted: September 24, 2014
												I haven't played any of the earlier BioShock games, so I will not include them in this review. (Except here) BioShock Infinite is a visually stunning game with a story so immersive that the ending might leave your jaw dropped! The game tells us the story about Booker Dewitt a man who is out to find and kidnap/rescue Elizabeth, a young girl who lives in the flying city of Columbia, a what at first looks like a idyllic paradise with no problems at all.This however turns out to be quite wrong, like all societys even Columbia have its problems, racism, class struggle, poverty and much more, this turns the kidnap/rescue mission into a trip through a failing society. A society that is eventually flipped into a bloody civil war. I won't go in to much more about the plot, because I want to spoil as little as possible. But the gameplay is quite FPS generic, you get some weapons, you shoot some guys, but you also have your "special powers" Throughout Columbia you find bottles, you can drink these bottles and with them come great power, power to kill. These powers make all battles a bit more interesting, and there is also a hook which via "cables" in the sky you can travel quite fast around the battle areas, surprising your enemy from above. I would say what makes this game is the story, and especially the ending, however the gameplay isn't bad but it isn't great either. I would recommend this game!

												To everyone opting to play Bioshock Infinite: I strongly recommend playing the Bioshock 1 before even starting Bioshock Infinite.Regarding Bioshock Infinte (without spoilers): I recommend this game - it's a totally awesome experience, very atmospheric, featuring unique gameplay ideas, very believable characters, strong and mind blowing plot and beautiful visual design. The answer is - the Bioshock Infinite DLCs "Burial at Sea".Having played Bioshock series in the right order (Bioshock 1 - Bioshock 2 - Bioshock Infinite), I enjoyed the whole series immensly.  The  Bishock Infinite DLCs complete the story of the series, but  the story arc unfolds in such way,  that now I wish only to forget what I saw while playing "Burial at Sea", and even the whole Bioshock Series is now a one whole drama to me. Some secrets better be left untold, some parts of the story better be buried and never known. You will not find hope here. You'll not find your dreams here. It's like watching "The Bridge to Terabithia" again.I have never played such a depressing game in my whole life -_-

content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												BioShock Infinite weaves a complicated and intricate plot around ever-changing variables. Not only is it an evolving story that sees protagonist Booker DeWitt and the mysterious Elizabeth grow closer, but Irrational's latest deals with the hubris of a society built above the clouds, its ideals inflated with so much of the same hot air that propels it above the world below.Though it touches on topics revolving around racism, religion, rebellion and revenge, these themes take a backseat to BioShock Infinite's primary topic: Love. Whether it be a society in love with its own patented brand of American Exceptionalism, a leader in love with his own self-appointed immortal image, or a pair of people that come together to care for one another, BioShock Infinite is a love story.And it's an easy story to fall in love with. Taking place in 1912, BioShock Infinite follows Booker DeWitt, a man with a mysterious past charged with ascending to the once-iconic but now forgotten city of Columbia, a floating city in the sky. Once there, DeWitt must find a woman named Elizabeth and bring her to New York to wipe away his debt. DeWitt, who first appears to be without a vestige of sympathy for the plight of the woman, complies. To describe details any further would only serve to eradicate BioShock Infinite's exceptional ability to surprise.Unlike the undersea city of Rapture – the setting of Irrational's critical and commercial smash BioShock – Columbia is a living world. Players won't draw blood from enemies for quite some time when they arrive in Columbia, a world established and ruled by a figure known as Father Zachary Comstock. Rather, DeWitt and the player are introduced to the technology and ideals that power the city as they move across its interlocking sections; and as gorgeous as the world of Columbia is, it's a horribly grotesque place. DeWitt learns that the city is fueled by racism, misplaced loyalty and morbid patriotism, and it quickly becomes a joy to know the game will eventually allow him to pull it down from the sky, arrogant brick by brick.When players first arrive on Columbia by way of being rocketed into the sky, the focus is a civil war between the "White Power" fanatics led by Comstock and a rebellious group dubbed the Vox Populi led by a strong black woman named Daisy Fitzroy. While this story weaves in and out of the overarching narrative, it eventually takes a backseat to more pressing matters: Elizabeth and DeWitt's search for the truth about their existence on Columbia.BioShock Infinite's core gameplay mimics that of Irrational's previous effort: a first-person shooter with a magical component. The "magic" in Infinite is composed of collectible vigors, potent elixirs that grant DeWitt special powers, like the ability to electrocute enemies or lob fireballs. Each of the vigors, and all weapons, can be upgraded to increase their power and properties – longer ability duration, extra ammunition, etc. Where things begin to diverge for Infinite versus the original BioShock is in collectible gear, which can be mixed and matched to grant special buffs, like headgear that allows DeWitt to leach health for successfully performing brutal melee execution kills with his skyline hook.The hook is used to traverse Columbia's skylines, a network of massive, suspended mechanical rails that connect different parts of the city. While both DeWitt and Elizabeth can use them to travel the city, they serve as more than just a simple means of transportation. As the game progresses, the pair will encounter arenas with varying levels of terrain with enemies attacking on all sides. Though you can pick each aggressor off from a static cover point, it's far more fulfilling to zip around on skylines and fight from multiple angles.Elizabeth provides DeWitt with valuable resources like ammunition, health packs and salts during battle. Beyond scavenging, Elizabeth can also modify the properties of the battlefield by playing with pre-determined "tears" – splits in the fabric of time she has the ability to open. These can introduce things like cover, turrets, and even motorized allies to help DeWitt come out on top.Tears also play a crucial role in the narrative. Elizabeth has been able to open them since early childhood, though as a young adult she's lost some of her grip on her ability. DeWitt, understandably, is terrified of Elizabeth's power, unclear of the true intentions of everyone involved in her life, including Comstock and his own employers. The tears add to the mystery, sometimes appearing with music from the wrong decade spilling out of them, raising immediate questions as to the true nature of the phenomenon, Columbia's place in history and even Elizabeth herself. Though their relationship is quickly strained upon first meeting, with neither truly trusting the actions of the other, Elizabeth and DeWitt become allies and even friends, a relationship made possible by BioShock Infinite's superb voice cast.Engagements are typically a fun dance between mixing weapons and abilities while utilizing the environmental possibilities to cut down Infinite's assortment of enemies – snatching powerful weapons from tears, leaping onto skylines and fighting as you glide across the sky. Some of the battles, however, drag on too long and interrupt the flow of story-telling, especially toward the end of the game.In terms of its immediate adversaries, Infinite lacks any foe as terrifying as BioShock's Big Daddy; though the aggressiveness of the Handyman – a robotic behemoth with a human head that literally begs for death – can be a daunting challenge to manage. Both standard and special enemies, even the mini-gun toting Motorized Patriot, eventually become just another thing to shoot at, never reaching the same dangerous heights as BioShock's giant, iconic protector.The ending of the game is marvelous, and you'll have to trust me when I say that BioShock Infinite's final section – dedicated entirely to its narrative – handily disposes of any minor gripes. There is not only one twist to the tale, but many entrances and exits to a wide array of secrets, diving deeper into the past of the primary cast of characters and the world of Columbia itself. The greatest discovery, however, is the love that blossoms between Elizabeth and DeWitt, and how far the pair are willing to go to protect each other.As a game, BioShock Infinite has its successes and its falterings consistent with any suitably complex piece of interactive entertainment. As a story, as an exercise in drawing the player into a believable and relevant world, as proof of exactly what a videogame can mean to a person... BioShock Infinite is damn near perfect.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												BioShock Infinite.At first, i felt this game was too over-hyped. I mean its another FPS game. I was wrong. This game is worth playing but even more so when you get all the content (DLC packs)At first i was disappointed that the main story campaign only takes an average of 9 Hours to finish even with exploration and a bit of backtracking, the atmosphere was superb, the graphics were phenomenal, the voice acting was superb, and i really fell for the overall feel of Columbia. Then when i finished the campaign, i just kinda let it sit in my library.But then as soon as the Burial at sea Episodes unlocked, i got sucked back into the world of Bioshock. I tell you, they really did a great job on the damn story on this one. The story is superbly thought out and was simply a pleasure to experience.I really felt for Booker, i empathized with him and at one point i felt like i was him. Clinging to this tiny shred of hope that maybe, just maybe i can redeem myself and save this girl for i have already doomed her in another reality. And i really sympathized with Elizabeth. The loneliness and the feeling of being caged off from the world outside the walls she knows so very very well.The game made me question choices and the illusion of free will for you are given a few choices but with pre-determined outcomes. Despite all the good that it has, it has flaws as well.The atmosphere is great but i wish that i could interact with more of the environment aside from the vendors, the trash cans and etc. I'd like to have a conversation with a random civilian and have that person acknowledge me (me as booker at least) and not feign back to the scripted, backgroundish routine that it follows. The plasmids kinda just help you shoot people better, they are useful for stopping your enemies or holding them in place or disabling them so you can deliver some lead to their systems. After a while, i get tired of the phrase "BOOKER, CATCH!"I particularly like the SkyHook feature as it allows me to sucker punch an unsuspecting enemy into oblivion (if he were standing on a floating piece of real estate in Columbia) I believe that despite the feeling of it being over-hyped, its a great game.It is a masterpiece that can only be done through the gaming medium. Movies, books and music can only hope to scratch the surface of what Bioshock Infinite's story has done. I doubt that any other medium could deliver this story quite as well as the game has already done. But i wouldn't mind seeing some books, graphic novels and other things about BioShock.This sets the bar for storytelling in games that are centered around a full bodied plot.The DLC's story was a perfect example of content that gives you the kind of clarity that you get when you get to the conclusion of a long fairy tale.The final DLC hits the nail on the head, and is a fitting final goodbye from Irrational Games. Get it on sale and get the season pass.Its a hefty Download but damn its worth it.Would you kindly play the game?

Posted: March 27, 2016
												Well, although  not the best game in the universe, this game does both right and wrong things all at the same time. The main complaint I have with BioShock Infinite are its two contrasting themes of parallel dimensions mixed in with themes of religiousism, idolfication, the constitution of the United States of America, sexism, hedonism and people in black sheep's clothing, it does too much. There is no separate transition from this main theme towards the other themes of tears, parallel dimensions Elizabeth can will by the power of her memories.  If this was removed the game would be so much better.Let's get down to the breakdown of the game.Gameplay: Gameplay as others have mentioned I am sure already is the repetitive gunplay. There are many situations where you are forced through the in-game script to pick-up weapons you may not want to use in the situations they make you use them in. This is problematic in one of the toughest battles later in the game against warships, zepplins. The guns however do feel nice to use. The sounds of them might be a little unrealistic or barely noted to pay attention to.Story:      This is my largest complaint with the game , even more so then the repetitive gameplay without much variation. Much of the game is told through kinetoscopes which tell majority of the story through a type of film projected roll of film in black-white old cinematic style. However, the story is better presented through non-verbal actions when you meet Elizabeth and when she interacts with you within the world she was trapped in. However, you as an outsider don't understand everything that Elizabeth understands and knows about the world in which she lives in as an insider. This is why they had to put parallel dimensions in this game to make sense of both an insider and outsider perspective of the situations at hand. However, it is poorly executed and done. Religion:     Many of you that are not religous or even Christian for that matter will not understand some of the biblical references to the garden of eden, Sodom of Gomorrah and washing away the debt of sins. However, without spoiling the story too much, one guy comes to you and says you can wash away the debt of your sins if you give your own daughter away; though, it is really unclear if it is yours or Elizabeth when she was a girl. I assumed it was Elizabeth since she is the one they wanted to take Lady Comstock's place in the end .     Themes:Idolfication: The story takes place in the early 1900's. There are points in the game where you enter in upon factory workers being enslaved and  people are  being tortured for heresy against a rising secular cult of people that are not following the true Gospel of God. Everyone in this game is blinded by idolfication. Even the people who follow Comstock, they are just his followers; nothing more. He is the actual false prophet in the game, though they frame you as the AntiChrist when instead you play the role of Jesus. Your job is not to minister to people but to tell them that they are wrong about following this skeptical guy Comstock and his teachings. He is the one that actually should be accused of heresy. However, during this time, Columbia is promised an eternal state of Heaven. However, they believe it has to be done through a human sacrifice of Elizabeth through the baptism of Booker De Witt. Racisim: They have black and white wash stations characteristic of slavery days. There are various jargon and little things I will not be going over as that would spoil the game's experience for you. Take note that there is much racisim and questions regarding the philosophies of the world along with branding people's names of the last sins they have commited upon death. If it takes place in the 1900's sins should be wiped away through Jesus Christ. Ultimately they believe Booker is the AntiChrist. Yet in many parallel dimensions he is seen as the hero and savior of the world of Columbia.Overall: Do I think Christians should play this game though it stands as one of the most controversial triple AAA games out there currently in the bounds of the Christian worldview and modern world? Yes I think you should. This game teaches you what the nation is like and the times we live in today with modernisim using parallel dimensions and universes as the main driving point and vehicle for the message. It shows you both the good and bad things of religion. What works right when religion is performed in a manner based on biblical teachings, then what goes wrong when those biblical teachings are reprimanded when man's leadership is based on the teachings of our country's founders.7/10 Only because many games don't have the courage to discuss idolfication, racisim, sexism and politics in a worldly sphere and through alternative realities relating to the secular realities of men and women on this earth. Even though the game is just your average shooter, it is worth at least for you to check it out for yourself.

												INTRODUCTION:Bioshock Infinite is the third installment to the popular Bioshock series. Set in a city in the sky as opposed to the city underwater, this game features a revamped combat mechanic featuring Sky-lines rails and and a new AI companion, all the while, retaining some of the old features of the previous games.You play as Booker DeWitt, a former 7th Cavalry soldier turned Pinkerton who was tasked by unknown individuals to recover a girl, Elizabeth, from the floating city of Colombia. A simple recovery mission quickly turns sour when the girl you have to take turns out to be a very important figure head.PROS:+ Story: -Needless to say, the one primary factor that drives the Bioshock games is they are narrative-driven. This game delivers a very compelling, interesting and immersive story that makes you want to know more about the city and world of Colombia.+ Graphics: -Stunning visuals and magnificent world design makes Bioshock infinite one of the prettiest games of the franchise. Breathtaking scenery, beautiful texture quality and character designs makes the world alive.+ Elizabeth: -I normally frown at escort missions, specially if the AI is poorly programed for, but Bioshock Infinite (despite being an escort mission start to finish) got past that  by introducing an companion AI who is helpful and doesn’t get in the way. She assists the player through support roles providing money, ammo, and regenerative potions all throughout the game. She's not the revolutionary AI companion that everyone was excited about, but she's the closest one we have.+ Optimization: -Was optimized enough for the PC to allow even mid-range desktops or laptops to play the game in relatively high or medium-high settings.CONS:- Combat: -Retains the fun and high paced combat with guns and magic of the previous titles BUT seriously fails due to the poor decision of limiting the player with only TWO weapons carry limit which does not live up to the previous games who had several weapons at the player's disposal. Too many: (1) Kill Bad Guys, (2) Elizabeth Opens Door, Repeat step one, sequences.- Poor Antagonist (No Spoiler): -Explaining this is a bit hard without spoilers. We were introduced with a great antagonist by the name of Andrew Ryan in the first game but I can't help but feel that the new Antagonist, Comstock falls short. Anything more would be a spoiler. Now even the new Songbird creature (kinda like a buffed up Big Daddy) makes very, very limited appearances and its role in the whole story somewhat becomes pointless once you progress.- No sense of Danger: -This has been an illness since the first game. Death in the Bioshock franchise is more of a minor inconvenience than an actual penalty. Vita-Chambers in the first and second Bioshock games made death pointless. This was carried over to Bioshock Infinite where the Vita-Chambers beeing replaced by Elizabeth reviving you every time you get incapacitated. This totally eliminates any sense of dread that you should be feeling in a high combat scenario.CONCLUSION:AN OVERALL GREAT GAME. Though it has its short comings, I would still recommend Bioshock Infinite to any fan of the franchise. It provides a satisfying narrative and introduces new characters that leave a lasting impact.Although I would still RECOMMEND this game to NEW players in the Bioshock franchise, I think this is best appreciated by people who already gone through the first and second games.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------Like my Reviews? Follow my Curator's Page:http://store.steampowered.com/curator/6861651-Miyumi%27s-Review-Corner/

Posted: February 1, 2014
												When I initially saw the trailer for this game before it came out, I was a bit put off. The trailer left me wondering "WTF is this? Why is this a game about a city in the sky now? Where are the big daddies? What happened to the little sisters? Where's all the water? And why the ♥♥♥♥ is George Washington in this game!?So I finally purchased the game expecting to hate it, wishing through out the whole time that it was like the first 2 games. It only took about 10 minutes for all of that to go out the window. The new world  in Bioshock Infinite is beautiful. Definitely better than  Rapture. Rapture is grimy and there is very little to look at. In Colombia, the atmosphere is a lot more lively. Everywhere you turn there is something to look at, It's like a giant theme-park. Colombia is a lot more open than Rapture, so it allows for combat to be more spread out and not so in your face as in the previous 2 games. The shooting feels a lot better. At first i was a bit bummed like most players about only being able to carry 2 weapons, unlike the previous game were you could carry 8 (I think). It took me a while to see how this 2 weapon system is a lot better IMO. In Bioshock 1 & 2, I pretty much just used 2-3 weapons and it was a pain fumbling around with all the other weapons I had no interest in using. In Infinite you find a lot of the other weapons you aren't carrying around anyway, so it's not like you get stuck with crappy weapons you don't want. Plasmids are still in the game, but now called Vigors. Rather than leveling them up with Adam, you just upgrade them with money in vending machines. No big deal really. The new vending machines are an improvement over the old circus of value ones, I like them. The hacking is gone, don't really care really, after a while it became annoying in the previous games.This game is not about just eye candy, it has a fantastic story just like the previous Bioshock games.  But it does a better job at presenting it. The story is more interactive in this game than the previous, where it was pretty much all driven by the audio logs. Overall i really enjoyed the game. I finished it in 3 sittings. That is something i rarely do, I usually just play like 1/4 of the game and come back to it a few months later in episodes until i finish it. This kept my interest and never really felt dull. It is a great installment in the franchise and I can't wait to see where they take it from here.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2014
												Bring us the girl. Wipe away the debt.Bioshock Infinite is a fantastic First-Person shooter in the sense that it has fun gameplay with a strong narrative behind it,driving the game forward. You take the role as Booker Dewitt, a man we know nothing about, and you are asked to find the girl and if done so, you will wipe away the debt. The story seems to be simple but as the game goes along, it gets more intricate and by the end it had me in awe. Even the second time around. The dialogue and voice acting is some of the best I have ever heard (Troy Baker is God) and it really helps immerse the player into the world of Columbia. I found myself finding and playing every single voxophone, small voice recordings of characters, because I loved the side/back stories behind all the characters introduced.Elizabeth, the girl, is a strong female lead for the game because she is very likable. She has some great AI mechanics which do not hinder the fastpaced gameplay but instead make it more interesting and fun as Elizabeth throws whatever she can at your aid to benefit you. The gun mechanics feel very smooth and the added Vigors allow more variety to be in play from "shock powers" to "calling in a swarm of crows" powers and it really helps make the game so much more fun. Another aspect which makes the game so much fun is introduced a little into the game and it is the skylines. The skylines allow the player to ride above the ground and land off and attack or flank enemies from all over the area. The main story clocked in for me at about nine hours which I think was the perfect length for a game like this. I played the game originally when it released on the Playstation 3 and I enjoyed the feel of the game a whole lot more on PC. It runs better, it looks better, it plays better, it feels better, and it is better on the PC than the consoles. With some great dialogue, an intriguing story that keeps unraveling until the very end, and some very fun first person shooter combat, Bioshock Infinite is just one fantastic game. 9/10

Posted: April 5, 2013
												Wow.That's all I could say when I finished the game, this wasn't just another game, it was an experience, one of the best gaming experiences I've had yet.I loved the first two Bioshock games, but after several hours, rapture began to feel repetitive even it was an unique and interesting enviroment.Bioshock Infinite doesn't suffer from this problem at all, Columbia feels vibrant, alive and unique without dragging on one aspect from the city too long.Many will say that they feared that the FPS genre had reached it's capabilities, but this game is "the savior of FPSs" we've been waiting for, I think this game will reach the legendary status of Half Life 2 and the original Deus Ex.Every part of Columbia has a story to tell, even the restrooms!Let's take the restrooms for example here, the game is set in 1912 and the city of Columbia is an attempt to realise the American Dream, but the city relies heavily on immigrant workforces, while the well situated citizens have restrooms that looks almost like a palace, the restrooms of the african and asain workers are just tiles and broken sinks.There is also a ton of propaganda, posters and art all around Columbia which all serve a purpose and make the game even more immersive.The gameplay feels fluent and well executed, especially in the larger battles where you can jump on the so called "sky-lines" to soar across the battliefield and strike foes from above or even shoot them while riding the sky-line.The enemy AI isn't dumb either, they will follow you on sky-lines and try to block your way, handymen will even electrocute the whole line to force you off.The weapons and vigors (plasmids) also work great and a lot of combinations are possible, you could for instance lift a whole group of foes up in the air with the "Bucking Bronco" vigor and then let a swarm of vicious crows loose on them, and if you want you can lights said crown on fire as well!I've said "no game is perfect" many times, but I can't really come up with anything that this game doesn't execute well.10/10, absolutely worth every penny if you're a FPS lover or a sucker for an amazing story!

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												After the great Bioshock (one of my most favourite games of all times) and a quite mediocre Bioshock 2 I was curious if Bioshock Infinite would be so amazing as the previews mentioned. Now I am glad I just bought it on Steam Autumn Sale for less than 10 €...Bioshock 3 is a shooter, quite different from the previous titles. By the setting in a town, floating in the sky, it lost all of it's dark and terrifying atmosphere which made Bioshock once so great.So let's start by the good things:Bioshock 3 isn't bad at all. Technical:Graphically fitting you walk through a shiny world, see scyscrapers and go by the sky-line railsystem from platform to the other. I played the game with highest graphics, but it is only mediocre. Sound is ok, but not overwhelming.Fighting:Weapons are varying and for every taste you get some weapons. In my case the huntsman carbine and the pig flak volley gun... *cough*Enemies act not too stupid. Only few enemy types.The vigors, Jedi-like forces that support in quite funny ways, are quite different and function quite good. Story:The story seems easy at the start, but gets very twisted later. You might need more than playthrough to get everything of the story. Some few hidden places you can find while playing, giving you special equipment like hats and stuff.Now the bad things:I am totally disappointed. Forget the trailers...Technical:Graphically it is ok, but that's it. Nothing special.Another nuisance is the "invisible wall". In games from the 1990's an invisible wall as level-border can be accepted. In games from 2012/2013 NOT. Dear programmers, do me a favour: stop creating the illusion I could walk somewhere when I CAN'T!Fighting:Fights are mostly too chaotic. And the enemies can see through walls (in some cases also SHOOT through walls...).A lot of vigors, the half of it would have been already enough. I just used shock jockey, possession (only at the last airship level) and devil's kiss (which traps didn't work sometimes....). The rest is a nice idea. I missed a freezing power. Oh wait... THAT you get in a dlc. Amazing..............................Story:I enjoyed the story, it was pushing you forward, wanting to know what happens next. I really didn't expect the turns, ups and downs of the story. But the end: At first I was irritated, then thought of it all. Remebered the game.... and uninstalled. Seriously? After all these hours? Dear writers, I love good written stories. You did a pretty good job there, but this ending is the most stupid I have ever seen in a game. Ok, maybe not THE worst, but it is very close to that rank.Things that COULD have made Bioshock Infinite better:There could have been so many possibilities to play with the fear of heights of the players, but this chance was missed.I have a fear of heights, but wasn't one time afraid of falling down somewhere.Bugs like waving textures (really annoying in ingame-cutscenes), missing textures or missing sounds should be fixed before selling a game.Only three persons are consistant in this game, the player, Elizabeth, and the prophet. The other persons stay quite faceless.The enemies act ok, but they are all exchangable.If I hadn't bought the game on a Steam Sale, I would be now quite vexed.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2013
												BioShock Infinite... one of the most critically overhyped game, is THE biggest disappointment of the year for me by FAR.The game starts out very, very strong by showing you our character, Booker DeWitt and explaining why he has the mission to find a mysterious girl by the name of Elizabeth, and so is sent to the world of Columbia, a colossal city in atop the sky. I say it starts out strong is because it wastes no time in immersing you into what you immediately see a vast city filled with life and soul, but it quickly drops after you're introduced to the actual game.~Visuals           Right at the very beginning, you can see how beautiful the game is. With vibrant colors and clean textures for most of what you see. Although some items thruought the world of Columbia have muddy textures and just things that look downright lazy, it's essentially a nitpick when you see what the real focus of the game is - however those items are still present and detract from the overall ambiance. Enemy models and the such are varied throught the game when it switches the standard Columbia militia for members of a cult organization to supernatural entities.~Sound           Not much to say for this game. The game has a few ambiance setting melodies throughout to keep the mood running the way the situation calls for it, though generally you won't notice the music running in the background at all, there aren't any real unforgettable scores other than Elizabeth's Theme. The rest of the game does a fairly well job of relaying how guns work, the enemies yelling in the background mocking you, the distance of their gunshots, etc. My best mention sound wise, is the soundwork for Songbird - it is genually as creepy as the Big Daddy's cry in the original BioShock.~Gameplay            Sadly though, this is actually where the game faulters. The game quickly starts you on a shooting romp that is seemingly never ending without much variation. From the very first gunfight you have in the game, the only things that change is when you get more weapons, more vigors and Elizabeth starts using her powers, most of which, with the exception of Elizabeth, do nothing to improve the base gameplay the game has to offer.           You can use vigors (very similar to that of BioShock 1 & 2, but in here, you're better off going the "gung ho" way as the vigors on this game are pretty underpowered, nearly all of them, except for the "Shock Jockey" vigor, are damn near useless or do same thing as others do or does next to nothing at all(Lol wash away your enemies). Elizabeth presents the most to the gameplay as the game (I'm aware of the 90's mode the game has) gets incredibly easier when she tags along. Elizabeth can activate turrets, robots to help you get the enemy, decoys, cover, health, etc to help you in your battles, while there's not variation here either - it's still a welcome addition that's also pretty original in any game.           Sadly, the rest of the game can be summed up with one description: Shooting Gallery. The game literally consists of you moving from room to room in what the game tries to illusionate is an open world, but is actually a long corridor - you effectively run from room to room shooting dozens of enemies, kill them, run in a straight line to another room, kill more dozens of enemies ~ rinse and repeat. It tries to incorporate strategy by incorporating the "Skyhook" as a means to move about the combat area, but that only serves to be a cheap way of "saving bullets" and killing enemies and it generally very useless outside of combat and in areas that don't have a rail on 'em. All in all, the game was a disappointment for me as I was expecting more story and interactivity from a game that had promised just that. Instead I believe we got a game with an unsettling pace, extremely linear gameplay, a forgettable soundtrack and it was just overall a forgettable, generic experience.**Just to clear up some misconception - No, BioShock Infinite is not a bad game. It's not inherently broken or buggy (PC wise, it's actually one of the better ports out there), this is just what it is, an opinion, to me this game was one of the most repetitive experiences I've had this year and the story bits were too scarce for me to really get into it. I don't have fun mindlessly shooting wave after wave of enemies, if you do, then by all means get the game.

												Bioshock Infinite is the third in the Bioshock trilogy, bringing to a close the story of our Protagonist. A Steampunk-styled, dystopian alternate universe; However, instead of traveling to city at the bottom of the ocean, you are transported to a sky city where everything is Heaven-flavored, that is until it all goes to Hell. Fast. I have to admit, I sort of fell in love with the series after a short time playing the very first Bioshock. I found myself wanting to immerse myself in the story and learn all I could, while trying to survive not only the hidden things lurking around corners, but the scattered people who seem to have gone completely insane. This Bioshock was different. In this, the people of the sky city are told by their rulers, whom they almost seem to worship, that you are The Marked One, who must be killed. So instead of encountering people who are completely insane, you are chased, cornered, and attacked by people of thinly veiled sanity, from a once seemingly utopian society. I would recommend this game, as well as the entire Trilogy, as it was fun, exciting, and worth at least a playthough.

Posted: September 25, 2016
												If it weren't a BioShock game, I might have liked it better.I'll skip the poetic details and get straight into my gripes, in no specific order:-Repetitive gameplay that provides little challenge, even on the hardest difficulty.-Extremely linear level design that provides no challenge for advancing the game.-Whereas the previous BioShock games had level design that could convincable be used as a city, Infinite's Columbia wouldn't be mistaken for an actual city in a hundred years. Each area was clearly designed solely to be a combat arena, with the mere aesthetic of a city.-Boring, generic characters that all fit at least one archetypical mold.-The story, though sort of interesting in its own right, was predictable, anticlimactic, and ultimately strayed too far from the original BioShock storyline.-The "vigors" we too powerful, the AI was unintelligent, and the weapon/"vigor" upgrade system was way too easy to access, all of which leads back into the point of unchallenging gameplay.-The hacking system has been removed entirely.-Alternate Ammo Types have been removed (the Vox Varients could arguably be "ammo types," but that's stretching it).-The shield system makes the game very easy (ProTip: Invest in shields, not HP. Shields regenerate).-When your health does manage to get too low, you have to rely on Elizibeth for aid, because Health Packs have been removed.-Elizibeth's ability to open "tears" that give you another advantage in the fight were pure cheese.-Most of the weapons were far outshined by other weapons (I used the Carbine and Triple-R the whole game).-The "Equipment System" is a crappy reissue (downgrade, imo) of the Gene Tonic system.-The "Boss Enemies" are not a challenge.-There was only one real boss fight (two, if you count that the same boss is used twice).and lastly, and most firmly,-The Skylines. Whilst on them, you are practically invulnerable. When diving from them, your attack is a one hit kill. If a Skyline is in one of the fighting areas, I cheesed it to no end because why shouldn't I? That's what it's there for.All in all, the game would have been better had it not been called a BioShock game, but that only alleviates any problems I had with story and/or systems crossed over from previous games being changed for the worse (gene tonics to equipment, health packs to Elizibeth giving you health, etc.). The DLCs are actually more fun than the base game, but they are woefully short.I would recommend this game to Matthew Perry, the actor that portrayed Chandler in the extremely over-rated SitCom "FRIENDS."I hate Matthew Perry.

Coming from Bioshock, I was pressing keys "instinctively" in some fight scenes and it made it harder than it could have been. Weapon selection and "plasmid" selection tripped me up more than once. (tbh, I didn't check if there was an ability to change bindings and if there is, some may chose to for reasons just mentioned.)One small point if I may, weapon choices started to get silly. When entering a hostile area, the weapon "choice" offered sort of gave away what was coming so the element of surprise was taken away. I repeatedly found myself sticking with the carbine and the sniper rifle and not bothering much with some "ïnteresting" weapons that just didn't do the damage I expected given their implied "awesomeness". This was a let down in my view.Even some of the choices of the "secondary weapon"system" became confusing and I found I stopped using them at times because the effects were marginal or even completely unknown.All in all, a good game, beautifully presented and it held a special fascination for me. I just wish the playing field was a little less cluttered but perhaps, given other highly regarded reviews, it's just my age showing through.Pretty intense at times and without giving away too much, employing "AI" to assist at times was very well done. 8.5/10gg

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												BioShock Infinite, yet another game in the beloved BioShock series.  Or is it?The game is set in the year 1912.  Booker Dewitt accepts a job to travel to Columbia, a city suspended in the air, in order to retrieve a girl (Elizabeth) and wipe away his "debts".  I don't know how much else I can say without spoiling some bits, so I'll just get right into the review.You see, Inifinite not only has a different setting.  It's very, very different to the first two games, in fact.  So different to the point where one could easily say that it's just a game that only has a different, original setting (as well as some lovely throwback references to the series) in common with it's franchise.  That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed the game and find it to be a great addition.The game itself is fantastic.  The story was good, combat was quite good, the setting was fantastic and I found myself enjoying the characters (Elizabeth, The Lutece Twins and Songbird were probably my favourites.  Yes, even Songbird).One who tries to play this game as if it were the original BioShock (or the second) will not do too well.  This game is more of an open-ish world shooter with large areas to move around while in combat.  As well as this, the player can utilize Columbia's transport system (Sky-Lines, metal lines that one can traverse with a grappeling hook) to fight foes and move around the city.  It's a cool feature in general.When watching the game be played, the main fear I had was that Elizabeth would be constantly forced as a character I desperately needed to care about.  While this is true in some respects, I didn't neccesarily find her overbearing.  In fact, I began to enjoy her company as well as the character throughout the game.  That being said, though, she definitely isn't a companion; more of a follower.One thing to note is that you can no longer carry more than two weapons.  Apparently the downloadable-content "Burial at Sea" allows this once again as the player returns to the city of Rapture but since this is about the main game I'll just say it's a bit of a letdown.  I'm not thrilled that the change was made, but it's not something I believe you should focus on.Another thing to note is that the little "boss" characters that the character finds throughout the game aren't utilized very well.  I find that they're nowhere near as memorable as the Big Daddy characters that the player encounters in the first game.  It's a letdown indeed.  That brings me onto another topic; Plasmids.  Plasmids, or "Vigors" as they are now called, just aren't as memorable as the ones you encounter in Rapture.  On top of that, I only found myself using two or three of them on a regular basis compared to the first two games where I would use a wide variety.To sum it up, this is a good game that should keep you occupied.  If you're one who likes to play through games multiple times once you get it I'm sure this could keep you entertained for a while.  That being said, I still can't overcome my biased attitude towards the first game in the series and would definitely reccommend that, if you're willing to pay for this game, you at least consider getting the first one as well.

Posted: July 3, 2014
												As a gamer, I was of course excited to hear about another BioShock title in development, but I was skeptical towards its potential success. Upon release, BioShock: Infinite was praised with positive reviews that I personally noted, but they did not alter my skepticism. How wrong was I? Completely. Totally. Utterly. Rarely does any medium of entertainment--from books to movies---challenge my perceptions or affect my emotions. BioShock: Infinite did and I'm not sure why. The game is a virtual rollercoaster ride that mixes strong dramatization, story, characters and new gameplay mechanics that build up another one of Ken Levine's twisted dystopias. The game also offers one of the most compelling non-playable characters (NPCs) to date that will ultimately lure you into the world of BioShock. The game is beautiful, varied and philosophical in its representation. BioShock: Infinite has displaced the Mass Effect series as my all-time favorite game which is a statement unto itself considering the length of one game versus a trilogy. You owe it to yourself to enjoy the BioShock experience!

												(Just to let you know, I got only like 3-5 hours into Bioshock Infinite on my Ps3, so I can't get all things right since it has been quite a while.)Bioshock Infinite is a lot more different than the last two. Unlike the creepiness on Bioshock 1 and 2, this is more focused on Action. Your name is Booker, and you are trying to find this girl named Elizabeth who has some very strange, yet amazing powers. But the reason why this Town of Heaven went to Hell because AD is on your right hand, and the people are racist. So while you are on your quest, you have to kill police and other enemies.The combat can get intense, and sometimes you don't even know what is going on. Don't get me wrong, the combat is crazy fun, but sometimes it can get a bit out of hand. In Bioshock Infinite, you use Vigors (almost the same as plasmids) to get your powers, and you use Salt to cast some more. It can come from throwing Fireballs to summoning Crows to damage your enemies. The rail grinding, it can be the most fun thing in the game. Rail Grinding plus The Intense Action equals The Most Fun Out Of This Game.But since the combat is different, the controls were changed. V is the Melee, Q is to switch Vigors, and E to switch weapons. You can change the controls, but I think that getting used to the normal controls is the smartest idea.OVERALL:If you were expecting for this to be like actual Bioshock 1 or 2, you might be disappointed. But If you love intense action FPSs, you will love this game. I can't recommend this enough!

												This series is more story than game at this point. I felt like I was shooting enemies just so I could earn the next bit of exposition at times. One of the criticisms leveled against the first Bioshock was the drop in quality during the third act, after the climax. Those unhappy with the ending are welcome to try the DLC, although I doubt anyone looking for a happy ending will be satisfied with that either. I like sad stories so of course I thoroughly enjoyed it. As always, the value here depends heavily on your expectations. I have to agree with zero punctuation on this one - it's not perfect, you can point out the flaws, but its way more ambitious than most anything else that came out in the same year, which makes it GOTY. Sad that it didn't make enough money to keep the devs in business. AAA games may have to take a rest until they find a business model.

												BioShock Infinite is one of those games that you must play before you die, whether you are a fan of the FPS genre or not. The gameplay may be lacking in some parts if you compare it to the previous two titles (BioShock 1 in particular since both 1 and Infinite were made by Irrational), but it still provides a unique experience that you can't find in other shooter games. The story is also compelling enough to keep you interested. The concept of parallel universes, constants and variables can get very confusing down the line, and eventually you'll be left with feelings like "WTF just happened". But once you understand it, you can appreciate the story for what it is, and maybe even want more. The two central characters, Booker and Elizabeth, are also very well-designed. Troy Baker and Courtnee Draper's voice acting is top-notch. They really bring the characters to life, leaving a very good impression in the players.All in all, this game deserves to be called a masterpiece. 10/10, no discussion. Thank you Irrational and Ken Levine for making this game. Hope to see more projects from you guys in the future.

Posted: February 3, 2015
												Coming from someone who's beaten this game about 3 or 4 times now, with having beaten it very recently, I can definitely give this game two thumbs up from me! BioShock Infinite serves as an excellent addition to the BioShock franchise and if I must say, has become my favorite game of the series. It's a game that has an excellent story, interesting and loveable characters, amazing settings, and more. With the previous two games having both taken place in the underwater city of Rapture, it's nice to see this game take a departure from there and instead, having it take place a completely brand new, different setting, which is the floating city of Columbia. I also enjoyed the game's soundtrack and as well, was taken in by the graphics of the game. It isn't the top of the line realism graphics, but graphics that I find to be quite beautiful. And then there's Elizabeth! She has to be one of my favorite companions of any game. I could honestly go on about her for ages, but in short, she's a character I easily grew to love and who has a very interesting personality, as well as backstory. As well, a companion who is actually seems real as opposed to a not so smart AI. One of my favorite things of this game though is that the city of Columbia as a whole and it's people, as well as so much of the game taking place in bright settings like outside and such, at first glance, it seems like one of those bright, positive games. While this game does have it's brighter, cheerful moments, underneath all that, at the core, I believe BioShock Infinite to be a darker game, when you consider certain parts of the storyline and such, especially when delving deep into the story. Overall, I've had loads of fun playing this game and think it to be a masterpiece of a game, if I do say so myself. I'd recommend this game to anyone without second thoughts!

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
												I just finished the last DLC of this game (Burial at Sea Episode 2), and I'm just blown away by this amazing work of art.This game is simply amazing. There will be spoilers ahead for anyone who hasn't played this yet. Story ----------------------------------Bioshock Infinite's story is possibly one of the most complex stories that I've ever encountered in a game. The whole concept of infinite universes and 'constants and variables' is an ever present theme throughout the series. After completing the base game, I was left with a few questions, but the two follow-up DLCs: Burial at Sea 1 & 2, gave me such an emotional and satisfying ending that I was left with no ill-feelings. I'll just say straight up that if you love a good story, which is so massive and complex, yet understandable, this game is perfect for you. Gameplay ----------------------------------Bioshock Infinite has some very enjoyable gameplay. Combining FPS, with rapid skylines, and vigors (special abilities), makes this game mind blowingly awesome. Every shot, every power, feels impactful. The visual detail is stunning for a game which has an almost 'cartoony' feel to it. Riding skylines, and hopping from location to location feels amazing and action-filled as you quickly hop off to take down an enemy, only to run back and swing along looking for your next target. For the more tactical players, setting off vigor traps, or possessing enemy structures can turn the tide of battle in an instant. The weapons....oh man the weapons. The time period of this game brings back all the 'old-school' weapons which have a certain kind of feel to them which can't be explained. The detail of the gun models, the sounds, the firing rate, and the damage it inflicts just gives a satisfying feeling at the end of a battle. There are all kinds of weapons for any kind of player. Snipers, pistols, shotguns, grenade launchers, and a ton more. Gameplay wise, this game deserves a playthrough at the very least...but no, there's more...Characters----------------------------------Oh my god, where do I begin?? First off, Elizabeth is possibly the most lovable, attractive, helpful character I've ever seen in a game, period.The voice actors for both Booker, and Elizabeth are simply amazing. They made the characters feel so real, so personal, and the story could not have gone anywhere without top quality voice actors.There's literally paragraphs upon paragraphs I could write about this masterpiece of a game, but no, buy this game and it's DLCs. Play it. Enjoy it. 9.9/10  I wanted Elizabeth to live :'( If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is a memorable action game that is somewhat let down by its game mechanics and story.Let get this clear: the world that Bioshock Infinite presents is truly breathtaking as if the creators knew exactly what people had in mind when they imagined a city above the clouds. The city of Columbia is a marvel to look at, and its exploration stays enjoyable until the very end of the game. It is a breathing, living world that really makes this game remarkable and for this reason alone I recommend getting the game and playing through it at least once.However, I wish I could say the same things about the gameplay and the story. While the skyrail is a joy to use, the shooting simply does not feel satisfying and the enemies are too bullet-spongy. Even though you gain superhuman powers throughout the course of the game, you simply do not feel powerful.It doesn't help that I played the game on 1999 mode which in itself, is a joke, because there is simply nothing "1999ish" about it. Your health regenerates, exploration for ammo and health is very limited, and the checkpoint system also does not improve on the situation. The developers thought they made this mode harder because you can only die a number of times (I'm not sure if I remember this correctly), but you can easily cheat the system if you just reload the checkpoint before the death animation finishes. Sure, you could spam the quicksave-quickload buttons back in 1999, but you still were on the edge of your seat due to conserving ammo and health.(Not to mention the fact that every time you reload the game, the item drops RANDOMIZE. I have no idea who thought this was a good idea. Sure, some bullets or health here and there could vary I guess, but even the gameplay-affecting modifiers too?)The story, while it starts out strong, it gets way too stuck up its own♥♥♥♥♥towards the end of the game. While I enjoy a complex story and even the dimension-jumping element was a good surprise ( I also managed to get around 70 of the audiologs), explaining what the hell happened in the last 5 minutes is not good storytelling. It seems as if the developers had all these crazy ideas what should happen throughout the campaign but ultimately failed to wrap things up nicely.Ultimately, I give this a recommendation because the game really shines in its world-building and atmosphere. If you go in expecting a remarkable if somewhat flawed shooter, you're going to get your money's worth out of Bioshock Infinite.However, if you're a Shock-fan that has played through the System Shocks and the first Bioshock, I recommend waiting for a sale.

content:
Posted: April 28, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is an OK game. Let’s just put that on the table. This is pretty good. But that whole “the defining game of our generation” crap swirled around in the media by “reviewing” sites such as IGN are wrong. This game is not revolutionary.First off, the game-play. Bioshock Infinites game-play plays disappointingly similar to the original Bioshock, that’s not to say it’s bad, just not very different. Plasmids from Bioshock 1 have been replaced by Vigors which carry slightly different abilities and are taken orally instead of through injection. Some abilities are really fun to play around with, such as Possession, allowing you to take control of nearby enemies and make them fight for you for a brief period. Another good one is Return to Sender, allowing you to blast back damage taken from enemies and absorb attacks. It seems however, all other 6 Vigors are just means to either straight up damage your enemies, or disable them for a short time to allow you to shoot them. You tend to pick two or three Vigors you like using (for me it was Shock Jocky, Possesion and Bucking Bronco) while all the others are sort of just forgotten about. However, playing on harder difficulty mode does sort of force you to use other Vigors to get little creative. Another thing I found strange was that some of the Vigors, namely Undertow and Return to Sender are only entered into the game in the last few hours, leaving no really chance to get a feel for them.Gun-play is solid; each gun feeling like it has strong differences to the others the others, allowing you to choose which is best for you. However, the upgrade system for the guns is really poor. They basically give damage bonuses, recoil reduction and increased clip size in exchange for in-game currency. No form of attachments or customizations on the guns at all, which while not really necessary, would have been nice.The soundtrack, visuals and voice acting are all exquisite, couldn’t really fault them if I tried. I played this back on my old PC at low Graphics and game still looks amazing.Now, the story. If you're interested enough to play the game, stop reading here, just to avoid any minor spoilers.It is to me at least, decently executed and fits into the feel of the game. All the characters are well-written, especially Elizabeth, whose backstory and mysterious powers is the most interesting aspect of the story. The point when the plot becomes controversial however is the end. There is a huge plot twist that is hinted slightly throughout the game but never really realised until the end that will leave many people a little dumb-founded. Some people love this shock factor in media. That said, while being starling, it is by no means original, it’s be done before and been done better. Regardless, the game is still executed well and the story is of enough credit enough to warrant a play-through.Don’t believe the hype of this game, it is, like all other hyped games, nowhere near as good as people say it is. But don’t let stop you from playing.

As a man haunted by the crimes of his past, you embark on quest designed to find you solace, but only thrusts you further into a world of sin. BioShock Infinite dares to explore the powerful ideas of virtue and God through an emotional storyline that will leave you on the edge of your seat.

Posted: January 8, 2015
												Rating 9/10Overview: First Person ShooterThe Good:+ As is the case with every Bioshock game proceeding this one, the world, setting and atmosphere is the main attraction and this game is no different. The city of Columbia is beautiful and one of the most interesting and unique game settings to play in. + Graphically both artistically and technically this game is gorgeous. Easily one of the best looking games on PC to date. + The story is fantastic dealing with major themes such as racism, morality, religion and faith. A game that should leave a lasting impression on you long after you finish it. + Elizabeth one of the main NPC's is incredibly helpful in and out of combat, providing you with health, ammo, money etc. The developers did a great job making her realistic and helpful and not a hindrance.  + The game introduces vigors (identical to plasmids from previous Bioshock games) that give you special powers such as charging enemies, shocking, possessing etc that give you an advantage in combat.+ Plenty of weapons/vigors to fit your play style. You can charge in and blast your enemies with shotguns or stay back and snipe with a sniper rifle. + The game introduces skylines for you to ride on adding an extra gameplay element to combat. You can jump on and off the the skylines at will to either attack enemies from above or to escape a potentially dangerous situation. +The three pieces of DLC are very enjoyable. Clashes in the Clouds is a horde mode across 4 levels and 15 waves each. The goal obviously is to survive each wave and if possible complete the bonus objective. Burial at Sea part 1 and 2 tie in the story of Infinite with the events of the first game. Although the story may be a bit contrived in doing so it was still nice to revisit Rapture from a different point of view. Each episode introduces some new gameplay elements. The first episode being more action oriented while the second being more stealth oriented. + Great music and soundAverage- Other than the inclusion of skylines the gunplay introduces nothing new. You can also only carry 2 weapons at one time which feels very limiting compared to the previous games. - Throughout the game you will find pieces of equipment for you to wear. You can equip a total of 4 pieces. The problem is the vast majority of equipment you find is terrible and offers little to no value. The few that are good can really break the game. There is no balance. -The last gameplay segment is uninspiring. I got the feeling the developers ran out of time/creative ideas.ConclusionYou really have to love the world, story and characters to really appreciate this game. If you play it solely for the gameplay you may find yourself a tad disappointed. I personally loved the game I only wish the world was more open ended for me to explore at my own pace.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is easily one of the greatest games I've had the pleasure of playing.Graphically, it ushers in a new standard for the PC. Set in a backdrop of a 1930s city, the environment is vibrant and colorful, but not distracting towards gameplay, although the same cannot be said for the heroine Elizabeth ( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°). The textures and intricate details put into the surroundings and characters allow for a spectacularly immersive experience, all the while being well optimised and running smoothly for most mid to high end computers.Just like its predecessors, the storyline for Bioshock Infinite is fairly dark. This certainly does not seem to be the case at first when you enter the idyllic, utopian city in the sky that is Coloumbia–it appears nothing like the dingy underwater city of Rapture in the past two games. However it soon becomes evident that there is much more than meets the eye.Instead of the generic, faceless protagonist in many FPS games, you play as Booker Dewitt, a man with his own agenda, motivations...and regrets. Tasked with retrieving a girl named Elizabeth from the city of Coloumbia, the two develop a complicated bond as they rely upon and learn about each other in their bid to escape from Coloumbia. There is very strong character development in both Booker and Elizabeth as the story progresses, on par with a well-written novel. The plot also progresses at a enjoyable pace with many twists along the way. Although the story is linear, there are moral choices that the player has to make along the way, and you are constantly reminded of that choice for the rest of the game. Despite several plot holes, the story was one of the best I have experienced for a video game, to the extent that I feel that the game would have remained a masterpiece even if combat gameplay was removed and it was made into a visual novel with the same cutscenes.Therein lies the only mediocre aspect of Bioshock Infinite: the actual combat. Although there are some fairly innovative features, such as shooting while moving along aerial rails at high speed, much of the FPS elements fail to leave a big impression. The weapons and abilities that you can use feel largely similar, just as most of the enemies that you fight. There seems to be little variation in tactics involved, the player simply guns baddies down from one area to the next. This is further limited by the fact that you can only have 2 weapons and 2 active abilities at a time. Combat is also hardly challenging with little disincentive to dying. On death the player respawns at the location, with only the surviving enemies from the past engagement healed–already killed enemies do not respawn. This means that you could just slowly try to kill an enemy one at a time before dying if you are having difficulty in a fight, rinse and repeat until you manage to clear it.Despite these drawbacks, I feel that Bioshock Infinite has redefined videogames and the FPS genre as a storytelling medium, and I certainly look forward to replaying it again. (In fact, this lengthy review was written in a bid to stave off that feeling of dejection that one gets after clearing a really good game/book. I hope that stands as a testament to how brilliant this game is.)10/10

Posted: February 3, 2014
A lighthouse, a cryptic message, and an impossible city. The stage is set for another adventure through the grim, but surprisingly sunny, world of Bioshock. The original Bioshock is a landmark in immersive videogame narrative and incredible design. It combined wonderfully designed aestethics with cool gameplay elements and a nice story to boot. For those who were truly interested there was plenty of room to explore and learn more of the fallen city of Rapture. Infinite then had a lot to live up to.Infinite takes you to the flying city of Columbia, a seceded state from early America that left the blasphemous world below behind to ascend to a plane closer to god. You're former private eye with a checkered past who is hired to retrieve a girl from this flying utopia. How hard can it be?Plenty hard. As it turns out, you're expected, and they're not happy. Inifite has you duke it out in the streets of Columbia while listening to the zealous chants of radical prophets and out of control rebels. The atmosphere is piled on at every turn and the game spares no expense to show you new and crazier things than you held possible. It is an exercise in world building of the highest order that adresses social, racial and religious themes to make you, the player, contemplate your actions and you make your way through the game. However, for all the grandeur and splendor found in its presentation, the execution leaves something to be desired. Do not misunderstand, the story unfolds perfectly and you're still given room to explore. The problem is in the gameplay. Infinite borrows much of its combat from the original Bioshock, but trims away a lot of the fat and only leaves a bare bones set of options. Most battles revolve around bullet pumping and a bit of power flailing, while the combat systems in Bioshock 2 introduced so many cool things. This is Infinite's main problem. After a few hours, the sun doesn't shine so bright anymore while you stride into another gunfight. Luckily, Infinite spares no expense to keep the pace up so you can make your way through the story at a proper pace. This makes it a game to be enjoyed for its content, while it skimps a bit on the gameplay. That said, if you fancy yourself a masochist, feel free to dive into the 1999 mode. A super hard mode that leaves you reeling if you don't prepare. That'll keep you occupied for a while. Still, Bioshock Infinite is an experience you will need to try at least once.

Posted: May 28, 2014
												It's undeniable that the first Bioshock has advanced the narrative in this medium quite a bit, and Infinite is just another step in the right direction. Of course you get the amazing narrative you'd expect; Elizabeth is one of the best companions in gaming. The developers took their time in developing her character and build the relationship between her & Booker. A character of this quality has not been done since Half Life 2, and even then the comparison falls in Infinite's favor.The level design is another standout. The addition of the skyline was ingenious as it allowed the developers to open up the map in a way where it complimented the setting of a city in space.Superpowers, now called vigors instead of plasmids, allows the player to mix a match their play style. There's a decent selection of vigors that allows the player to experiment with certain combos and leads to some replay value. Some of the returning powers from the old game have been streamlined to allow for easier management. For example, instead of having to switch between enemy specific plasmids, the power of possession now encompasses all enemies. This aids the somewhat clumsy interface that plagued the first game.There is simply no other game like Infinite at the moment. It is frankly one of the most memorable games I've ever had the luxury of playing. Thanks to the superb narrative and game design, Infinite will sit in my mind for days to come.
