content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is the third in the Bioshock series and takes place in a different environment. Both Bioshock 1 & 2 took place in the underwater city of Rapture, while Infinite takes place in the flying city of Columbia. In general though, the gameplay between the three games is very similar and if you liked parts 1 & 2, you should like Infinite as well.A recap in case you haven’t played any of the Bioshock games yet:Bioshock 1 showed what might happen in a world ruled by extreme practicality, everyone looking out for their own best interest. A man named Andrew Ryan created the equivalent of Atlas Shrugged’s “Atlantis.” In the underwater city of Rapture, there was economics without government oversight, art without censorship, and science without ethics. Imagine what the Olympics would be like if all athletes were allowed to take steroids or be otherwise enhanced. Rapture collapsed (figuratively) when people started “splicing” freely.  A substance called Adam was discovered from deep sea slugs that could be used to transfer modified genetic material to people. Everyone could buy these “plasmids” giving themselves superhuman powers and other genetic modifications. Unfortunately people became addicted to this “self-improvement” and a kind of civil war broke out which ended up leaving the city a ghost town. You show up in the final days of the city and try to find your way back to the surface.In Bioshock 2, you learn more about the final days of Rapture, as well as what happened after the fall. A psychiatrist Sofia Lamb came to Rapture to try to solve the city’s problems, but she ended up creating an even bigger divide amongst the citizens. Dr. Lamb saw the potential to create a true Utopia (perfect world) but realized that to have a Utopian city requires Utopian citizens (everyone living to serve the greater good).  She tried to create the first Utopian using Adam gene splicing, with the result being a superhuman with all the memories and super powers of everyone in the city (bad idea). You play a different character from the first game trying to rescue someone held captive in the city a couple years after the events of Bioshock 1.The story of Bioshock Infinite actually takes place before parts 1 or 2. In the flying city of Columbia, the opposite of Rapture has happened. The city is ruled by religion and actually seems like a great place (if you’re not a racial minority). Bear in mind that this takes place in the early 1900’s so there’s a lot of racism and discrimination. The first half hour of the game you might be shocked at how awesome Columbia is, with no crime, and everything is on the honor system. People don’t need to watch their stores because nobody steals. Instead of worshipping God, the people of Columbia seem to worship the Founding Fathers of the United States (George Washington, Ben Franklin, etc.). The city is controlled by “the Prophet” with the people gladly giving their lives for him if needed. As you go along you find that under the surface, the city is on the verge of revolution. You play the character Booker DeWitt, a private detective looking for a girl being held prisoner somewhere in Columbia. When you find the girl Elizabeth, you realize that she has the power to create dimensional rifts and is revered (and feared) by the people of Columbia as a kind of messiah who will bring destruction to the sinful world below. The story is pretty complicated since it involves dimensional travel (maybe time travel?) and a lot of shifting loyalties. I’m still not 100% sure of what happened in the end but it’s a gripping ride nevertheless.Bioshock Infinite is a First Person Shooter similar to Half-Life 2 in that it has no out of body “cut scenes.” You see everything from the view of Booker DeWitt with the story happening around you. There isn’t too much variety in weapons, although a few of the weapons have different “versions” since they’re used by different factions in the story. The game has “vigors” which are basically the same as plasmids in the first 2 Bioshock games. Think of them as magic powers that you find along the way. You have a health bar and a “salts” bar (mana) and you find a lot of health and salt pickups, many of which are dropped by enemies when they die. The game also seems easier than Bioshock 1 & 2 because Elizabeth is with you most of the time as your ammo / health supplier. You don’t need to escort her and she tosses you items occasionally when you’re almost overwhelmed.Pros:+Excellent story that you “live” instead of read about. In Bioshock 1 & 2, you mostly learn the story by listening to recordings.+Decently long game with a lot of replay value. I’ve played through the game 3 times and I’m keeping it on my hard drive to play again.+There’s a lot of variety in environment. You’re not stuck in an underwater city this time. You can fight in the sunny outdoors, flying along skylines, or in a “haunted house.”+The price is pretty low for this game. It was so critically acclaimed that it’s constantly a sale headliner.Cons:-No multiplayer, but frankly I don’t see how multiplayer would add much. Maybe a co-op mode would be nice but is unnecessary.-A huge bunch of the Steam achievements are for the game’s DLCs. I usually don’t buy DLCs and the Season Pass for the game is as expensive as the main game :(Overall, Bioshock Infinite is definitely recommended to fans of shooter games and good stories. So many people seem to have the game that you could probably use Steam’s family sharing to play it off of your friends’ accounts. It’s a pretty big download but definitely worth it.

												Short summary: best story in Bioshock games so far, but worst gameplay.First, I will list everything that went wrong with Bioshock Infinite: Levels are mostly linear: just run and gun from point A to B, very little incentive to explore. There are no level maps. With the ability to ride sky lines, Bioshok Infinite is literally a rail shooter.In rare cases when you find some "secret" stuff, game lists it as a secondary objective: "you found a closed box, go look for the key". Thankfully, there's no path marker leading to the key.No combination locks. Instead you pick up generic lockpicks and use them to unlock any locked door or safe. There's one door locked with obligatory 0451 code, but it's opened in a cutscene without player's input. You can only carry two weapons. If you run out of ammo for both equipped guns, you're forced to run around the battlefield and search for a new weapon to swap or sit in cover and wait until Elizabeth throws a loaded weapon at you. There is only one ammo type per weapon. Weapons and their upgrades are more boring now: ordinary pistols, shotguns, grenade launchers etc. Upgrades do not change how the weapon looks. No more crazy revolvers with two cylinders, electric shotguns and spear launchers.No passive tonics. Partially replaced by gear, but it's limited to four slots total: hat, shirt, pants and boots, with no ability to increase this limit. Also you cannot mix and match any effects as you wish, as every gear piece can only be equipped in its designated slot.No first aid kits or EVE hypos. When you're getting low on health in a fight you're have to drop everything and run around searching for a tear with health packs or you're dead. The're a small shield that regenerates when not under attack, but enemies destroy it in couple of hits (on hard difficulty at least).No vita chambers. You're probably wondering why is it a bad thing - it's because in previous two games vita chambers could be disabled in settings. In Infinite you have no choice but to accept your "revival" and lose money in the process. There are no manual saves anymore too, so there are no reasonable way to bypass that if you liked to play without vita chambers before.  Hacking was removed. There's a plasmid (or vigour, how they call them here) that serves a similar purpose, but it only works for a short time and huge drain on salt (EVE). Using it on a vending machine makes it drop a small amount of money instead of decreasing sell prices.I'm still recommending to play Bioshock Infinite for the story - it's worth it regardless of shooting mechanics and exploration. Just set the difficulty to easy, don't repeat my mistake.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2015
												BioShock Infinite is an artistic masterpiece. Beautiful, suspenseful, and haunting at times; it captures a blending of history and myth to create something both wonderfully unique and familiar. Elizabeth is one of the best characters to ever appear in a game and the world is beautiful.Story: 10/10 As we all come to expect from Irrational, the plot of this game is bursting with rich parallels, powerful emotional imagery and an ending (brilliantly foreshadowed throughout) that will leave you both satisfied and begging for more. Ambiance: 10/10 This is where the game really shines. Each set-piece alone could be a work of art, each architectural blend, each cultural costume. All of the visual splendor mixed together with a score that perfectly juxtaposes the glamor and grit of what Columbia represents. Gamplay: 10/10 I expected a rich story and beautiful visuals/music, what I did not expect was game-play (particularly combat) that surpassed Irrationals previous games in terms of enjoyment and dynamic action. This game takes everything that we loved from previous BioShock games and adds a whole new level of tactical planning and on the fly improvisation. Each combat area is a stage set for a brilliant play, each enemy adding new challenge, each weapon a chance to master. Never has combat been so challenging and satisfying in a BioShock game.

												9/10"As you can see, Booker, the inmates run the asylum." Four years on from its release this game is still a gem, proving to be a pyschological thriller with mystifying twists and turns. While some of the game does lag and is noticeably boring in parts, the eventual tying of the story in of itself, and to the Bioshock franchise as a whole, is thoroughly well thought out and expertly crafted. Bioshock unlike most other games allows players the freedom and diversity of a well equiped arsenal that can be upgraded, leading to you changing your approach in dealing with different foes. The graphics are beautiful and not at all dated; while the textures and lighting are also superb. The game feels easier than Bioshock 1 and 2 and, Elizabeth, plays her part in this by routinely finding you ammo and coins to stock up on. That said the final fights of the game are much more challenging. If you pay £10 or under for this game you've found yourself a bargain.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is absolutely amazing, the shere attention to detail and the gripping story made all the time spent looking in every corner of every random lane and fighting wave after wave of interesting (but occaisionally dull) enemies a blast and had justified the 20+ hours I have spent on this game. I found the story in the beginning a bit slow and uneventful, but the bright and glamorous world made up for that with interesting dialogue, spoken by the people lining the streets and the great showcase of the indoctrination of the people by Father Comstock. As the story/game progresses things change dramatically, throwing in plenty of combat and spicing up the story perfectly.After ruthlessly slaughtering countless numbers of enemies I found the combat got a bit dull, and in a way a bit easy after getting most of the upgrades and new weapons/vigors. The enemies are also a bit on the bland side, since most of them are just a darkish colour and little detail on the uniforms I found my self killing what I thought was the same person over and over again, this was especially prevalent towards the end of the game.The combat incorperates a lot of 'fantasy' into it, with things like Vigors and more modern guns with a little less realism and less punch. The physics of the weapons felt great too, they were not way too unrealistic but they weren't too reaslistic either, which provided a nice blend making those heads look as bigger target as always. If I were to have 1 major complaint about the guns it would be how underpowered some guns can be towards the end of the game, where I ran out of ammo for  my sniper and had only a pistol as a replacement. The pistol been my main weapon at the beginning of the game and could take down enemies in what felt like 1 blow, but the pistol had no such effect when taking down the same enemies later on, making one have to completely spray all their ammo at the opponents head to actually take them down.At the end of the story things get very weird and confusing but when the game ends, most previous events in the game begin to come together, but some do not leading to a lot of confusion and possibly sequels (?). The end left me wanting to play again, so that I can find all those little events that link to the main plot and then giggle, thinking about "how could I have not noticed this before?"This game is one of a small ammount of games that have left me happy and satisfied at the end, and I can definately see myself playing it again sometime in the future. To get a game this great for only $10 was itself amazing. I have seen games that cost a lot more and has been realeased a lot earlier, that are absolutely terrible. Overall I believe Bioshock Infinite to be well worth the time and money, and that Irration games & 2K have done an exellent job, creating what is probably, a masterpiece. I would definately recommend getting this game, and I guarantee (A guarantee? Who has time for all that paperwork?)  you will have fun!  I give it a 10/10

												I've had some time to think about this game, and here are my overall thoughts. (SPOILER-FREE)Bioshock Infinite is at its core an average single-player shooter game. However, this is not what compelled me to pick it up. I picked this game up for around 10 bucks during the Steam Black Friday sale, hearing that the story was excellent, and far better than what you'd see in an everyday shooter. After about a month of letting it sit in my library, I gave it a try. Damn, were my friends right. The story is what MADE the game. The world of Colombia is sprawling and full of life, which is surprising due to the subject matter. The character of Elizabeth gave the game heart and a way to convey its story through someone else's eyes, rather than the focused and violent sight of Mr. Booker Dewitt. The ending left me speechless, and I talked to my friends about it for hours. I tried the other Bioshocks, but they were not even close to the fun I had with Infinite. They were far too dark and overall lacked the polish of Infinite. Infinite's choice of a lighter atmosphere and a gripping story reeled me in and gave me an overall great experience. It was worth every penny.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2014
												I've always been a fan of the Bioshock series and irrational games as a company, I even thought Bioshock 2, made by 2K was a great game, not as good as the others in the series but definitely worth your time.March 2013, the release of Bioshock: Infinite.Who knew, that a game could have such an emotional pull on someone. That it could make you feel and care for the characters, so much that you would be thinking about them, worrying for them and doing everything in your humanly power to make sure that everything went the way you wanted it too. That is the feeling Bioshock: Infinite will bring to you and anyone who plays this game and truly immerses themselves in the story, putting yourself in the shoes of Booker Dewitt and getting the feeling that these in game events are actually happening and that you are involved.This is the best game in the Bioshock series, without a doubt, simple things like the main character being able to speak and having a companion,to huge things like the world being fueled by slavery, racism and capitalism, not to mention the fact that the game is absolutely stunning visually and the added feature of zipping through parts of columbia on sky hooks and landing on enemies heads to send them flying through the air and off the map are all features that make this game such a unique and mind blowing experience.The characters are amazing, the gameplay is easy to pick up and the story is the best story I have ever experienced in a game, the link up with the city in the sky Columbia to the underwater utopia that is Rapture is special and the added DLC of Burial at Sea parts 1 and 2 that bring the Bioshock series to a close, is some of the finest storytelling that not just gaming has ever seen, ENTERTAINMENT has ever seen (Yes better than TLOU).In short, buy this game and play it, I have completed this game 3 times already on the Xbox (where my original playthroughs are) completed all the DLC, and I fully expect to be going back to play this game time and time again, I 100% hope this isn't the end of Bioshock as a series, but if it is, all I can say is it has been an amazing journey, and Bioshock sits at the top of my most treasured games list and will for a long time.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is a contendor for Game of The Year only for its story, the gameplay is subpar. The Story is as you come to expect from the creators of Bioshock, you wander around a city for awhile trying to complete a goal that will lead you to the big twist at the end of the game. It was done very well because of the voice acting, pacing, writing, and its impact. However, the gameplay was extremely boring. First off, all you did was verse the same 2 enemy types that never change over the course of the 17 hour campaign. Then you have the vigors , which are explained in a cool way but are just various forms of stun that distract the enemy for about half a second. The Handymen  and the Motorized Patriots were sad attempts at trying to recreate the Big Daddy that didn't offer any reward. Next, you can only carry 2 weapons that never seem to have enough ammo and make you feel underpowered. Finally you can't carry salts or health packs, so when you run out you have to wait for Elizabeth to "fetch" you some. If you like a good storybased game then i would recommand this game for you. But if your a fps junky then this game will annoy you too much to finish it.

This game comes out of the gates hot with its hype and irrefutable beauty; which apparently is all you need to sell a game these days. Anyone who has played previous Bioshocks can tell you that Ken Levine can't write an ending to save his life, and this game is only different than its predecessors in as it falls from greater heights at a much earlier point in the story. As fast as the characters' qualities and personalities are developed they are confused and lost. Pepare for all your questions of the mysteries of this game to be answered by questions and those questions to be answered with riddles so vague that you could comfortably fill in the blanks yourself out of confusion and a desire to know what is not there; but I'm not biting.  Its a cup and ball trick story, whichever cup you choose you can be sure that the real answer is in Levine's pocket.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2015
Set in Columbia, an impossible floating city comprised of a multitude of structures, Bioshock Infinite approaches a similar layout to the first game in the series-not taking into account the System Shock video games-and redefines it from a horror-based open-world story set in the underwater city of Rapture to a more linear swashbuckling adventure with intricate combat sequences as well as platforming elements. I understand that a lot of individuals who favored the first game did so because of very specific ideals-myself being one of them-but I must admit that Bioshock Infinite is still a solid, enjoyable experience; they are both special in their own ways, and should both be given a chance. You play as Booker Dewitt as he travels to said city of Columbia in search of a young woman, Elizabeth, whom he plans to hand over to wipe away a debt he owes; this results in an exciting tale of hardship and intense action.Here are just a few of the features that I enjoyed about Bioshock Infinite:Theme - I am not one to hold a ‘controversial’ theme to my heart because I understand completely that the developers had no intension of offending anyone, so whoever protests “racism” toward this title can listen to one of my favorite Eagles songs titled Get Over It. Most of Columbia’s history melds closely around issues similar to the Civil War, when African American citizens were identified as property, so Bioshock Infinite utilizes the concept of slavery to demonize the majority of citizens and ruling party throughout the game. Comstock chooses African Americans as a favored enemy-therefore receiving a bonus to all attack a damage rolls when facing against them in combat (Dungeons and Dragons joke, do not mind me)-and believes them to be an impure race; this, as well as religious affiliations, paints a majority of individuals within Columbia whom endlessly idolize Comstock as members of a blind faith, and believe him to be some sort of messiah. This hook (pun intended) is a twisted yet interesting one to exploit since the first Bioshock game also features few pseudohistorical references.  Along with the cast of this game, the theme develops into quite a gripping tale unlike many.Gameplay - The key feature that separates Infinite from other ‘Shock’ titles is the swashbuckling gameplay revolving around the Skyhook. With the ability to magnetize to hanging rails above, this new item allows the player to melee strike without the need to switch weapons, perform executions on damaged enemies, and even adds an element of platforming to the fray. Vigors reappear within Infinite’s story but modify play as an addition to combat such as in previous Bioshock titles. Fluid gameplay is also included in this installment, though players may only carry two weapons at a time; though this is one of the newer features to the ‘Shock’ games, it is also one which previous fanatics did not enjoy due to it too closely resembling a modern first person shooter title while also shying away from the first game. Overall, despite its minor setbacks in its combat system, Bioshock Infinite’s gameplay blends very well with story elements and sequences.(Partially) Open World - Though certain sections are closed off after specific story progressions, Bioshock Infinite permits the player to backtrack through previous segments to loot silver dollars-the currency in this title-, health and salt boosts, and to finish side quests, which generally direct players off-route in order to gain other helpful advances. This system is just open enough to fit the swashbuckling style without sacrificing story elements.Clothing/Perk System - Within the numerous actions Booker Dewitt can perform are an array of combination attacks and tactics; however, a player may become too accustomed to one set of combat maneuvers to attempt any of the other functions of the games such as the Skyhook’s flying melee attack. This is where the clothing system comes into play. Clothing acts as a perk or upgrade system since various actions-such as said Skyhook drop-can be modified to obtain additional effects. For example, there is an article of clothing that grants all of the player’s melee attacks chained electrical damage as well as the base melee damage, which would entice players to attempt using melee attacks more frequently. This system, though, could be considered a double-edged blade as it may also provoke players to adopt new strategies or cause them to become dependent on a specific set of upgrades and, subsequently, actions; either way, it is an interesting concept.1999 Mode - Unlocked after completing the game’s campaign at least once, 1999 mode offers a challenge to players that seek it. In this mode, players take increased damage from enemy attacks and the respawn system is dramatically altered in that you lose one hundred silver dollars when you die. Not being able to pay this fee upon death means losing all progress in the current save slot. This offers a fun and challenging experience to those that believe they have mastered this game and wish to juggle expenses between vending machines and life itself.TL:DR - It is difficult  to say what has already been said about this award-winning title. Bioshock Infinite blends well with the gameplay of its predecessors while also retaining some original elements, as well as telling an outstanding story packed with intense action, twists, and sorrow. Infinite is certainly a title to explore if you have not done so, prior fanatic to the series or not. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												This game is a contendor for Game of The Year only for its story, the gameplay is subpar. The Story is as you come to expect from the creators of Bioshock, you wander around a city for awhile trying to complete a goal that will lead you to the big twist at the end of the game. It was done very well because of the voice acting, pacing, writing, and its impact. However, the gameplay was extremely boring. First off, all you did was verse the same 2 enemy types that never change over the course of the 17 hour campaign. Then you have the vigors , which are explained in a cool way but are just various forms of stun that distract the enemy for about half a second. The Handymen  and the Motorized Patriots were sad attempts at trying to recreate the Big Daddy that didn't offer any reward. Next, you can only carry 2 weapons that never seem to have enough ammo and make you feel underpowered. Finally you can't carry salts or health packs, so when you run out you have to wait for Elizabeth to "fetch" you some. If you like a good storybased game then i would recommand this game for you. But if your a fps junky then this game will annoy you too much to finish it.

Posted: March 10, 2014
												I've had some time to think about this game, and here are my overall thoughts. (SPOILER-FREE)Bioshock Infinite is at its core an average single-player shooter game. However, this is not what compelled me to pick it up. I picked this game up for around 10 bucks during the Steam Black Friday sale, hearing that the story was excellent, and far better than what you'd see in an everyday shooter. After about a month of letting it sit in my library, I gave it a try. Damn, were my friends right. The story is what MADE the game. The world of Colombia is sprawling and full of life, which is surprising due to the subject matter. The character of Elizabeth gave the game heart and a way to convey its story through someone else's eyes, rather than the focused and violent sight of Mr. Booker Dewitt. The ending left me speechless, and I talked to my friends about it for hours. I tried the other Bioshocks, but they were not even close to the fun I had with Infinite. They were far too dark and overall lacked the polish of Infinite. Infinite's choice of a lighter atmosphere and a gripping story reeled me in and gave me an overall great experience. It was worth every penny.

Posted: April 3, 2014
												I've always been a fan of the Bioshock series and irrational games as a company, I even thought Bioshock 2, made by 2K was a great game, not as good as the others in the series but definitely worth your time.March 2013, the release of Bioshock: Infinite.Who knew, that a game could have such an emotional pull on someone. That it could make you feel and care for the characters, so much that you would be thinking about them, worrying for them and doing everything in your humanly power to make sure that everything went the way you wanted it too. That is the feeling Bioshock: Infinite will bring to you and anyone who plays this game and truly immerses themselves in the story, putting yourself in the shoes of Booker Dewitt and getting the feeling that these in game events are actually happening and that you are involved.This is the best game in the Bioshock series, without a doubt, simple things like the main character being able to speak and having a companion,to huge things like the world being fueled by slavery, racism and capitalism, not to mention the fact that the game is absolutely stunning visually and the added feature of zipping through parts of columbia on sky hooks and landing on enemies heads to send them flying through the air and off the map are all features that make this game such a unique and mind blowing experience.The characters are amazing, the gameplay is easy to pick up and the story is the best story I have ever experienced in a game, the link up with the city in the sky Columbia to the underwater utopia that is Rapture is special and the added DLC of Burial at Sea parts 1 and 2 that bring the Bioshock series to a close, is some of the finest storytelling that not just gaming has ever seen, ENTERTAINMENT has ever seen (Yes better than TLOU).In short, buy this game and play it, I have completed this game 3 times already on the Xbox (where my original playthroughs are) completed all the DLC, and I fully expect to be going back to play this game time and time again, I 100% hope this isn't the end of Bioshock as a series, but if it is, all I can say is it has been an amazing journey, and Bioshock sits at the top of my most treasured games list and will for a long time.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												If all you want is a pretty game with decent gameplay and don't care about / don't pay attention to story, in terms of for example dramatic pacing or coherence, then BioInf is the game for you. Otherwise you may want to read this review to contrast the fanboy fawning from the industry and previous fans of the series.This is my opinion: BioInf is a beautiful game, with mediocre gameplay where longer healthbars simulate difficulty, and a story that pretends to be deep while it's really mostly pretentious, chopped up, and doesn't "handle" and of the issues it briefly touches on. I could write you an essay about all the plot flaws; examples being blatantly ignoring huge character events, having Booker act like a total retard (and I mean extra everything total retard even in game terms) to make the story even more convoluted, and not keeping to their own in-universe laws. They introduce story elements like travel in time and between worlds in the multiverse, but don't seem to take into account the obvious consequences; for example, why does Booker assume that if they pass into a new world, his old deal with someone would be valid over there? And concerning all the deep issues it handles; you get hammered by racism, then all the black people go murderbrawl and you have to mindlessly shoot them all, is that what people mean by the game "handling big and important issues"?Now, I don't think BioInf is a worthless game; it can be fun at times. The intro is fantastically beautiful, for example. But if the question is simply: did I think it was worth my time and money spent? then my answer is no. The original idea of this game may have been brilliant, and the story complex and beautiful, but it feels like it's been compromised too many times in development, and consequently can't hold itself together. It may have benefited from not taking up quite so many "deep and important issues" and not branching out into quite so many things. It ends up trying very hard to be something it isn't: a good story.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This review is more about preference than quality.This was a tough one for me, as the visuals and presentation were outstanding, but sadly there is a lot wrong with this game, and it's all in the gameplay. I'll start by saying that all of the amazing things shown in the E3 demos was cut for some reason and replaced by more basic and less interesting content.The game itself is extremely linear run-and-gun, but slower and less convenient. Rather than explore a city, you get locked into small arenas with a circular railway circuit and are forced to fight a number of respawning enemies until a timer runs out and you're allowed to leave.The complexity of levels is comparable to more faster-paced, more straightforward shooters like Serious Sam, but scaled up in size immensely, which while looks impressive, also means it takes ages to move down pretty basic paths. Exploration involves backtracking miles to find secret buttons or clues, meaning a bad hunch can waste over 20 minutes of walking (which happened to me a few times).Combat is run-and-gun, but slowed down with combat mechanics that are interesting at first (and I'm sure many gamers would love it), but for me gets jarring and annoying quickly. You get Elizabeth to spawn in infinite ammo boxes, minor barricades or friendly versions of NPCs to distract enemies (and no escape routes or secret passages as previously planned). You then use a basic 'stun' attack with the vigors and then shoot the enemy in their weak spot to kill them, and you have to do this a LOT and the pace of the game gets annoyingly slow as a result. Because you are expected very strongly to use the vigors, the guns are extremely unreliable. To make matters worse, you have only two weapon slots, you can only switch guns with dropped weapons, and ammo can completely vanish in certain areas, with many areas that strongly lean towards specific weapon types- which skews gameplay in many annoying and frustrating ways.Story was ok-ish, and the presentation of the story was certainly excellent. But again, compared to the trailers, nowhere near as good. The vibrant living atmosphere of a city full of paranoid psychos where Booker tries his best to blend in at his own peril when they could turn on him any minute? Wasn't there. After the opening sequence, the streets are deserted for the rest of the game except for the badguys (police or rebels) waiting to fight you and its a standard first-person shooter. Another problem is the majority of the story is delivered solely via voxophones (audio logs), which are mostly hidden and easily interrupted by scripted character speech, meaning the player must wait for a quiet spot, turn it on, and just sit around listening to it. Some in-world spoken information is easy to miss by being in the wrong place at the wrong time. Overall, it's very easy to miss what is going on.Overall, it was a pity, as it could have been outstanding, and there is nothing in the game that is legitimately botched or crappy, and to its further credit, the drawbacks I listed were all fairly ambitious ideas and mechanics that I think many people will love (that I simply didn't), and never to poor or unimaginative design that plagues many other games. If you think an approach like this, or a theatrical experience, is worthwhile in itself, and don't mind the gameplay style, then certainly buy it, if you're like me- maybe not.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												There are a lot of positive reviews for this game, which was initially what compelled me to purcahse it upon release. It was praised for its "excellent story" and immersive qualities. While it does have a decently gripping plot, Bioshock Infinite suffers from lack of gameplay quality. Enough so that I would not recommend this game to most players.Bioshock Infinite holds a scary resemblence to Assassin's Creed (the first one) not in the sense that the setting or story are the same, but both have a great story and terrible gameplay. Like in Assassin's Creed, Bioshock Infinite has you doing the same things in the same scenarios over and over again while trying to switch it up by adding new elements to the same system. This repetitive style of development is completely transparent after your first handful of encounters and while not even halfway through the game, you can tell there is no end in sight to the repetition. In order to get through the plot, one has to hack and slash one's way through the dull gameplay; an uphill battle from which I chose to retreat from after about a third of the way into the game.I applaud both Bioshock Infinite and Assassin's Creed for their efforts in storytelling, as it's a quality that is severely lacking in the video game industry and rarely explored. The Assassin's Creed team learned from their mistakes and hit a homerun with their second installment, Assassin's Creed II. Hopefully the Bioshock team will also learn from theirs and create a game that can tell a riveting tale as well as engage the player. However, Bioshock Infinite simply does not cut it.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
												First of all I want to start off by saying I am a huge fan of the Bioshock series and fell in love with System Shock a long, long time ago. I can recommend this game if only for the story. This has by far been the most disappointing entry in the series for me. Let's get to the basics shall we?-Structure: One of the biggest let downs of the title. While there have always been directives and objectives and overall goals sewn into the games, this one follows one core goal to the next in a very linear fashion compared to the others. You have a mission and there isn't any deviating or experimenting afoot, you might have a few instances where you can veer off briefly and grab a new piece of clothing or boost,  but these opportunities are few and far between. You have one autosave checkpoint to the next and if by God for some reason you were to get lost, a simple tap of the up on the Dpad will paint a line showing you where to go next. It's essentially a strict path to follow from one story bullet to the next. 4/10-Game play: Another disappointing occurrence in what could have been something amazing. The game play in this title is never fully actualized or as fleshed out as it could have been. What you have is a sprawling city atop the clouds and they're all intertwined and connected with these sky-lines. This game could have been as grand and diverse as the original Bioshock but what you essentially get is a connected roller coaster to fly on from one checkpoint to the next. The gun play leaves something to be desired, weapons feel different in their own right but the feeling has been lost from Bioshock. When you would round a corner and see a group of enemies or a Big Daddy and then mentally prepare on how to tackle it. You could lay down some mines or trip wire, stay close to a puddle of water to electrocute your prey and just have a variety of well planned destruction at your disposal. With this game all you really need to do is throw a bronco and or toss some grenades and empty your clip and wait for Elizabeth to toss you another needed resource. 6/10Presentation: This is where the game really shines and shows that if most things are lost in an Irrational title, they can still tell one hell of a story. What you're presented with is a story that dissects culture as we've come to know. A brainwashed patriotism powered by slavery and a bunch of other somewhat touchy areas throughout history. Racism is thrown up at every corner, and it feels like it fits for an early 1900's era.You can still see some of the overzealous Christian overtones and theme they shove down your throat, for story telling purposes. The graphics are beautiful and colorful with the vivid image of Red, White, and Blue painting the sky and interiors of all the places you'll come to see. While the story crosses into some nonsensical territory, overall it's brought to you in a beautiful way and I expected nothing less. The shining beacon of light in this game is the story so hang on every word it might be all you have or can take from it. 10/10Overall I'm not sure what you intend to take from this game, I wanted to love it, I really did but the story is the only basis I can recommend this title for. Your game time will stretch further than a lot of other FPS games will these days but that's it's job, after all it's Bioshock and not Call of Duty. If you bought this on sale you may very well get your money's worth, just see yourself as paying for a really damn good story. Just remember, there's always a lighthouse, there's always a man, and there's always a city. You'll know it when you need to.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Bioshock games have always had the ability to tell strong stories and create impactful moments, but nothing that the studio has done before has come close to Infinite.You're thrown into a world where you ponder the sanity of the residents, you question your mission, and you gravitate slowly towards your companion. The long distance visuals are excellent, but the detail is lacking in the textures, making it feel more like a port than a PC game.You've always had your guns and your abilities in previous games, but never a companion like Elizabeth. She will help you in ways you've never been assisted in before, and you'll start taking her for granted. She's beautifully written and the work and detail put into her character brings her to life like never before seen in a video game.The biggest disappointment is the environment, almost nothing responds to you. Sure, you can walk by a couple and hear a quip, but try to enter nine out of every ten stores and you'll get a lovely low-res texture and a non-response. The environment feels rich in certain areas, like the opening sequence, and then completely dead in others. The action elements are pretty standard, but the story will leave you with many questions and plenty to ponder long after. It's a great discussion piece, and there are moments that can really stick with you.Overall, Bioshock is a beautiful game with beautiful moments. The story and characters elevate the weaker gameplay elements, and it's like living in an old movie. It's an unforgettable experience.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												Leaving Andrew Ryan behind and scouring the figure of a comparable autocrat/antagonist for a new BioShock title was no easy task for the developers; I acknowledge that, but I cannot pretend I did not forget Comstock's voice and assertions as the story progressed. Unlike Rapture's idealiser, Columbia's had little imposing density in his character. But BioShock is not entirely about its self-righteous and paradoxical authority personalities, and Infinite shines outside this conceptual bubble. In spawning a more ancient, more morally delusional - and picturesque - society, the game becomes more satirical, thus more interesting to add to. A vivid city, Columbia exposes the illnesses of the American "Thule", so to speak. Over those clouds lurks a shadow of disguised hate and disciplined stupidity, much like the idealisation of national rights of John Gast's Columbia and the dangerous romanticising of the Manifest Destiny. Only this time, America went airborne, not westwards.Infinite triumphs on this premise. As it unfolds - so subtly -, its characters become less of casual citizens and more of monsters, just as its astonishing streets become filthy paths exposed by rebellious graffiti and mauled bodies. Its beautiful design and graphics provide the eye with constant awe, as though those bright windows and doorways far into the sky were veritable man-made stars. It is a joy to witness the game's visual ascension as you attempt Elizabeth's "rescue" and learn more about that floating pseudo-paradise.Oh, and speaking of Elizabeth. Although I expected more than an almost quintessential damsel in distress, voice acting and writing often gave me hope; and her background, fears and convictions throughout the story - not to mention her in-game functions, tacit but exciting as they are - forced me to think back to previous milestones of the story and look at the whole scenario from a standpoint which was not that of Booker DeWitt's. That was unique, I have got to say.BioShock Infinite may not cause as much thematic bewitchment or those dialogue goose pimples, but it offers decent food for thought; which is the safe haven of the series. Its virtue may not lie in character conception or in the renewal of the plasmid feature, for example, but its well-paced and extremely pleasurable gameplay, its audiovisual style, its sidekick system and its plotline premise hold consistency to the end of the chapter, refusing to even steer close to collapse. The BioShock name, though currently with a relatively uncertain future, still shines.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												BioShock Infinite is by no means a terrible game, but compared to its predecessor, it has many of the same flaws and lacks the redeeming poetry and vision.BioShock is now a modern classic. Its successor, BioShock Infinite, takes us to a new world that is superficially just as captivating as Rapture, but the similarities are purely superficial. Where BioShock had ideas, Infinite simply has plot devices. Where BioShock asked us to choose, Infinite just asks us to run and shoot.Part of what made BioShock special was that its ideas, emotions, story content, and gameplay were all coherent in a thematically consistent way. Ultimately BioShock told a story that was thematically compatible, and even thematically harmonious, with the conceits and conventions of FPS games. BioShock Infinite tries to tell a story, but the dissonance between the narrative/emotional content and the gameplay content is jarring in the new installment. It doesn't help that the story, though told with exquisite craft and care, ultimately is for all its artistry utterly inane.With a story that is so thoroughly undermined by the gameplay mechanics, Infinite needs to lean heavily on gameplay to be entertainment. Unfortunately, like BioShock, Infinite is merely a competent shooter from a gameplay perspective. Worse, the level designs are now more linear.In sum, it's a competent but underwhelming game, and outright disappointing when set against its predecessor.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Had loads of fun with this game. Everything is beautifully crafted, especially the set designs that come in a huge variety but all remain fresh and equally interesting. As with the original Bioshock, the intricate presentation of social themes and ideologies are an important part of the overarching design, and Bioshock Infinite is no different. They are gripping and clearly presented, while refraining from distracting the player from the main narrative. The story, while confusing and even overbearing at times, is intriguing, reaching a fascinating crescendo during the last 20 minutes of the game.The game is by no means 'perfect', but the clear amount of affection and care that has been put into every small detail in all of its many, many different components results in something that is thoroughly remarkable and enjoyable. It's a game that should be respected, and more importantly enjoyed, for a sum of all its parts.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												Jack of all trades, master of none.Bioshock infinite is a shooter based on the existing franchise, however the gameplay felt poorly planned.  The firefights were uninspired bouts of you against massive bullet sponges.  There is little incentive to use your elemental powers as the enemies are easily defeated without.  The combat seems to encourage the use of cover, however it lacks a key component: usable cover.  Each fight is approached the same way, and although the game lets you use your powers to place traps, you will almost never find yourself in a place to use them.  Each fight is a head-on bout of how many bullets of your seemingly infinite supply it will take to progress in the story.speaking of the story, it has no focus.  In the beginning, it is a portrayal of a society in the clouds full of religious bigotry and racism.  It soon turns into a completely pointless display of how much Ken Levine knows about theoretical physics, apparently just enough to think he knows what he's doing when he has really only scratched the surface.  Although at times interesting, by the end it does not make sense with itself and still baffles the community and even Levine himself.  The story will leave you feeling empty, as it makes no remark on the social injustice happening in columbia.The game tries to do too many stories and fails to complete them effectively, making the whole game feel both unguided and lazily put together.  If there was a more clear direction as to where they wanted to go with the story, it would have been at least redeemable in that aspect.  The gameplay should be completely revamped, as the actual first-person-shooter aspect is neither fun nor rewarding.  Every weapon uninspired, every special ability almost pointless to use.Bioshock: Infinite gets a 2/5

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												This is my fave Bioshock game,  better characters that I actually felt like I cared about,  I like that the characters talk to each other and have banter, previous games only chatter you'd get is from audio logs or a radio message telling you what to do next, environment is visually gorgeous and has an immersive if somewhat convoluted story.I like Columbia much more than I do Rapture,  swinging around on sky hooks and using a sky hook to swoop down and kill an enemy. I was starting to get sick of Rapture and am glad this game has a different setting.The game gives the illusion of a vast expansive sky city, it does not have the stuffy claustrophobic feel of the underwater city Rapture. In Columbia you just want to soar and swoop at every chance you can. Though it does make my stomach churn at times using a sky rail is almost like riding a roller coaster.Elizabeth is an interesting character though at first she reminded me a lot of a Disney princess, the way she moves, expressions in an over exagerated disney princess way, she's almost a rip off of Belle from Beauty and the Beast in how she looks, she has same hairstyle, big over large eyes.You have a variety of ways to kill enemies you can ask elizabeth to open a tear so you can have more cover, a hook for swinging off, medical kits, guns, turrets, though that is limited as you can only have 1 tear open and active at a time.But the game is not without frustration.You can only carry 2 guns at a time which is very limiting, though you can swap 1 gun you are carrying for a gun that's on the ground, you can never carry more than 2 at a time.Vigors are often the most fun and versatile ways to kill which are the replacement for plasmids but are much more limited in their use as you can't carry salts on you, you seem to run out of salts way too quickly though  (salts are the blue energy metre simular to eve) to replenish salts you have to find some sort of drink or a bottle of salts. Usually there are salts nearby or Elizabeth will find and toss you some.You can't carry first aid kits either but you have a energy shield which is better, you don't lose health unless your shield is fully depleted and if that happens you can just hide till it replenishes.But even so I found the battles more fast paced and enjoyable than the previous Bioshocks.I dislike most  that there is only auto save and you can't save your game when you want. I wanted to stop playing but it said my last auto save was 10 minutes ago, so had to keep playing for 10 more minutes to get the next checkpoint. It makes it so I have to replay again if I just want to quit playing. The most annoying thing about the game. I had to leave the game running when I wanted a break as my last checkpoint save was half an hour ago, auto saves should be at least every 10 minutes.There is no hacking, I miss that.The only thing that is a tiny bit like it is that Elizabeth can pick locks for you, but there is no mini game associated with it.To sumarise it overall the game is better in some ways than the other Bioshocks but also worse in other aspects.The story overall is rather freaky, tragic and messes with your head, I did a lot of reading about it to understand the story fully. But I better not say anything else as I don't want to spoil it for those who have not played and completed the game.Mostly though it feels enjoyable, fun, scary in some ways and exciting. Though unlike others I would not got so far as to say it's one of the best games I've played. Almost would rate it an 8, but there is too many negatives that the game should not have, it does not deserve more than 7/10.

												"Are you a bad man?" "I am a bad man" "No you're not a bad man." *Killing about twenty people* "Are you a bad man?" "That guy is a bad man." "That guy is a bad man."Bioshock Infinite wants to be a game about the nature of "what-if" and choice, framed in a story about ex-military officer Booker DeWitt sent to a mystical city in the clouds to rescue the mysterious waif Elizabeth, whose strange world-altering powers and sheltered childhood lends itself to an unfolding narrative of mutual cooperation; encouraging the player to care for an NPC as the two of you battle an unjust world out to get you.What it *is*, is a game about shooting dudes in the face. Lots of them, in hectic combat where you tend to get disoriented a lot and your low health and lack of carriable healing items causes you to run around from cover to cover like a headless chicken looking for that precious popcorn or abandoned soda to boost your all-too-fragile health. And when the red mist is over you are left with a pile of dead police officers and ordinary, well-intentioned people convinced you are a bad guy. Which, after having killed about twenty of them, you kind of sort of feel like. Racists they may be, but nothing in-game ever convinced me these people *needed* to die, and especially not in such crude, gore-tastic manners.Bioshock Infinite has a real issue with story-and-gameplay integration: The story and presentation leaves me ill-motivated to care about the main characters or anything they do. The gameplay, even if it had been better (it is certainly the weakest of the Bioshock games to date, sacrificing the last vestiges of System Shock on the altar of Call of Duty) creates a sharp divide between the themes of caring for someone and cooperating with them and killing endless hordes of very human cannon fodder with nary a thought; apparently only the hopes and dreams of the main character are worth diving into. Booker's dismissing of practically everything about this magical cloud wonderland he finds himself in, or his refusal to engage in any form of self-reflection about himself or his actions, certainly don't help matters.In fact, if I may be so bold I might say this game's core excellence is as a showpiece for the ideas promoted by Spec Ops: The Line. Do I feel like a hero yet? No, Bioshock Infinite. No, I do not.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												BioShock Infinite has lofty ambitions. It tries to tackle some social and existential questions, provide entertaining gameplay, and wrap it all up in an emotionally moving package. Unfortunately, the game's polish belies its shallow depth.The gunplay brings absolutely nothing new to the table. While the addition of Sky-Lines was an interesting idea, the implementation reduces it mostly to a form of locomotion, rather than a primary form of combat. The game provides challenge through tough, not intelligent enemies, especially on later difficulties where several headshots may be necessary for a simple grunt.As for the story, it attempts to bring in elements of multiverse theory and explores ideas of choice and consequence for each of the characters in the game. However, in doing so, it contradicts itself several times over in its conclusion. I won't spoil that here; there are several videos you can watch to see the ending, along with interpretations if you wish.While the game paints a pretty picture and plays a few nice tunes, it fails to sufficiently answer many of the questions the early portions will give you. What one is left with, then, is contradictions and loose threads, and the game provides very little to alleviate these issues.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												To quote someone else, Bioshock Infinite is wasted potential. The art deco, like Bioshock, is amazing. But, just like Bioshock again, any topics they bring up like racism for example has no commentary or explanation for it which is just bad. This is because it makes the setting and characters feel shallow, and because commentary and explanation can be interesting and informative in it's own right. The interactions between Booker and Elizabeth are interesting and will probably keep you engage enough to see the story to the end, but most of the game is bad shoot people gameplay. People will argue that the gameplay is bad because B:I got rid of basically all the RPG elements in Bioshock and also made the map design completely linear, but I disagree with this. These people don't remember that Bioshock already had shallow RPG mechanics and poor map design. The maps were design so that each path was a deadend that the player had to backtrack through once a mission was done... instead of making things loop around. This happens in B:I still, but the linearity negates most of it to optional missions. In B:I the vigors (plasmids) nearly all do the same thing (LMB to attack, RMB to make a trap) removing any strategy on which one to choose and removing any reason to mix them together (which atleast Bioshock had). You also can only hold 2 weapons, which ruins any chance of mixing up the gameplay. Like you have limited resources so you have to choose wisely on what weapons to upgrade so you'll probably only hold the same 2 weapons you've upgraded through the game because if you upgraded a 3rd weapon you won't be able to use it unless you randomly find it on the ground in the middle of the fight. Also since you don't have an inventory Elizabeth will randomly throw you items that you need during a fight which means there isn't really any strategy to refilling your health/magic in the middle of combat. Yes there are items that have small refilling benefits but that doesn't replace potions. You also can buy refill potions that are applied instantly and also random refill areas in combat arenas so just abuse these locations?But while they basically stripped down the gameplay to a bare FPS minimum, I think it was a step in the right direction for these developers. But they needed to go one step further, remove the gameplay entirely. Seriously, if this was a Themepark Simulator there would have been more time to flesh out the narrative, characters, and setting which the game greatly needed.I played the game on medium and I would not recommend playing it on higher difficulties because there are bullet sponge enemies and the only boss fight in the game is a bullet sponge that infinitely spawns enemies in which you fight the boss multiple times. I can't recommend this game because of the poor gameplay. I would recommend instead watching an LP (Let's Play or Long Play depending on your perspective c;) and buying some cool looking merchandise from Irrational Games instead https://store.irrationalgames.com/

Posted: November 29, 2013
												Bioshock is what I hope HL:Episode 3 would be like, except it has magic. Well, it doesn't call it magic, but it's the same idea. You're a private investigator who can't investigate for♥♥♥♥♥♥and gets pulled along by the undertow of fate and personalities in the universe. And that's just fine. You can switch between two kinetic weapons out of quite a few in the game ranging from pistols to RPGs. Some are better than others, and at one point the overvariety of similar weapons gets a bit overbearing. You also have the power of 'vigors' (spells). I find these similar to the weapons in that there are some stand-outs that I love using but many fall into the "me-too" category, particularly those that are only obtained late in the game. The very first vigor, possession, is by far the most useful and fun in general combat situations. There is also a grusome (if fun) melee attack that tends to become obsolete early due to the prevelence of guns unless you find the right gear to improve it when more difficult enemies appear.The most similar aspect to the HL2 series is your companion, Elizabeth, who assists you for much of the game. Unlike Alyx in the aformentioned series, Elizabeth doesn't engage in (and outshine you at) combat. Instead she will throw items to the player and effectively act as an engineer by pulling turrents and other defensive items out of her tear. Oh, tears... those are "rips in dimensional time and space, revealing an alternate universe, which does not exist in the current world." Don't worry, it makes sense in context. While Elizabeth's role could be otherwise filled, she is useful in combat and does not require guarding, a good choice by the devs. She's a compelling character that is the real star of the story, not the player controlled 'Booker." And the story is quite good, though it's confusing at times and feels like it has a few aborted endings. Most of the time it's compelling, though, and makes you want to keep playing to find out what's going on through the time loops and dimensional warps that occur. The ending is a powerful gut punch, and not wishy-washy at all. There are some choices in the game, but none matter. Or perhaps they all matter, but none can alter the ending- further explanation would be spoilerish and get into the philosophy of determinism. There are plot holes, as with any story that involves some sort of time/space warp, but it's a good story with a puncuated ending that I needed to sit back and recover from afterwards.  Then I quickly restarted so I could get back to the more carefree portions of the game and also start to see the events from the hindsight of knowing how everything plays out. There's a lot of backstory lying unobtrusively around for those who want to look for it in a playthrough.Cons include an awful save system (this is 2015, why can't we figure this out?) and a couple of portions of the game that are too repetitive with no payoff.I'd say the game is a steal at sale prices under $30.I didn't play the first bioshock but I think it might be a good time to pick it up...

												There's a cool storyline but it gives itself away far too soon.  And the game is very pretty but you are on rails most of the time so the levels often feel plastic and static (like a Doom level but with modern smoke and flare effects).  So, you are left with obviously demarked shooting areas and then a cutscene --  rinse, repeat.  The shooting is frenetic but not very strategic. In that old game, fighting was strategic and varied and the large levels offered tactical choices.    Bottomline -- "Infinite" is sadly a C+ game with an A- story.

												After months of trying to stop myself from playing the game, I have finally beaten (after getting it from the sale) the game in 2 days. The result is that I am not one of of hte many fans of the game. Now, please ignore this review if you are a fan of bioshock, this may indeed anger you.Ok. First off, I want to say that yes this game has a great story. the story is simple but is a well done story that has some scifi elements that made me say, I want to see a bit more. The ending is really good as it deals with a twist that was kinda unseen in the game. The characters, though likeable, I would say a bit forgetable. The characters I think are more memorable is the twins, who are pretty funny because they have a bit of the "out of this world" characteristic that you can enjoy. Elizabeth, the main female protagonist does indeed seems to be a very like able character, though not exactly a outstanding character as people would make her to be. However, the biggest problem with the game is the game, which I'm sorry to say, is subpar. Originally, I though that the original game wasn't that interesting to me because the combat system was too easy and too dull for me to continue playing the game. In Bioshock Infinite, I felt that combat felt less impressive than the first game. Fewer weapons and limits to what weapons you can have often drives me nuts when playing games. It even worst that the guns feel less impactful and that combat also felt like a chore for me. The only weapons that felt good to use were the pistols, revolver and the Air Grabber.The special abilities that you collect are also a real dull choice as it's possible to only use 1 or 2 of them throughout the game without even using others more than one moment. The enemies in the game are also a real annoyance, Some enemies, such as the RPG and Handy man, felt really overpowered and that the hints given about the handy man's weak point do not even result in doing any damage. The Ghost level is what I considered the worst level becauuse of how poorly done it is and how even the objective pointer after the 2nd tear was extremely broken because they only lead you aroudn the whole map.Overall, despite the great story, I cannot say this game is considerd a 9s or even the 10s that it recieved. I wasnt' surprised to see this game get awards at all. Overall, this game isnt' not the game we need or want.

Posted: December 21, 2013
												Brilliant presentation, mediocre gameplay, badly written storyline.All style and no substance. The story consists of plot twists for no reason other than to have plot twists, regardless of the mess it makes of the narrative, or what messages it ends up conveying. One character has the special ability to literally tear holes in the plot. As the "alternate universes" angle comes in, any reason to care about the characters goes out the window - if they're all alternate versions, with alternate realities, why care about any of them? Why is one reality/timeline objectively better, or more valid, than any other? On top of that, the gameplay is frankly boring. It does absolutely nothing to advance the shooter genre - on the contrary it's bland and derivative. It is VERY pretty though, I'll give it that.------SPOILERS BELOW------When I say "The story consists of plot twists for no reason other than to have plot twists, regardless of the mess it makes of the narrative, or what messages it ends up conveying" I'm referring to the Vox Populi turning on you.The game starts out with the premise that you're fighting against some really awful people, really vile racists and bigots. By introducing the plot twist that you must now fight the Vox Pop, though the developers almost certainly did not intend it, what their game is now saying is "You know who the REAL evil people are? They're not really the oppressors, they're the downtrodden minorities!" It's an absurd position to take, and it's an absurd situation to be in. There is no justification for having to fight the people you've been fighting to save, other than it being a hackneyed "shocking" plot twist just for the sake of having a plot twist.You can tell that at least one person at 2K had an inkling that this might be the case because before you have to fight them the Vox Pop are mostly black folks, but you only ever fight Irish folks. You can tell because it would make the offensive absurdity of the situation starkly obvious if the second half of the game was all about massacring black people!"♥♥♥♥ minorities, up with Whitey" obviously wasn't what 2K had in mind when they set out to make this game. But because whoever wrote the plot didn't stop and think that is what their creation says.Then there's simple, silly things it does to the plot. We jump through a portal into an alternate universe after failing to save the weapons dealer. Ok, so how does it help anything at all to defeat Comstock in this new universe? We've still left behind a universe where he wins. Why is this new universe objectively any different?Why does Booker ultimately drowning himself change anything at all? He's just ONE iteration of Booker; why does the death of that universe's Booker have any impact on any others?

Posted: January 3, 2014
												Despite this game receiving a majority of popular feedback, I find it falls very short as a game. I do however feel that it is a fantastic piece of art. The environments are gorgeous, and exploring Colombia were rather enjoyable. Also the story was well told and quite moving despite some gaps in continuity. However that's the extent of its positive qualities.As game it fails to be challenging, even on Hard mode the combat is incredibly trivial. Elizabeth can keep you feed with an infinite supply of ammo, health, and salts, which you don't even need because you can just kill everything with the skyhook. Aside from the combat the game was incredibly linear, with very few secrets, and of those that did exist none really provided any substantial benefit because the combat was so easy to begin with.And again back to the problems with it being so linear, I can't help but compare it to the first Bioshock, which was also linear, however at least had multiple endings. With Bioshock: Infinite there is one ending, and honestly it's not that good. For a game that has a theme of infinite worlds with infinite possibilities you have only one ending? Really?To sum it all up it's just not a good game; like I said the story was pretty good, but the combat is poor, and the player cannot change the outcome of the ending. In terms of gameplay it's more like Myst or Riven than a shooter. It's just a beautiful enviornment to explore. However, unlike Myst or Riven, Bioshock: Infinate is devoid of any choice or challenge. Overall I'd have to say that you would probably be better off just watching all the cutscenes on youtube, because it would make a better movie than a game.

												After letting this game stew for a while, I find my opinion has worsened from even my lackluster feelings after beating the game. Before you begin in with cries of you don't get it or you can't compare it to bioshock, I will bisect those two arguments right here and now. First off, yes, I may have missed bits of the subtext but I understood what was going on and it was a bit of a mess. Being pretentious does not mean being misunderstood, it means pretending to be making points and being smarter than you are, and this game is not nearly as intelligent or interwoven as it would like you to think it is. Secondly, yes I can compare it to bioshock because its called bioshock infinite, has psuedo-plasmids and similar combat and even blanketly steals sound assets from the first. The very name invited the comparison and therefore invites criticism regarding that. Now with that out of the  way, no I would not reccomend this game at full price, though at a sale price I can reccomend it for a playthrough at least. The game squanders its potential by not focusing on the more interesting bits, like talking to citizens and exploring the town with dull combat, that is infinitely more boring than Bioshock. Theres no real sense of progression, the fights are just long and drawn out and the abilities are mostly uninterestinhg or just copies of the original games plasmids. And speaking on that, the vigors are just reskinnned plasmids, just without any of the lore, intrigue or even real relation to the universe that Bioshock and even a game that I consider in some ways to be better, Bioshock 2 had. Theres no interwoven lore, the world is just there, the physics♥♥♥♥♥♥is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t pretentious and the main villian and city are uninteresting. I don't like how no one took this game to task for its issues, because maybe I am being pretty critical but the game is not as perfect as advertised. It got talked up and talked up and talked up, and even when I tempered exprectations I was left dissapointed. Its infinitely weaker than Bioshock, lorewise and world building wise and I just don't like it. I also really don't like how a game that did everything better than this one was overshadowed by this one because it was so hyped and deep and♥♥♥♥♥♥ Its not that deep, and when you have a line like "The city doesn't float cause of the ballons, it floats cause physics!!!" you know its trying to be that game without understanding that by trying and not doing it falls flat. Worth a playthrough, but bewared the hype, as I personally felt it was far weaker than advertised. Go play  the much better Bioshock, or even Bioshock 2, or hell, go play Spec ops if you want to play a truly great game, and if you want to see what this game could've been, go play the game it helped push away from the perhiphery, Metro Last light, because that game for all its flaws is much better than this one.

Posted: December 20, 2013
												Game started out fantastic. Beautiful design, engaging themes, and entertaining situations. Fast forward to around the sixth hour of gameplay: redundant fights, annoying combat, unsatisfying powers, and (if playing on the highest difficulty) maddeningly frustrating fights with the Handyman. Seriously, if you disagree with me, try to beat the Handyman in one of the last fights on the hardest difficulty. There is nothing gratifying with the combat structure in this game.Most reviews that I see gush over the game's story. Look, I get it: the idea of alternate universes, travel between them, and consequences of choices that can alter future choices is intriguing. Unfortunately, getting to these themes involved introducing multiple, underdeveloped characters that just seemed like more and more names being thrown at you. The games storyline with the revolution and the overall "alternate universes" theme conflicted and annoyed me for the latter part of the game. Fighting animated patriot machines was... dumb. It seemed like the developers felt they could get away with putting any stupid scenario in the game just because in one of the infinite universes it was possible.I would recommend many other games over Bioshock Infinite. I strongly feel that its success is a product of strong advertising. Not GOTY in terms of atmosphere, story, and combat mechanics.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite started out a great and incredibly beautiful, but after many hours it started dragging out for far too long. Combat turned from fun to an empty, churny and uninspired chore between story nibblets. It felt like the team lost track of "fun" 70% or so into the game. As such, the promise the game made with its fantastic first hours turned out to be a huge lie towards the end. The many many faults with the nimble-as-a-refridgerator controls were at first totally forgivable, but when everything but the visuals crumbled and came tumbling down around it, the painful dance with those blaring faults were pretty much all that was left. The payoff the game convinced me it could deliver was just reduced to a dirty rag tossed to the side.Playing on hard can be a real challenge towards the end, but I find that most of my deaths through the game came from getting stuck in basic geometry, the character not running, or simply not jumping to the various hook-spots when he was supposed to. Bioshock Infinite is also a perfect reminder of why enemies using hit-scan weapons in shooters just aren't fun.I will try to beat it as I'm most probably just one small hill from the end, just to get it over with, and certainly not because I find it entertaining anymore. I'm actually even rather uninterested by the story at this point, as all the characters decided to just muddle up their believability with just stupid and inconsistent behavior.It honestly feels like the original team of the game were not, at all, the same people who made the latter hours of it. Weird. Disappointing.I really wanted to recommend this. I was looking forward to finishing it so I could look up the DLC. I had it in my list of favorites. But I can't recommend it anymore. And I will certainly not touch the DLC.
