content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												In total, I give this game a 9/10, here is why:PROS:- Amazing Storyline- Easy to understand controls- Amazing Scenery (even on the lowest setting)- Variety of weapons, and way to go about the levels- Freedom to move around a bit (None linear levels in a way)- Many characters that are easy to understand and keep track of- Good variety of missions- Really tests your moral: Do what is right if it hurts people? Do what is wrong if it means no one will get hurt?- Elizabeth's ally skillsCONS:- Not a large variety of enemy types- Random ammo locations and ammo drops makes it hard to keep the weapons you want- Over viscious enemies that will not give inBoth, depending on your preference:- Jumpscare (Only one, but you won't be expecting it :P )A bit of spoilers beliw, but the main spoiler is at the bottom, so you can rwad below, and not spoil the ending,     The game is about a Mr. Booker De Witt, the character the player plays as, arriving to a light house, where a letter claims that Booker De Witt must bring "The Girl," in order to repay his debt. While exploring the lighthouse, he stumbles upon a chair that shoots him up into the sky, where he finds a floating city known as Columbia. There the people of the city seceeded from the U.S. due to Abraham Lincoln's Civil War, and became its own "state." There, the people worship George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and Benjamin Franklin, and follow the prophet and leader of their city: Mr. Comstock. Booker, bewidered by the place he stumbled upon walks around, allowng the player to learn how to play the game and ue each vigor as a carnival is going on show casing the different abilities the player will be experiencing. Everywhere he looks he sees posters of Comstock, and posters saying how he is the greatest man ever, and other posters claiming to avoid the "False Prophet," created to "stray the lamb away." One poster in particular claims that the "False Prophet," has the letter "AD" engraved on his hand, at this point Booker raises his hand to show the player that "AD" is on his own hand. As you are walking through the street, a note is handed to you, telling the player to NOT get #77 when playing the raffel that the city is doing that day. Lo and Behold, when you go and play the raffel and win, you got #77. You are given a baseball bat, and a black woman and Irish man is dragged out onto the stage and the announcer tells the player to throw it at them as the couple begs them. Here the player learns that the town is racist. The player is given their first choice in the game, throw it at the couple or throw it at the announcer. [I chose to throw it at the announcer] The player raises his hand, where a police officer grabs his arm, and points out the "AD," is on his hand. Instantly, people run, and you kill the police officer, stealing his gun, and the real game begins. You use the gun to shoot at the officer. The game progresses like this until you reach a tower, where you learn that the tower holds a girl hostage, Elizabeth. You free her, learn she can open tears (doors into other dimensions,) and that she is possibly the daughter of Comstock. The rest of the game is trying to find out who Elizabeth really is, and how to defeat Comstock and fix your life.      To begin, the storyline is amazing, and is constantly keeping me wanting more. While I played it on hard (for the first time,) I was constantly having a challenge and to me, that was fun. The characters developed nicely, evolving as the plot developed, which also fitted nicely into the journey your character was embarking on. However, while I say that, the main character seemed to not develope in character as in how the character percieved certain things or how the player reacted to certain events, it was always the same, a gritty "I don't want to be here," attitude; while this may be part of his character, it did seem to get a bit repetative.     Guns sounded nice, and did what guns are supposed to do. kill enemies in a realistic way. Upgrades could be purchased for the weapons and I admit that I did purchase a lot of them, but it is entirely up to player to buy upgrades, not only for the guns but for vigors as well. Vigors are powerups that the characters can use giving him special abilities, my favorite being possession; I rarely used the others however, but again, it is up to the player. Enemy variety is low, all characters that look one way also have the same type of gun, but do not carry the same gear when you search their dead bodies. These enemies range from anything to enemies with simple weapons and barely any armor (the police in the beginning,) to extremely hard (the helpers.) I will admit though, I did enjoy fighting all enemies when they showed up.)     Elizabeth, the character probably most people are familiar with, is an amazing ally. Constantly finding ammo, salts (item to use vigor,) health and pointing out items in the room you can grab. Without her, the player would have a hard time fighting. Her facial expressions are nicely done, changing as the story progresses. She mad at you? She will show anger, and talk to you differently. She will throw things to you without speaking, and show the player her anger by facing away from the main character: Booker De Witt.---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS SPOILERS ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The ending to the game was not something I could expect, especially when you find out Elizabeth is your daughter. It really makes you think about how you treated her in the game, and all the stuff that happened to her. Bottom line, you sold her.

												Had this game on Ps3 when it came out, and found it very indulging in story to the point where I may have spent a bit too much time playing it over and over for a week straight. The gameplay is just your average FPS variant due to the combination of guns and special powers called vigors that work in a similar way to plasmids from the first 2 games. The story is a fairly average one until you get more towards the end of the game where it finally all hits you and mind****s the hell out of you, and I did thoroughly enjoy it. Whilst the twist may not have had the same impact as the first Bioshock's twist did, it still was pretty much unseen for the most part and is worthy of appreciation as much as the first game was.If you have played the first 2 games, I think you will really enjoy this one. In my personal opinion I would put it ahead of Bioshock 2, but behind the original Bioshock, yet still a game worthy of the hype it received. If you like to play games based on the gameplay, and you're looking for a very good FPS, this MIGHT fit the bill but I would recommend it far more for the immersive story, the connections that can be made to the old Bioshocks, and the refreshing colour tones it brings for most of the game. (Oh - And of course all the crazy fan theories people come up with).Very enjoyable and well worth the download. Personal verdict - 9.5/10.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Okay. This is going to be an in-depth review of the game as a stand-alone game, and as a part of the series, divided by the various elements that make a game, well, you know, a game.Gameplay:As a Part of The Bioshock Series (assuming you have already played them):Seriously lacking. They replaced the Power To The People Station with simple and cheap ways of weapon upgrades, which is, as a part of the series, a dissapointment. They replaced the plasmids with vigors which are frankly awesome, but not THAT new. What was new was the introduction to traps, which was very well handled. But what I cannot forgive is that they took away the ADAM gathering, and moved away its upgrades to simple vending machines, giving the game a much easier experience, apart from the serie's particular difficulty. 8/10As a Stand-Alone Game:Different, innovating, thrilling and rewarding, not to mention hard. Vigors kept the experience fresh, and the guns were well balanced. Good work. 9/10StorylineAs a part of the Bioshock Series: Good enough. It provided new and fresh ideas, but keeping the feel of being a Bioshock game. The unfolding of the story trough voxophones is brilliant, and, as compared to the stories in previous games, much, much more coherent and entertaining. 9/10As a Stand-Alone game:An absolute Masterpiece. Mind-blowing, exciting and amazing in every way. The characters are beautiful, the voice-acting is tremendously well done, and, not to spoiler anything, an ending worth crying for. 10/10Other elements:Animation: Perfect in every way. Very well done. Way better than the series (due to the fact that most of the main character in previous installments had little to no screen time) 9/10Soundtrack: Very well put toghether as actual parts of the storyline. 9/10DLC's: Absolute must haves. (Maybe Clash In the Clouds not as much) but the Burial at Sea series are definetly worth getting. ESPECIALLY if you played both previous Bioshock games. They may have their own reviews later on.Graphics/art: The art, as it's common among the Bioshock games is absolutely, amazingly beautiful. Therefore, the graphics are really, really good. 10/10Overall:As a part of the Bioshock Series: 8.5/10.    The gameplay changes were a serious letdown.As a Stand Alone Game: 9.7/10

												The  third instalement of the Bioshock universe, the FPS classic. What was great about previous ones (story, gameplay, atmosphere, great universe, interesting characters) is also present in this third and last game in the franchise. The atmosphere here feels a little bit more "vintage" so to speak as the game takes place in the early 20th century. But that doesnt hurt the game at all (Unfortunetaly my favourite character A.R. from original isn't present... well sort of) I found the new setting rather refreshing and interesting and once again very creative. The DLC content is also great especially for those who suffer from nostalgia for the Rapture :). Same as the first game in the franchise this one also offers an interesting twist and story. What I find especially great is that your in-game "companion" - Elizabeth - who you are supposed to help doesn't get in you way as it is case with most games that want you to escort someone or safe someone. Here it is direct opposite and it sets an example of how to do this kind of stuff right as Elizabeth is quite helpful, usually scouting around for ammo when you need it during the combat as well as med packs, coins etc. She also has a useful ability that player can utilize. It is a great addition to already great gameplay basics that was laid down by its predecessors. This game great, definiteley buy, you won't regret spending your money on this one,  and I can guarantee that this will be one of those games that will be stuck in your memmory for a long long time as it offers a great gameplay and emersive story experience. 10/10

												All of my yes. This is easily one of the greatest games I've had the pleasure of experiencing in years. Artistic style, setting, storytelling as well as the story itself, topics and their exploration, voice cast, writing, everything about this game is top-notch. I've heard complaints that the gameplay has been simplified from it's predecessors, but as someone who hasn't played them, I found it to be quite nice, and it suited the game well.The game certainly handles the companion thing incredibly well. They're never in the way or a nuissance, and very helpful, especially in firefights, where you really wouldn't notice her if she wasn't saving your life. The amount of detail put into her character while roaming or idling is extreme.From a technical standpoint, there are some minor yet glaring graphical errors (horribly stretched/skewed/misaligned textures, occasionally glitchy speculars, primarily) but nothing too noticeable. There are quite a few clipping issues throughout where you can get stuck on invisible solids or edges which can be very annoying when moving urgently. Load times are short, and it also runs well on lower-end hardware.

They've done an intersting work with Elizabeth, she interacts a lot with the environment and with the player. She is helpful in battle and soo human in all the scene where she is involved, expecially in the little scene where she is alone with Booker (essentially with you). You feel her feelings.I don't wanna say anything about the story, I just say there are not many games with a plot and a narration of this level.In conclusion I really enjoy the game and it could become one of my favs.My final advice is: try it, love it.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Bioshock Infinite, what a brilliant change of pace for the First Person Shooter genre. It seems this game could easily be a saving grace amongst the average dystopia brown and gunmetal gray shooters of this modern era we live in.In Bioshock Infinite, you play as Detective Booker DeWitt, who seems to owe some large debt to some very dangerous people. Booker is sent to Colombia, a city in the sky, to retrieve a girl, Elizabeth.In most of my reviews I'd say "Now that we've gotten the basics out of the way," and get to the actual review, but the main point in Bioshock Infinite that truly made me flip my proverbial lid was the story plot. It was a glorious thrillride of emotional turmoil between Booker and Elizabeth, gunfights and brutal hookblade finishers that kept me interested until the very end, in which the game gloriously exploded into a-... Well, anything I say about that would spoil the ending.Another point I'd say I truly liked about this game, was that it was a true sequel to the original. Sure, it takes place in the same universe, but it's truly a completely different game. In Bioshock you could stuff your weapons into seemingly neverending orifices, but in Infinite, you can carry only two, and must rely on Elizabeth to keep you stocked on weapons, ammo, salts, and health. Elizabeth is a character of neverending personality who can sometimes be hard to understand, which is a shocker to me. Most support characters are simply blatant cookie cutter stereotypes who are easily predictable and quite boring. Infinite, however, does not follow this suit. If I DID have to complain about something, (which I do, that's why it's a review) I'd complain that there isn't a large variance in the gameplay. You fight guys with guns and the occasional mini-boss, BUT OH LOOK, NOW THESE ARE DIFFERENT GUYS WITH DIFFERENT GUNS, but the mini-bosses are kinda the same, as essentially so are the baddies. But please, don't mistake this as saying the game is repetitive, which it isn't, if you play on a decent difficulty instead of coasting through life on the Easy mode... Casuals...TL;DR: Bioshock Infinite is an amazing game in which the main point is the changing relationship between Elizabeth and Booker, though the gameplay may be A LITTLE repetitive, that does not mean it is bad. You cannot have too much of a good thing.

												There's nothing positive I can say about this game that hasn't already been said better.  Overall it was interesting, weird, fun, and thoughtful.  The atmosphere was superb, the gameplay smooth, the voice acting top-notch, and the world was very well put together.  I found the game extremely linear, with some environments reused here and there when it made sense to do so.  It's linearity wasn't a bad thing; it had a story to tell and an open world wouldn't have facilitated that process.  Still, it was a shame there was this rich and gorgeous world floating there and the game ended before I felt like I'd really seen everything Columbia had to offer.  My one complaint, and one that is entirely my own fault, is that I'd been led to believe that finishing the game opened up a new game mode (1999), and that the story would continue there.  Instead 1999 mode is just the same game with a dash of extra difficulty, and I was sad my adventure with Elizabeth was over.  Oh, also, it annoyed me there was a scene in the trailer that doesn't even remotely happen in the game, which sucked because it was awesome.  :(Anyway, Bioshock: Infinite deserves all the praise it has received and more.  Absolutely splendid game.

												Okay so I thought I'd update my review that I posted about 3 years ago now. Looking back at it, this game is really a master of pulling you into the gameworld and just engulfing you completely. The story might not "click" for some people but if it does, boy it does.The graphics are on a technical level not really something to write home about but I have to give big props to the art direction. No matter where you are or in which direction you look, this game screams personality and is just gorgeous all around. The gameplay didn't change too much from the first two Bioshock games. There's still the plasmids which are now called vigors and you still shoot enemies with guns. They did add something new called a Skyhook which adds a new dynamic to the game (Atleast in the areas where you have tracks for it). Let's get to the story. Without spoiling much, the story definitely is the highlight of this game. It starts off very strong and subconciously plants a lot of questions in your mind that you want answered. This leads to the player never really being bored. It kind off falls off for some time in the middle but it ends again with a big bang. Especially the two Burial At Sea episodes wrap up the whole series quite nicely. Top Voice acting performed by notable people like Troy Baker elevates it to something truly special. There are some people who don't like this game. I get why. The gameplay is sometimes wonky and if you only play games for gameplay, this might not be the best experience you can have. But if you want to experience a truly special world, this is exactly the game for you. I for myself, love it.There's nothing like it.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
 "Booker, are you afraid of God?""No, I'm afraid of you." Disclaimer: While I don't talk about things that are major to the plot, I WILL talk about things that were revealed before the game was released.TL;DR: Overall, it's amazing. The story is great, but sometimes illogical and clichéd. The combat has been downgraded from BioShock 2, but it is still good enough that you can have fun for probably like 2 playthoughs(enough to see everything the game has to offer). Everything else is great, especially the sound.BioShock Infinite is the third installment to the BioShock series, and if you really look at it, it's BioShock 2. The real BioShock 2 is an expansion more than anything to BioShock 1. So, BioShock Infinite is as tradition, a story-driven narrative FPS game. It's been critically acclaimed and is considered the 'best FPS ever made', and I met a LOT of people calling it 'perfect'. A lot more than you would definitely expect. Then is BioShock Infinite that good? Not really. But that happens with games. And this game is still really really good.The game takes place in the flying city of Columbia. You are Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton and now a hired gun, sent to Columbia to rescue a girl trapped within the city in order to pay off a debt. The most interesting of all choices Irrational made with BioShock Infinite is that they implemented a talking protagonist- not just a talking protagonist, but there are backstories and plot-related things that are surrounding him. Ken Levin himself, the head writer for BioShock 1 and this game, said that making a talking protagonist was a LOT harder to write with then a silent one. So seeing that change was a bit surprising, but not that major since this game takes in a completely different but similar environment than the previous games.Columbia, in hindsight, is a beautiful city, but you'll quickly find out that the entire city is built on Nationalism(specifically on America) and Racism, and the city is a social commentary on these issues, and I enjoyed them. Though, the city is also built on religion, which at first was weird because BioShock 2 was a bit about religion, but Ken Levine was NOT involved in BioShock 2 whatsoever, so that can be accepted.But the entire game is actually in fact NOT about these philosophies. For some reason, folks at Irrational wanted to make BioShock Infinite about alternate dimensions. Huh. Weird approach, but I really liked it. Not very original, but they still somehow managed to fit it in with the world and the execution was great.So let's elaborate on these alternate dimensions. Elizabeth, the girl you have to save, has the power to open 'Tears', which is a doorway to another world. It works both in gameplay AND the plot; you can summon guns or cover and such from the other worlds to aid you in battle, or sometimes you'll just go to another world! Though you can't just make Tears out of thin air(the game say Elizabeth COULD, but now she can't).I won't talk about the story longer- but trust me, it's really good. I don't think it's as good as what people say, and I think it's not THAT original and clever, but the character interaction(which I can't talk about for long) and the writing itself really won me over. But... let's face it, in BioShock games; in ANY FPS games, you're going to be running around and shooting people. Then shoot people again. Watch a cutscene(not in this game though, there aren't that many cutscenes), and shoot some more people. At least, for 50% the time, you're going to be shooting people, not listening to characters talk. That's why the gameplay is so important, and this is where BioShock Infinite fails only a bit.First problem. You can only carry around two weapons. ...yes. There are NO explanations for this, even though in the previous BioShock games you could carry around 10 ♥♥♥♥ing guns at once, in this game, you can't do that. This really limits the tactical choices you can do in the combat because you can't predict the future. There'll be a point where you would say "I wish I had this and this gun right now", and that's not good. It prevents the player from having fun.There is also a lot of stuff they took out such as the Research Camera. Now I'll admit it, the Research Cameras in BioShock 1 and 2 were a broken mess gameplay-wise, but they still somehow worked and it fit right in the sci-fi heavy world that BioShock games have. They could have easily fixed it and put it into the game, put they decided it wasn't worth their time.This game also has some RPG elements with upgrades and such, which was present with BioShock even before it came out with System Shock. But the upgrades in Infinite are really dull and disappointing. You have your generic 'Damage Boost 1/2', 'Recoil Decrease', 'Reload Increase', etc. Really really dull. And I'm emphasizing this because BioShock 2 had great upgrades that were tied in with the Cameras. With the Rivet Gun, if you upgrade it fully, you can set people on fire! How cool is that! Not very useful admitibly in late-game, but still cool and it shows they put effort into it. Not in Infinite though.They HAVE implemented a brand new feature: Gears. You can get different kind of hats, shirts, pants and boots and they will give you passive upgrades to you, similar to Gene Tonics from the previous games. Unlike weapons, you can switch out Gears at ANY TIME. Wow. They did this with Gears but not weapons. I still don't understand that... but anyways, the gears are actually pretty fun to use(unlike Gene Tonics) and it also heavily encourages exploration as they will be your prime rewards for exploring the world, and BioShock has always been about exploration.There are also not a lot of enemy types, and this one enemy called the 'Siren' is basically just a chore to fight in higher difficulties. While this is a thing with a LOT of FPSs, it still doesn't excuse it. What I DO like about the gameplay is just the rest of it: the guns overall feel satisfying, but the actual gun variety is also pretty small. And 'Vigors', which are basically Plasmids, has more of the same concept, but the execution is done MUCH better then Plasmids. But again, sadly, there are only a few Vigors in the game.One things I also really like are the Sky-Lines and the Freight Hooks. You can climb on to a Freight Hook and gain height advantage, or ride around in these semi-monorails and fling around and such, It's really fun to use and the Gears also encourage the players to use Sky-Lines since there are a lot of Sky-Line related Gears. There is also a 'Shield' mechanic in the game; not original and not very well executed. A lot of times it pops out of nowhere and ruins the immersion.Let's talk about some minor parts. The graphics are vastly improved, and the world is very colourful. But there are some parts that are reminiscent of the original horror-type environments of BioShock 1 and 2. The sound design is AMAZING. Occasionally, you will hear present-day Classic Rock songs converted into 1910s-type western-feel songs, and boy, they are amazing covers. They are definitely one of the best part in the entire frickin' game.I COULD'VE gone for another paragraph about the game's story(and how it sometimes doesn't make sense), but the writing is just great in general and the storytelling is also great that you should experience it yourself. I personally thought some parts didn't add up, and some parts are only explained in the DLC, and some parts are just clichéd, but overall it was great.Overall, BioShock Infinite is an amazing game. Definetely would have been GOTY if it wasn't for the best game ever made(GTA V, wink wink) that also came out in 2013. I urge you to grab ALL of the BioShock games, and grab the Season Pass for this game as it adds a story DLC that wraps the entire series up nicely. I give BioShock Infinite a 8.8/10, it's a must own for its fairly cheap price tag.

The combat has been downgraded from BioShock 2, but it is still good enough that you can have fun for probably like 2 playthoughs(enough to see everything the game has to offer). Everything else is great, especially the sound.BioShock Infinite is the third installment to the BioShock series, and if you really look at it, it's BioShock 2. The real BioShock 2 is an expansion more than anything to BioShock 1. So, BioShock Infinite is as tradition, a story-driven narrative FPS game. It's been critically acclaimed and is considered the 'best FPS ever made', and I met a LOT of people calling it 'perfect'. A lot more than you would definitely expect. Then is BioShock Infinite that good? Not really. But that happens with games. And this game is still really really good.The game takes place in the flying city of Columbia. You are Booker DeWitt, a former Pinkerton and now a hired gun, sent to Columbia to rescue a girl trapped within the city in order to pay off a debt. The most interesting of all choices Irrational made with BioShock Infinite is that they implemented a talking protagonist- not just a talking protagonist, but there are backstories and plot-related things that are surrounding him. Ken Levin himself, the head writer for BioShock 1 and this game, said that making a talking protagonist was a LOT harder to write with then a silent one. Though, the city is also built on religion, which at first was weird because BioShock 2 was a bit about religion, but Ken Levine was NOT involved in BioShock 2 whatsoever, so that can be accepted.But the entire game is actually in fact NOT about these philosophies. For some reason, folks at Irrational wanted to make BioShock Infinite about alternate dimensions. Huh. Weird approach, but I really liked it. Not very original, but they still somehow managed to fit it in with the world and the execution was great.So let's elaborate on these alternate dimensions. Elizabeth, the girl you have to save, has the power to open 'Tears', which is a doorway to another world. It works both in gameplay AND the plot; you can summon guns or cover and such from the other worlds to aid you in battle, or sometimes you'll just go to another world! Though you can't just make Tears out of thin air(the game say Elizabeth COULD, but now she can't).I won't talk about the story longer- but trust me, it's really good. I don't think it's as good as what people say, and I think it's not THAT original and clever, but the character interaction(which I can't talk about for long) and the writing itself really won me over. But... let's face it, in BioShock games; in ANY FPS games, you're going to be running around and shooting people. Then shoot people again. Watch a cutscene(not in this game though, there aren't that many cutscenes), and shoot some more people. At least, for 50% the time, you're going to be shooting people, not listening to characters talk. That's why the gameplay is so important, and this is where BioShock Infinite fails only a bit.First problem. You can only carry around two weapons. ...yes. There are NO explanations for this, even though in the previous BioShock games you could carry around 10 ♥♥♥♥ing guns at once, in this game, you can't do that. This really limits the tactical choices you can do in the combat because you can't predict the future. There'll be a point where you would say "I wish I had this and this gun right now", and that's not good. It prevents the player from having fun.There is also a lot of stuff they took out such as the Research Camera. Now I'll admit it, the Research Cameras in BioShock 1 and 2 were a broken mess gameplay-wise, but they still somehow worked and it fit right in the sci-fi heavy world that BioShock games have. Not very useful admitibly in late-game, but still cool and it shows they put effort into it. Not in Infinite though.They HAVE implemented a brand new feature: Gears. You can get different kind of hats, shirts, pants and boots and they will give you passive upgrades to you, similar to Gene Tonics from the previous games. Unlike weapons, you can switch out Gears at ANY TIME. Wow. They did this with Gears but not weapons. I still don't understand that... but anyways, the gears are actually pretty fun to use(unlike Gene Tonics) and it also heavily encourages exploration as they will be your prime rewards for exploring the world, and BioShock has always been about exploration.There are also not a lot of enemy types, and this one enemy called the 'Siren' is basically just a chore to fight in higher difficulties. While this is a thing with a LOT of FPSs, it still doesn't excuse it. What I DO like about the gameplay is just the rest of it: the guns overall feel satisfying, but the actual gun variety is also pretty small. And 'Vigors', which are basically Plasmids, has more of the same concept, but the execution is done MUCH better then Plasmids. But again, sadly, there are only a few Vigors in the game.One things I also really like are the Sky-Lines and the Freight Hooks. You can climb on to a Freight Hook and gain height advantage, or ride around in these semi-monorails and fling around and such, It's really fun to use and the Gears also encourage the players to use Sky-Lines since there are a lot of Sky-Line related Gears. There is also a 'Shield' mechanic in the game; not original and not very well executed. A lot of times it pops out of nowhere and ruins the immersion.Let's talk about some minor parts. The graphics are vastly improved, and the world is very colourful. But there are some parts that are reminiscent of the original horror-type environments of BioShock 1 and 2. Posted: April 6, 2013
												Buy. This. Game. Now....no seriously. I'll wait. Oh, you haven’t bought it yet? And you want a (average) review on it? Alright then, here it goes. This is a masterpiece. People are relating it to Half Life 2, and Uncharted based on how good it is. It currently holds a meta critic score of 96/100 which is almost unseen of. The graphics and visuals in this game are absolutely stunning. You can easily get lost in this game's atmosphere looking for money, looting every corner of every place you visit, listening to the conversations between NPCs, reading the extremely well-designed advertisements located on walls, posters etc... I can go on all day. The amount of love and craftsmanship that went into this excellent piece of work is jaw-dropping. If you have the chance play this game on Ultra Settings, the graphics are almost better than life, its that good. Take the time to look at the detail on your weapon, or a poster on a wall, and I assure you, you WILL NOT see any sort of distortion or pixels (except when zooming in with a sniper). That my friends, is how detailed the world is. The gameplay pretty decent honestly, but nothing to special. You have your standard FPS gameplay, shooting your weapons, blowing off enemies’ heads and what not, but also has its own twist. Similar to the old bioshock titles, you can equip and weapon in one hand while casting lightening spells at your enemies with the other, or perhaps sending a flock of crows to eat away at your enemies flesh as you gun him down. The story as you progress is very good. You start to form a relationship with the character Elizabeth as she aids you throughout the game (also her character design is awesome, like something out of a Pixar movie). Toward the end of Bioshock Infinite the story starts to go full circle. But without spoiling, I did scratch my head for a good 5 minutes toward the last 30 seconds of the game, trying to figure out what just happened. But once I figured this interestingly beautiful (in an odd way) ending, I was satisfied. Sadly thought this game took me about 8 hours to complete on Medium, which is quite decent. I also play a lot of FPS games so there wasn’t much challenge for me. But next time I get the chance I will be doing a Hard run, just to give myself a bit more of a challenge, and to relive the atmosphere.Turn off all the lights in your room, put on some high quality headphones, turn the graphics on Ultra (if you can), and strap in because Bioshock Infinite, is easily going to take hours of your life away, as you explore this beautiful and extremely detailed world. Bioshock Infinite easily earns a 9 / 10.

												It's been months since I've first played this game, and let me tell you. I am still absolutely awestricken by this game. THE GRAPHICS: Amazing, very smooth and nice to look at. THE ENVIRONMENT: Though it seems to be a happy and cheerful environment at first, the environment can really show its sick and twisted underbelly. Which is exactly this game's intention. The environment in this game really says a lot about it and is most like nothing you could have seen before.GAMEPLAY: Though it has very similar gameplay to its predecessors in the franchise, it has features that are not of the previous that make it fun and unique. The main part in this being the character, Elizibeth, who can bring new things into the area and help you with things such as HP and replenish your ammuntion.THE STORY: Man, the story on this game is absolutely a work of art. A masterpiece, if you will. It will always keep you guessing and is filled with twists and turns. With the Burial at Sea DLC it really ties all of it together.THE CHARACTERS: Arguably the best thing about this game is its characters. The characters work very well in their environment, are very dynamic, and can be very relatable. A man fallen on hard times, a girl hidden from the eyes of the world, or a few people who just want to have a sense of freedom.Another thing I say this game does greatly is give the main protagonist a personality. Whereas the main protagonist in  the first game, Jack, has no definate personality, Booker Dewitt has a very definate one. Some protagonists' personalities  don't work quite well with them, but with Booker, you really get a sense of what he's thinking and his goals in mind. He's a great character, well written, with a great and definate personality. Don't even get me started on Elizabeth, either. She's arguably one of the most dynamic characters I've ever seen.I figure I've spent enough time on this review. You want to know more about this game, you say? Buy it, it is worth every last cent.I rate this game 10/10. Has played, and will play, over, and over, and over, again.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is a beautiful game with interesting characters and an engaging story that jumps the shark toward the end and lost my interest.The mechanics of the game do not live up to the aesthetic and story. The gunplay is very average. Some guns have some nice kick and decent variety, but I never was extremely entertained by the combat. Also, the looting system left me searching every nook for lockpicks and money fearing that without the upgrades I'd get from these I'd be helpless in later combat. That distracted too much from the narrative and prevented me from truely enjoying the story to its fullest potential.The city is beautifully designed and creates a visual representation of the extreme contrast between the rich and the poor in the Guilded Age, the time following the American Civil War up to the early 1910s. Rich parts of town look bright and beautiful while the ghettos are run down and dark.The story and characters of Bioshock Infinite may be its greatest achievement after its art style. While the story kept me engaged for almost the whole game, the last few hours or so of the story became very odd. I was very disappointed, and I was hoping for a simpler resolution than the grand drama the last few hours became. Also, there are far too many plot twists. I started feeling like the game was trying to hard to draw itself out. Overall, the story is worth experiencing despite its flaws.While Bioshock Infinite's mechanics and ending detract from its engaging plot and aesthetic, Bioshock Infinite is still a brilliant narrative driven game that is a joy to experience.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite seems, at first glance, to be a rather significant departure from the norm in this series: where Rapture was worn down and decaying, your first view of Columbia is of a radiant and lively city (in the clouds).Thematically, however, it is just as ambitious as the first Bioshock, and has more than a few parallels to it.In terms of story, it excels: one of my favorite narratives in games, and I do not give that praise lightly.In terms of game mechanics, it doesn't deviate that much from the tried and true Bioshock formula. In fact, one of the few problems that I found with it is that it oversimplifies it: gear (which substitutes tonics) is nothing but an afterthought in normal difficulty and, barring a few places, I found the game rather easy (and I'm no pro). It has, however, one of the finest implementations of sidekicks in FPS of all time: not only is Elizabeth actually helpful (I lost count of the times she offered my health or ammo just when I needed it), but she is a interesting, developed character. Hell, it might be argued that she, and not you, is the main character of the game.Also, great, great, great music, and more related to the plot that it may appear at first glance.So, short version: great game, excepcional story, a bit easy, game mechanics needlessly simplified. Not a perfect game, but a game that you really should play, even if FPS are not your favorite genre.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2013
												There is really nothing I can say about this game that hasn't been said already.  This is by far one of the best games I've played in many years.  From the storyline to the gameplay, this is a winner.  It keeps you interested all the way through, and once you finally get 1999 Mode, the action becomes something truly incredible.  If you havn't bought this, or say it hasn't lived up to the hype...play it, or play it again.  Its a masterpiece in gaming, and one owes it to themselves to at least try it, to at least experience the beginning.Edit: I keep thinking over my original review, and I feel I should kinda make it, you know, a proper review, and give the goods with the bads.  I'm a little bit biased, as I LOVE this game, and would go as far as to say it's one of, if not the best video game that has come out since the golden age of gaming.  Yes, that's a bold statement, but I think I can back it up.First of all, I should state what isn't so good: the combat.  I just got the dlc, and honestly, I hadn't played in a little while, so I was rusty.  Slowly but surely, I started to notice that even though it was fun to play and shoot stuff, it didn't have the impact so many other games like it have.  A lot of people don't like gore, but really, it's here to stay.  Many gorier games have combat that's just plain gut-wrenching, where you literally feel the bullets fly out of your fun.  This game doesn't have that as much, and with the storyline it has got, the combat shouldnt only look viseral, it should sound and feel viseral too.  I can say that's my only complaint, and it isn't much of one either, as it's still fun to play, just not as good as could be hoped. Now, to what I bypassed in the original review: the attention to detail.  The world of Infinite is a living, breathing society.  It has relatable characters, even in it's villains, (cough cough like Andrew Ryan cough) and an incredible vision of this world.  The future songs reverted to the music of years past.  The scenes of the future, and the confusion of these from the protagonist.  The ruddy landscape, like heaven itself, gleaming down upon you!  This game, in terms of what it sometimes doesn't say, and in terms of how the makers of it worked, is damn near perfect.  I've never just not wanted the game to end, and afterwards, not even want a sequel to it, as it couldn't even compare to it's predecessor.  If you haven't played this game, please...would you kindly pay the money, and pay attention to what isn't said in this masterpiece?  Don't just play the game: with mouse or controller in hand, live it.  That's the only way to appreciate it fully.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												THIS REVIEW IS FOR THE BIOSHOCK INFINITE DLC, BURIAL AT SEA EPISODE 2. THIS IS NOT A REVIEW OF BIOSHOCK INFINITE. This is without a doubt the best DLC I've ever played. I liked Burial at Sea Episode 2 more than BioShock Infinite itself. Maybe the reason why I enjoyed this so much is because I'm a huge fan of the original BioShock, but at the same time I really liked Elizabeth's character and the way she interacted with characters from the original game. The Schrodinger's Cat stuff is still present due to this being an expansion of BioShock Infinite's story. This doesn't really bother me, though, seeing as the story is presented in a way where the player can actually take a moment to digest everything that's been happening - as opposed to BioShock Infinite. I'm not into the whole multiple dimensions thing, but if I absolutely had to have a story with it - this is how I'd want it done. Pros- Stealth combat that feels fresh after BioShock and BioShock Infinite's manic gunplay.- A plot that isn't as hard to swallow as BioShock Infinite's.- Great atmosphere - fans of the original BioShock will love it.- A couple new vigors/plasmids are introduced for the first time.- A great wrap-up to BioShock Infinite and a fantastic prequel for the original BioShock.- Sheds light on a few previously unseen areas and factoids of Rapture.Cons- The plot can seem kind of far out sometimes.- Plot holes, depending on how hard you want to look.- The Peeping Tom plasmid can kind of break the game's stealth mechanics. - The fact that the game tries to push you into playing stealthily as opposed to all guns blazing.- Going back to Colombia.- I wish it were longer!Overall, this is an amazing DLC that is definitely worth the admission fee. If you liked the first BioShock and didn't care too much for Infinite, this is basically a love letter to you from Irrational Games. Would you kindly kick back and enjoy your return to Rapture?

content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												It's been months since I've first played this game, and let me tell you. I am still absolutely awestricken by this game. THE GRAPHICS: Amazing, very smooth and nice to look at. THE ENVIRONMENT: Though it seems to be a happy and cheerful environment at first, the environment can really show its sick and twisted underbelly. Which is exactly this game's intention. The environment in this game really says a lot about it and is most like nothing you could have seen before.GAMEPLAY: Though it has very similar gameplay to its predecessors in the franchise, it has features that are not of the previous that make it fun and unique. The main part in this being the character, Elizibeth, who can bring new things into the area and help you with things such as HP and replenish your ammuntion.THE STORY: Man, the story on this game is absolutely a work of art. A masterpiece, if you will. It will always keep you guessing and is filled with twists and turns. With the Burial at Sea DLC it really ties all of it together.THE CHARACTERS: Arguably the best thing about this game is its characters. The characters work very well in their environment, are very dynamic, and can be very relatable. A man fallen on hard times, a girl hidden from the eyes of the world, or a few people who just want to have a sense of freedom.Another thing I say this game does greatly is give the main protagonist a personality. Whereas the main protagonist in  the first game, Jack, has no definate personality, Booker Dewitt has a very definate one. Some protagonists' personalities  don't work quite well with them, but with Booker, you really get a sense of what he's thinking and his goals in mind. He's a great character, well written, with a great and definate personality. Don't even get me started on Elizabeth, either. She's arguably one of the most dynamic characters I've ever seen.I figure I've spent enough time on this review. You want to know more about this game, you say? Buy it, it is worth every last cent.I rate this game 10/10. Has played, and will play, over, and over, and over, again.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2013
												Completed it in 18.6 hours on hard, almost a full investigation of all areas since it seems I missed 4 voxophones (aka audio diaries). Very deep and involving plot, to really appreciate the ending, you must search for all of the voxophones to really get a feel for the world they have created. A little too much exposition at the end though, which can be quite jarring if were just blazing through the game. I'd be lying if I said I didn't tear up.Also, make sure you watch the credits. Halfway through you see a video of the voice actors sing a song in the game, once that's over, keep waiting until the veeery end.Elizabeth is one of the strongest female characters in a game I've seen, in the sense of good characterisation. She's not weak enough to be damsel in distress (technically, she's invulnerable to damage anyway, no annoying escort quests here) aside from one section of the game which is both creepy but downright depressing. The tears she creates make her extremely useful, as well as those little moments when she find you money, health, ammo and salts. By creating this pseudo-interaction with her, you really begin to grow attached to her. also, she tends to point out interesting things like hidden lockpicks and whatnot. Her reactions to you vary throughout the game, and her posture reflects this.Boss battles don't really exist, just large enemies, but you'll grow to hate them. Handymen especially are the worst, I died around fifteen times in one battle until I found the trick to beat them. The same with 'another' boss who I will not name.Overall, a must play. There are no mulitple endings apparently, though some may disagree. Saying any more would spoil the game :)

I found the game extremely linear, with some environments reused here and there when it made sense to do so.  It's linearity wasn't a bad thing; it had a story to tell and an open world wouldn't have facilitated that process.  Still, it was a shame there was this rich and gorgeous world floating there and the game ended before I felt like I'd really seen everything Columbia had to offer.  My one complaint, and one that is entirely my own fault, is that I'd been led to believe that finishing the game opened up a new game mode (1999), and that the story would continue there.  Instead 1999 mode is just the same game with a dash of extra difficulty, and I was sad my adventure with Elizabeth was over.  Oh, also, it annoyed me there was a scene in the trailer that doesn't even remotely happen in the game, which sucked because it was awesome.  :(Anyway, Bioshock: Infinite deserves all the praise it has received and more.  Absolutely splendid game.

twitter - @verticalspriteBioshock Burial At Sea Part 2Many games these days play it safe, not veering from the popular or well worn. Burial At Sea part 2 not only provides unique and mature content, but shows how DLC can be just as significant as the main game.When Burial At Sea Episode 1 ended it was possible to feel slightly let down. The content was of good quality but no real risks were taken. Episode 2 mixes up the gameplay, gives us the chance to play as Elizabeth and in the process tie up loose ends regarding Rapture and Columbia.Although the story follows on from Burial At Sea episode 1 you could be wondering why, as Elisabeth, you wake up in Paris with an opening set piece that's very similar to Infinite's. Walking down the street you see a beautifully crafted world, with locals greeting you in French and going about their day to day business. But Elisabeth doesn't stay in this wonderland for long. Before you know it you are back in Rapture and trying to rescue Sally. It wont be easy though, Sally is being held as ransom by Atlas, who is more calculating and sinister as ever.  Being a veteran player of the Bioshock games wont help you here. The gameplay is significantly changed from everything gone before. Elisabeth is weaker not able to open tears or see past doors thus limiting what she can do. Realising early on she wont win in a gun battle Elisabeth relies on her wits and outsmarting the enemy. You can kill or take down splicers but it's a slower and more tense experience. Its essentially a stealth and explore game, forcing you to duck, hide and stay out of sight while collecting scraps of information, trying to meet Atlas's demands. You know the task at hand is never as easy as its first made out to be but seeing the twists and turns of several storylines unravel in front of you is fantastic.Playing as Elisabeth is genuinely a new experience making you look at levels differently and adapt your play style to match your gear. Certain sections aren't dissimilar to challenge style rooms forcing you to think on your feet and cover all angles of attack. If your spotted you wont be fighting your way out of it. Laying traps and using stun darts tactically are the order of the day almost forcing you to be more absorbed in Raptures world as you play at a different pace. If you ever wondered how Elisabeth picked those locks, then it's answered here in the form of a mini-game where you can either get a noisemaking dart to aid you or set off an alarm which alerts nearby splicers. Its not complicated, simply being a test of reflexes but its better then simply needing enough lock picks to proceed.  Burial At Sea episode 2 doesn't have that much backtracking although the main portion of the game takes place in a "hub" of sorts giving you freedom to roam as you see fit. Follow the story and you will see most of what this DLC has to offer, yet even with the game basically telling you to explore and discover its still possible to miss that door code via audio log or that nod towards previous games hidden in a corner. Just by chance opening a door which was almost missed and not  part of any objective, led to a whole new area with upgrades and supplies. Another time curiosity may reward you with one of the biggest jump scares in recent times, almost seeming like Bioshock is saying "told you so".  Out of all of Bioshocks content on offer Burial At Sea part 2 nails the atmosphere perfectly. There are many areas of Rapture that are beyond eerie, and being forced to take your time due to your abilities only heightens the tension. Some very limited assets are re-used but they never seem shoehorned it to simply lengthen the DLC. Everything on offer here is present for a reason making Burial At Sea as powerful as any of the main Bioshock games.Episode 1 was very generic in its approach to Rapture giving you only a hand full of tools and a style of play seen many times. Episode 2 does not make the same mistake. There are a very few minor missteps like re-spawning enemies from time to time or the odd difficulty spike. You have plenty of weapons at your disposal to fall back on but the slower stealth mechanics of Elisabeth makes sense and it forces you to play differently. Also seeing parts of Rapture that easily surpass that of anything offered in Bioshock 1 or 2 was a huge welcome, being able to observe the relationship between Big Daddy and Little Sister evolve  or realising the ties between Rapture and Columbia go way deeper then ever thought possible, Burial At Sea Episode 2 is worth the season pass asking price alone. Clocking in at over 3 hours this DLC a massive fan service to both Infinite and the original Bioshock games that no-one should miss.Phenomenal PlotEerie AtmosphereTies up loose endsFitting Conclusion5/5

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												When I first played this game back in 2013 I bought all the hype and thought it was a perfect masterpiece and all that crap. Over the next while I slowly started to see its flaws and began resenting it for being so overrated compared to some games that I believed to be far better. Until the point that I pretty much hated it just because it got too much praise.I recently replayed it and I'm somewhere in between those things now. It's definitely a good overall game with some very compelling qualities, but it's not the same game that MetaCritic will tell you it is.The combat is in no way tactically demanding, but it's fast-paced and satisfying. If I could use one word to describe it, I would probably call it very "juicy" (shut up Whitely). Some examples of straightup bad game design are handymen, the pathfinding feature, the final fight's level design, and above all else the decision to limit the player to two guns. I seriously will never understand that...Presentation is completely stunning, I don't think anyone can argue that. The models, textures, animations, effects, and especially the lighting build powerful atmosphere even when the story falls flat at times. The score, voice acting, and sound design help as well.But the thing everyone talks about is the story, which is where I actually have the biggest problem. It's ridiculously full of itself. In fact I don't think there's another game as laughably pretentious as this one.The relationship between Booker and Elizabeth is sooo clunky (with scattered exceptions), the ending is poorly delivered (while nobly ambitious), and the side characters are completely boring.Despite its flaws that people seemed to completely overlook at launch, I do think that everyone should play this game. If nothing else because it tried. It deserves to be recognized as something special, as an example of a company who was brave enough to go outside the comfort box of the FPS industry.

You know the task at hand is never as easy as its first made out to be but seeing the twists and turns of several storylines unravel in front of you is fantastic.Playing as Elisabeth is genuinely a new experience making you look at levels differently and adapt your play style to match your gear. Certain sections aren't dissimilar to challenge style rooms forcing you to think on your feet and cover all angles of attack. If your spotted you wont be fighting your way out of it. Laying traps and using stun darts tactically are the order of the day almost forcing you to be more absorbed in Raptures world as you play at a different pace. If you ever wondered how Elisabeth picked those locks, then it's answered here in the form of a mini-game where you can either get a noisemaking dart to aid you or set off an alarm which alerts nearby splicers. Its not complicated, simply being a test of reflexes but its better then simply needing enough lock picks to proceed.  Burial At Sea episode 2 doesn't have that much backtracking although the main portion of the game takes place in a "hub" of sorts giving you freedom to roam as you see fit. Follow the story and you will see most of what this DLC has to offer, yet even with the game basically telling you to explore and discover its still possible to miss that door code via audio log or that nod towards previous games hidden in a corner. Just by chance opening a door which was almost missed and not  part of any objective, led to a whole new area with upgrades and supplies. Another time curiosity may reward you with one of the biggest jump scares in recent times, almost seeming like Bioshock is saying "told you so".  Out of all of Bioshocks content on offer Burial At Sea part 2 nails the atmosphere perfectly. There are many areas of Rapture that are beyond eerie, and being forced to take your time due to your abilities only heightens the tension. Some very limited assets are re-used but they never seem shoehorned it to simply lengthen the DLC. Everything on offer here is present for a reason making Burial At Sea as powerful as any of the main Bioshock games.Episode 1 was very generic in its approach to Rapture giving you only a hand full of tools and a style of play seen many times. Episode 2 does not make the same mistake. There are a very few minor missteps like re-spawning enemies from time to time or the odd difficulty spike. You have plenty of weapons at your disposal to fall back on but the slower stealth mechanics of Elisabeth makes sense and it forces you to play differently. Also seeing parts of Rapture that easily surpass that of anything offered in Bioshock 1 or 2 was a huge welcome, being able to observe the relationship between Big Daddy and Little Sister evolve  or realising the ties between Rapture and Columbia go way deeper then ever thought possible, Burial At Sea Episode 2 is worth the season pass asking price alone. Clocking in at over 3 hours this DLC a massive fan service to both Infinite and the original Bioshock games that no-one should miss.Phenomenal PlotEerie AtmosphereTies up loose endsFitting Conclusion5/5

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												I haven't played Bioshock 2 so I can only compare my experiences to the first game, and I'm happy to say that I had a much better experience than I did with the first game.The story is a time-travel / alt universe story that plays out pretty well I think, and I think one of the reasons it plays out so well because the devs put quite a bit of work into making the aesthetic and setting of the game really add to the story.  A lot of environments are pretty impressive and genuinely pleasing to behold, and I definitely took my time to appreciate quite a few of them.  The setting feels pretty well set out and character personalities feel right and topics such as racism and religion are well integrated and dont feel shoehorned in at all.  Elizabeth as second -main- character who has personality and importance to the story also adds a lot to the game, and gives the game a much better sense of reality than BS1 or other FPS games I have played do where side characters die off or don't have much depth to them.In some ways the weakest part of the game was probably the gameplay itself.  Guns and powers and their related upgrades feel a bit lacking in 'oomph' and there just a bit too many of them, and the game presents only a few enemies with the same powers you have.  There is quite a bit of combat in the game, a topic which I have seen other players complain about, but it didn't seem too excessive compared to other main-genre FPS games I have played, and it was at the least MUCH better than the combat in BS1.  The skyrail platforming works for quick movement and elevation-changing but just feels a bit too awkward in combat.  All that being said, I don't feel like the gameplay was a detriment or a displeasure at all.  It's just not amazing, and theres nothing wrong with that.The setting isn't without its flaws either, although minor.  For real, there needs to be more guard rails since falling off the city would be a huge hazard.  I don't have any problems with the story, I liked it as is without much need to contend with any details despite one or two specific points I am a little perplexed on.  On principle I don't like the mechanic of delivering the story in voicemail recordings, as I feel like its a little bit too much of a modern throwaway mechanic to give the player a digestable plot, but that's how it is these days and the story was good enough that I didn't mind it either.The game ran well with everything set on High / Very High.  Although fraps gave my FPS to be about 30-45 most of the time, my rig isn't amazing and the game never stuttered or felt like it was performing badly.Overall, I enjoyed the game a lot, much more than my usual FPS experience.   I'd reccommend the game, and would like to thank the person who gifted it to me.  I had fun.I haven't played the DLC but it has been reccommended to me.  I'll update this review when I get the chance to play it.

												Okay so I thought I'd update my review that I posted about 3 years ago now. Looking back at it, this game is really a master of pulling you into the gameworld and just engulfing you completely. The story might not "click" for some people but if it does, boy it does.The graphics are on a technical level not really something to write home about but I have to give big props to the art direction. No matter where you are or in which direction you look, this game screams personality and is just gorgeous all around. The gameplay didn't change too much from the first two Bioshock games. There's still the plasmids which are now called vigors and you still shoot enemies with guns. They did add something new called a Skyhook which adds a new dynamic to the game (Atleast in the areas where you have tracks for it). Let's get to the story. Without spoiling much, the story definitely is the highlight of this game. It starts off very strong and subconciously plants a lot of questions in your mind that you want answered. This leads to the player never really being bored. It kind off falls off for some time in the middle but it ends again with a big bang. Especially the two Burial At Sea episodes wrap up the whole series quite nicely. Top Voice acting performed by notable people like Troy Baker elevates it to something truly special. There are some people who don't like this game. I get why. The gameplay is sometimes wonky and if you only play games for gameplay, this might not be the best experience you can have. But if you want to experience a truly special world, this is exactly the game for you. I for myself, love it.There's nothing like it.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Out of the two Bioshock games, Infinite has over thrown over the original Bioshock just by the skin of its teeth.(Yes I said two. That God awful game called Bioshock 2 does not count.) The thing that caught my attention immediately was the atmosphere and look of Infinite. It was an alien to the series, not just because it wasn't under water anymore but with the colors, the atmosphere and THE COLORS. The city of Rapture had a feeling of isolation and despair to its world. It had the colors of a dying rainbow, dont get me wrong I loved that about it. I thought that was a key feature for the series, but I was wrong. Columbia was a "happier" place to be in. It was bright, colorful and the old American feel to it was outstanding as well. Columbia was just a better world to roam around than Rapture. Because it has that open feel to it that the tubes of Rapture failed to  give, thus I found myself covering every inch of the world. A big factor I noticed in Infinite Vigors (Plasmids in the old Bioshock) was not an actual highlight to the story. There is no build up to it you just literally pick it up and drink it. That was an odd thing for me. Enough about the world time for the characters.Bioshock Infinte produced a handful of memorable character compared to the first one. Your character Booker Dewitt actually talks often so it just gives him more character than just another generic piece of meat that you control. He is further highlighted by his sidekick whom I think is the star of the game. Elizabeth the girl nextdoor type or rather the girl next to a cage(I laughed at my joke more than I should.). She's smart and has a lovely feel. It's an odd feeling to see someone so happy in a game that you actually feel happy for them. Play the game and you'll know what I mean. Sadly her character development was altered faster than expected maybe it was because of the things that happening in the story. I hoped for more dialogue between Dewitt and Elizabeth because it was charming and funny how they spoke to each other. The Lutece siblings were terrific. They added a depth to the pool of characters in the game. Maybe because they were british? A game is only as good as its gameplay and Infinite's gameplay is what won me over. The added sky line feature was a major touch to it. It just adds that momentum feel to it, rather than just running around, it different I can tell you that. The Vigors available in the game worked perfectly together and was fun to think of new combos that would destroy your enemies. Weapons were abundant but I just used 3-4. There is no more hacking in the game which for was a good thing. I was never really a fan of that. Now you just have to find lockpicks for Elizabeth to use. Oh and Elizabeth is an amazing sidekick. she is actually useful. The game is now a "loot fest" as you can pick up a lot of things for your health, vigor and ammo. You dont have health kits anymore you need to pick up a lot of things to regenerate your health(Which I like). The enemies are'nt that memorable because they're just normal people so you'll probably miss the good old splicers. It's still a solid FPS game. My finaly Verdict is that Bioshock is a soild 9/10 game. Now I say 8 because the story is an odd one. Not that I dont get it I played the game twice just to see that I actually got it being that Im an idiot. Sadly it feels that it tried so hard to shove the story down your throat. The last 25 minutes of the game is where all of it actually makes sense rather than just spread the story through out the game so that player would slowly "decode" it and form their own theories as they are playing the game so that the plot twist would have been a bigger shocker. Saddly it was not as good as the first Bioshock. It had way to much sub-plots that makes you lose sight of the main story. A shame really, if only the plots intertwined as good as I hoped them to be. non the less its a good game I recommend you buying it. Just wait for sales though I noticed that this game is almost free when it goes on sale so keep that in mind. or just buy the trilogy the down side is you'll get Bioshock 2. This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend BioShock Infinite then skip to Results and read from there.Irrational Games takes what 2K started did and pushes it above and beyond reality. One cannot come to words for how to describe BioShock Infinite as there are no words that possibly capture its essence. Story:As you sit in your little office you are given an offer, one that will allow you to be free of all that you owe. Two people, a man and a woman, provide you with an ultimatum with you accept. You are given the opportunity to go to a world in the clouds and retrieve a girl. As you push through your mission you will learn more about yourself than you ever wanted to know. Campaign:BioShock Infinite campaign is of decent length. Depending on the difficulty you chose and your play-style you get through this game from anywhere between 10-16 hours. I would recommend taking your time as this game is more about the story than the gameplay and missing the smallest element can result in a completely different understanding. The campaign is divvied up across 40-chapters, all varying in length, some take only a minute, while others you’ll be wondering for at-least an hour. An interesting element in Infinite is that almost all of the cinematics involve player interaction. You control basic camera elements, as well as in some scenes interaction with the environment. This provides a more immersive campaign than traditional games. Gameplay:BioShock Infinite does away with tonics, ADAM, and limited weapon upgrades. Instead of Plasmids you use Vigors, which are essentially the same thing with a different name. The only currency in the game is Silver Eagles, most likely based on the US Silver Dollar and Half-Dollar. You can use this money to buy weapon upgrades, Vigor upgrades, and ammo/health/salts. Unlike in the first two you no longer need to acquire Adam to get Vigor upgrades, which means you can customize your gameplay based on what you plan to use more. I was weapon intensive so I spent all my cash on weapon upgrades, and only upgraded on Vigor for the achievement. You also don’t buy Vigors instead you unlock them for free throughout the campaign which means you will have every single one by the end of the game. There are 14-weapons that you will find throughout the campaign: Sky-Hook, Broadsider Pistol, China Boom Shotgun, Triple R Machine Gun, Huntsman Carbine, Bird’s Eye Sniper Rifle, Paddywhacker Hand Cannon, Peppermill Crank Gun, Pig Flak Volley Gun, Heater, Burstgun, Repeater, and Hail Fire. So you won’t feel limited in this game by your weapon choice, as you have more than you can ever imagine. Although despite all these choices you can only ever carry two-weapons at one time. So you will more than likely stick to what you like, as you may not get it back for a while if you let it go. A new feature to the series is Infusions; infusions are vials found throughout the campaign that allow you to increase your health, shield, or salts (mana). Depending on your play-style you may find more or less of these throughout the campaign, but you will probably not find them all. Some are in secret areas, while others are right infront of your very eyes. Infusions allow you to customize yourself without limiting your capital.Results:BioShock Infinite is an amazingly beautiful game that is aweing and terrifying at the same time. Like all BioShocks you will enter confused and cautious, but as the game unfolds you will never want to put it down. The story is beautiful, the gameplay is fantastic, the music is breathtaking, and the environment is inspirational. As you play you will learn more about yourself that you can imagine through even the simplest choices, heads or tails?Pros:+Amazing story, amazing doesn’t even breach how brilliant it is.+Beautiful environment, you will stand there just to look at how beautiful the architecture is, how elegant the people are, how clean the world is.+Amazing music, the music is simple but rather still brings much depth to the game. Even the combat music draws shivers up your spine.+Great graphics engine, as well as a fantastic optimization tool. +Awesome boss battles, which keep you on your toesCons:-The enemies are kind of lacking (Most of them are the same enemy with a different gun)-The combat AI is rather limited, I found myself taking advantage of how stupid they were on many occasions.-They got rid of the manual saves (if you have a busy schedule you sometimes don’t have time to find a checkpoint).

For instance, the early NPC's of Columbia introduce topics, like the Vox Populi, which are not fully explained until halfway through the game. Some may argue that this is counterproductive, but I believe it holds some strategic merit. Oh, and the Lutece Twins, my favorite side characters from Infinite, are exceptional examples of how game characters can really connect to the player! After all, they "are where [they] are needed and needed where [they] are"...

												It’s old, it’s been covered, the plot has been spoiled and the DLC produced, yet somehow I never got caught in the media blaze that was hailing Bioshock Infinite for being one of the best narratives in gaming. In fact, I actually managed to play it completely blind well over two years after it’s release in 2013. So here’s my verdict for this once near-idolized FPS RPG: Eh it’s a pretty good game I guess.I remember the ravings and the discussions over just how mind blowing the story was and how everyone just melted into an ooze of wonder when they hit the big plot twist, but it was just good. I think whoever wrote the story did a great job and I hope they were well commended for it, but the game on the whole was nothing revolutionary. The formula was refined but essentially handled like the other BioShock titles. The gunplay wasn’t weak but certainly didn’t carry much weight. The vigors even lacked depth; I found myself only ever really using the shock/fireball/charm vigors, and I only fired the shield and tentacle one just to say I tried. If there is anything to praise about BioShock Infinite, it’s Elizabeth. No not because her “story is so fantastic” and the narrative she delivers is “mind-bending”. Honestly, she could have had next to no involvement in the plot and I would have still been blown away simply for the fact that I did not hate every single action she took. I have not seen an AI companion in a game be this not-terrible since Half Life. Every game that ever wants to do AI companions or even escort missions needs to take a good hard look at how Elizabeth behaves both in and out of combat. She never gets stuck, never halts progression, never runs into a hail of bullets to find cover behind a nearby piece of paper, doesn’t require you to hold her hand through every single encounter and in fact reliably keeps you in relatively good shape during combat by tossing you ammo, health and salts.BioShock Infinite is alright, well worth picking it up on sale for 10 or 15 bucks, but in my mind the most amazing thing about it is that someone finally made an AI companion that wasn’t the absolute worst thing on the face of the earth.

												BIoshock Infinite... where to begin?The story of Bioshock is one that we all have come to love. The first game was memoriable not because of the new gameplay elements it introducted with plasma, but because the story was so gripping. I played that game in ONE SITTING because i was so into the game. It was one of the only games that i have every done that with. Bioshock 2 takes place 8 years after the first but left a hole in the plot and was almost a copy and paste version of the first.Now Bioshock Infinite comes out.Bioshock Infinite may not offer the newest shooting elements, nor will it win any awards for the multiplayer, but this game stands out as a TRUE sequel to the first Bioshock. The characters, the story, the enviroment, everything stands out just like it did in the first Bioshock. It starts with Booker DeWitt and he is searching for a woman named Elizabeth. The reasoning behind this is vague,cloudy and adds to the development of the story. "Bring us the girl and wipe away the debt". Columbia feels different than Rapture...yet strangely familiar. You will be impressed looking around just as you did with the first Bioshock.Columbia's world sucks you straight in and never let's up. I was surprised to see countless themes put into this new world. Racism, Social Class System, Socialism, War, Rebellion, Revolt, everything that was found in the early 20th Century.Some people might be turned off because of the "religious" theme that is found throughout the story, but believe me it does not turn the story off. i HIGHELY RECOMMEND that you search for all the VOXOPHONES to get the entire story of Bioshock Infinite.The graphics in Bioshock Infinite are right up there with some of the best and  current PC games. Whether it comes to a keyboard or a controller the controls are tight and responsive either way. Take the time to look around and see the detail and hidden secrets that the world of Columbia has to offer. This is probably my GOT for 2013.I look forward to the newest installment of Bioshock through DLC and maybe a sequel? Who Knows?10/10

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												BioShock Infinite is a beautiful game, suffice it to say. It's a wonderfully crafted story that tackles so many different concepts, you'll wonder how they could have fit so much thinking in one game. Free will, betrayal, racism, religion, human life, faith, the unseen, and of course, interdimensional travel. I have lots to say about this game so I think I will break it up into a few different segments.Graphics-The graphics in BioShock Infinite are utterly gorgeous. There is no other way to put it. The artistic vision and realistic textures are blended together in a splendid way.Character Development-It is impossible not to become infatuated with Elizabeth when she first appears. Her naivete, her identity crisis, her piercing blue eyes... Simply wonderful, that one. Elizabeth is like something out of a Disney movie, with a bit of a dark side. Her commentary on Booker's actions is quite thought-provoking.Plot-I had to sit and think about it for a while. The only thing that got "rekt" here was my brain. A few of the concepts I latched onto quite easily, but I quickly dove into the trippy♥♥♥♥♥ending, and things became a lot more fuzzy. The amount of brain power it took to write and create such a great plot is Matrix-level impressive.Allusions/Commentary-The game takes on faith in a very interesting way. If anyone actually read those transition cards that the game shows with Booker's writing on loading screens, one of them mentions the power of peoples' beliefs, which is portrayed in a very amusing way in the game. Essentially, BioShock Infinite demonstrates that faith is a tool that can be used for good or for evil. I've read some reviews calling this game racist, and that is downright disappointing. Simply because a game portrays a society that supports racism does not mean it is a "racist game." That would be like calling George Orwell's "1984" a book that glorifies authoritarianism. Anyone who calls this game racist has blatantly misunderstood most of its messages. Racism is not glorified in any way, nor is religious extremism or murder. As for the clever references, props to 2K for all of their work! In fact, when  Elizabeth opens that tear to Paris, you can see the movie advertisement says "Revanche du Jedi." Does that suggest some kind of alternate universe where George Lucas made Jedis the villains of the Star wars Saga? Someone give me an answer in the comments.  All in all, Infinite is somewhat of a fairy tale for adults; a bit of a cross between Inception and Rapunzel. BioShock Infinite is quite possibly the most amazing game I have ever played. So, what are you waiting for? Buy it, beat it, and talk to me about it! Maybe we can swap theories sometime over a flask of Vigor.
