												I have played a good amount of first person shooters over the past couple of years and I can, without a doubt, say that this is my favorite. World: No game I have ever played feels as alive as this one. As soon as you reach Columbia you can tell it's a living, breathing, world. You can see pedestrians living their lives as if nothing will ever change. You can hear the conversations of people who are talking about the world around them. And the world of Columbia is beautiful, it's filled with color, music and life. Every couple of minutes there is a sight worthy of being put in a picture frame and hung up. World: 10/10Graphics: The world complements the visuals of the game itself. The graphics in this game aren't exactly "realistic" but they are beautiful in an artistic way. There are some very small areas that don't look too great though, such as the apples in a basket, which are just a flat texture. If you can max out this game I highly recommend you do, it will make your experience with this game even better. Graphics: 9.8/10Sound: Bioshock infinite chooses great sound to go with most situations. Whenever you get into a fight intense music is played to go along with it. If you cut off or shoot off an enemy's head or brutally murder an enemy it plays a sharp sound as if to say, "That’s ♥♥♥♥ed up." In the background you can hear music that really helps capture the 1900 feelling. The sound while just walking around or firing a weapon is also great. Sound 10/10.Gameplay: Most of the gameplay consists of fighting enemies. Although that doesn't sound too great, the game implements it in a way that is fun and refreshing compared to other shooters. You can ride on skylines and fight and the same time, making fighting very fast paced. While fighting, Elizabeth can help by throwing you some supplies such as ammo and health packs. This makes Elizabeth helpful and not annoying to have around. Gameplay 9.5/10Story: There is a huge mindf**k at the end and one day you will finally understand it… I’m sorry I didn’t explain much, the story is best experienced knowing nothing going in. Story: 10/10 This game permanently changed what I thought a video game could be. If I had to give it an overall rating I’d say 10/10. This isn’t just a videogame, this is a work of art.   BUY IT NOW!!! Average from 5 criteria: 9.86

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												As you are probably aware 'Bioshock infinite' is part of the contemporary prequel fad. Therefore, like Deux EX: HR or Serious Sam: BFE it takes place before the events of the original game. Instead of being in Rapture, an underwater utopia gone wrong, you are up in the air, in the city of Columbia. A totally different environment from the dark claustrophobic post-apocaliptic feel of the original games. The idea is most welcome, having a huge open and sunny playground with skylines connecting different floating platforms sure sounds like fun. But ultimately the strategy element of the original games (using the elements of each room to your advantage) gives place to more classic arcade action battles and the enemies are less imaginative. You get to see the city shining and falling apart as you progress through the game and although it has great moments, the dissonance and dark humor are less present than before. If the combat and actual set pieces are definetly aimed at a wider audience, the convoluted storyline is more niche oriented and ambitious. The uprising of the masses and the multiverse deliver many twists that other FPS wouldn't. All in all a solid 20 hours of gameplay, a fun ride despite the lack of real challenges even in hard mode (I have yet to test 1999 mode). The final product seems a bit rushed to actually call it a masterpiece but it's a worthy addition to the series and I bet the DLC's in Rapture are grand!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Out of the two Bioshock games, Infinite has over thrown over the original Bioshock just by the skin of its teeth.(Yes I said two. That God awful game called Bioshock 2 does not count.) The thing that caught my attention immediately was the atmosphere and look of Infinite. It was an alien to the series, not just because it wasn't under water anymore but with the colors, the atmosphere and THE COLORS. The city of Rapture had a feeling of isolation and despair to its world. It had the colors of a dying rainbow, dont get me wrong I loved that about it. I thought that was a key feature for the series, but I was wrong. Columbia was a "happier" place to be in. It was bright, colorful and the old American feel to it was outstanding as well. Columbia was just a better world to roam around than Rapture. Because it has that open feel to it that the tubes of Rapture failed to  give, thus I found myself covering every inch of the world. A big factor I noticed in Infinite Vigors (Plasmids in the old Bioshock) was not an actual highlight to the story. There is no build up to it you just literally pick it up and drink it. That was an odd thing for me. Enough about the world time for the characters.Bioshock Infinte produced a handful of memorable character compared to the first one. Your character Booker Dewitt actually talks often so it just gives him more character than just another generic piece of meat that you control. He is further highlighted by his sidekick whom I think is the star of the game. Elizabeth the girl nextdoor type or rather the girl next to a cage(I laughed at my joke more than I should.). She's smart and has a lovely feel. It's an odd feeling to see someone so happy in a game that you actually feel happy for them. Play the game and you'll know what I mean. Sadly her character development was altered faster than expected maybe it was because of the things that happening in the story. I hoped for more dialogue between Dewitt and Elizabeth because it was charming and funny how they spoke to each other. The Lutece siblings were terrific. They added a depth to the pool of characters in the game. Maybe because they were british? A game is only as good as its gameplay and Infinite's gameplay is what won me over. The added sky line feature was a major touch to it. It just adds that momentum feel to it, rather than just running around, it different I can tell you that. The Vigors available in the game worked perfectly together and was fun to think of new combos that would destroy your enemies. Weapons were abundant but I just used 3-4. There is no more hacking in the game which for was a good thing. I was never really a fan of that. Now you just have to find lockpicks for Elizabeth to use. Oh and Elizabeth is an amazing sidekick. she is actually useful. The game is now a "loot fest" as you can pick up a lot of things for your health, vigor and ammo. You dont have health kits anymore you need to pick up a lot of things to regenerate your health(Which I like). The enemies are'nt that memorable because they're just normal people so you'll probably miss the good old splicers. It's still a solid FPS game. My finaly Verdict is that Bioshock is a soild 9/10 game. Now I say 8 because the story is an odd one. Not that I dont get it I played the game twice just to see that I actually got it being that Im an idiot. Sadly it feels that it tried so hard to shove the story down your throat. The last 25 minutes of the game is where all of it actually makes sense rather than just spread the story through out the game so that player would slowly "decode" it and form their own theories as they are playing the game so that the plot twist would have been a bigger shocker. Saddly it was not as good as the first Bioshock. It had way to much sub-plots that makes you lose sight of the main story. A shame really, if only the plots intertwined as good as I hoped them to be. non the less its a good game I recommend you buying it. Just wait for sales though I noticed that this game is almost free when it goes on sale so keep that in mind. or just buy the trilogy the down side is you'll get Bioshock 2. (Sorry for some of my grammar this is my first review and English is not my mother tounge.)

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend BioShock Infinite then skip to Results and read from there.Irrational Games takes what 2K started did and pushes it above and beyond reality. One cannot come to words for how to describe BioShock Infinite as there are no words that possibly capture its essence. Story:As you sit in your little office you are given an offer, one that will allow you to be free of all that you owe. Two people, a man and a woman, provide you with an ultimatum with you accept. You are given the opportunity to go to a world in the clouds and retrieve a girl. As you push through your mission you will learn more about yourself than you ever wanted to know. Campaign:BioShock Infinite campaign is of decent length. Depending on the difficulty you chose and your play-style you get through this game from anywhere between 10-16 hours. I would recommend taking your time as this game is more about the story than the gameplay and missing the smallest element can result in a completely different understanding. The campaign is divvied up across 40-chapters, all varying in length, some take only a minute, while others you’ll be wondering for at-least an hour. An interesting element in Infinite is that almost all of the cinematics involve player interaction. You control basic camera elements, as well as in some scenes interaction with the environment. This provides a more immersive campaign than traditional games. Gameplay:BioShock Infinite does away with tonics, ADAM, and limited weapon upgrades. Instead of Plasmids you use Vigors, which are essentially the same thing with a different name. The only currency in the game is Silver Eagles, most likely based on the US Silver Dollar and Half-Dollar. You can use this money to buy weapon upgrades, Vigor upgrades, and ammo/health/salts. Unlike in the first two you no longer need to acquire Adam to get Vigor upgrades, which means you can customize your gameplay based on what you plan to use more. I was weapon intensive so I spent all my cash on weapon upgrades, and only upgraded on Vigor for the achievement. You also don’t buy Vigors instead you unlock them for free throughout the campaign which means you will have every single one by the end of the game. There are 14-weapons that you will find throughout the campaign: Sky-Hook, Broadsider Pistol, China Boom Shotgun, Triple R Machine Gun, Huntsman Carbine, Bird’s Eye Sniper Rifle, Paddywhacker Hand Cannon, Peppermill Crank Gun, Pig Flak Volley Gun, Heater, Burstgun, Repeater, and Hail Fire. So you won’t feel limited in this game by your weapon choice, as you have more than you can ever imagine. Although despite all these choices you can only ever carry two-weapons at one time. So you will more than likely stick to what you like, as you may not get it back for a while if you let it go. A new feature to the series is Infusions; infusions are vials found throughout the campaign that allow you to increase your health, shield, or salts (mana). Depending on your play-style you may find more or less of these throughout the campaign, but you will probably not find them all. Some are in secret areas, while others are right infront of your very eyes. Infusions allow you to customize yourself without limiting your capital.Results:BioShock Infinite is an amazingly beautiful game that is aweing and terrifying at the same time. Like all BioShocks you will enter confused and cautious, but as the game unfolds you will never want to put it down. The story is beautiful, the gameplay is fantastic, the music is breathtaking, and the environment is inspirational. As you play you will learn more about yourself that you can imagine through even the simplest choices, heads or tails?Pros:+Amazing story, amazing doesn’t even breach how brilliant it is.+Beautiful environment, you will stand there just to look at how beautiful the architecture is, how elegant the people are, how clean the world is.+Amazing music, the music is simple but rather still brings much depth to the game. Even the combat music draws shivers up your spine.+Great graphics engine, as well as a fantastic optimization tool. +Awesome boss battles, which keep you on your toesCons:-The enemies are kind of lacking (Most of them are the same enemy with a different gun)-The combat AI is rather limited, I found myself taking advantage of how stupid they were on many occasions.-They got rid of the manual saves (if you have a busy schedule you sometimes don’t have time to find a checkpoint).

content:
Posted: February 4, 2016
												YES!!!! This was how Bioshock 1 &2 should have played!This game was fantastic! It was gorgeous as far as graphics are concerned, and it played smoother than any game i've gotten on steam. honestly, my compter is a bit of a potato by today's standars but aside from a small handful of bugs i didn't have any problems that turned me away from the game, or ruined the fun.The atmosphere is very different from the first two. It's still a looter shooter of course, but it REWARDS you for exploring and explore you will! The immersion, especially in the first few parts, is what gaming is all about. It isn't a horror game like you might consider the first two. In Fact, save for a desperate scramble to reconnect the plot to the series in the end like a high school freshman half assing a paper rambling off topic from his thesis a half an hour before class(Not that i'd know... cough*), it has nothing to do with the first two. It's creepy in some parts, but the dark and gritty horror environments generated in the first two just weren't implemented.The combat is SO MUCH SMOOTHER. There are actual stagger mechanics, and the guns don't feel like pea shooters. While there's still potential for difficulty, when you pick up a mini gun... YOU HAVE A MINIGUN. It makes heads explode like watermelons and it's too satisfying. The melee finishing moves are grisly, and add a little more fluidity than just beating splicers over the head with a drill. Upgrades come timely, and seem to be at apropriate costs and scales. You feel rewarded for saving up all those pennis you scavenged for and put into your carbine.The plot.... I can't defend.It started out wonderful, and you're just excited to be playing and on an adventure. Save the damsel in distress, escape and save the day after shooting out like a bandit. BUT that Hottie you and SHOULD be sipping champagne with in paris at the end turns out to be your daughter. And she drowns you. The end. It seems that bioshock does well with plot, UNTIL they try and make it deep. It only turns out convoluded, and in the end you're absolutely baffled at the uselessness of your ending. There are some major holes, and the "rippin and the tearin!" time travel/alternate reality thing. If bioshock makes another game, im going to make sure they dont kill you off yet AGAIN by your own daughter before i buy it. If plot is super important to you, you'll be disappointed.Got this game for 3 dolars in a bundle and i have to say, it was worth the cost of the bundle and made up for bioshock 1 and 2. I'll definitely play this through again, though the plot is absolutely annoying.Steam issues:I had virtually none with this game, which i could only kindd of scratch my head at. This is by far the most demanding game ive played as far as requirements go and i didnt half a tenth of the issues i normally get from games on steam, and were even present in the first two older games.i had a blast, and i think if you enjoy first person shooters and immersive experiences and SMOOTH GAMEPLAY, you wont be disappointed you bought this, but ecstatic.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												I've always been particularly into dystopias, and I recently learned what a classy example of one Bioshock franchise is.The first game was purely awesome, though it did have some gameplay lacks and some incompleteness but the story and setting were totally deep and stunning.So, the same is with Bioshock Infinite. Its story, setting, art design (you bet!) left me absolutely marvelled. I mean, in what other game could you find quantum mechanics as the basis for the whole plot? This game made me seriously interested in this science and I actually went a bit crazy already dwelling on what we really are, how we are and "why do you ask "what", when the delicious question is "when"? The characters are also brilliant (Fink, Luteces, Slate) and I am certainly not the only one who fell in love with Elizabeth.But when it comes to gameplay, this game has some issues. For instance, the system of Vigors in my opinion is far from perfect. Having completed the game on PS3, I found with regret that some vigors I simply didn't need (that despite I was playing with gamepad without aim assist, so I was forced to use Vigors creatively). It is even worse with weapons, as many of them are virtually useless and would rather get you yourself killed than your enemies, and even upgrades are a slack argument for carrying them, especially as you can carry two pieces only, which I think is rather good and challenging. Besides, the whole gameplay could be less linear and repetitious. They could put those mechanical horses to use somehow, or add telekinesis, like in the first game. But no. Enjoy the great story between call-of-duty style shoot-outs with electromagnetic field in place of regenerating health. But as I have already stated, the story is so absolutely fantastic and overwhelming that I, for one, intend to play it over and over again countless number of times, discovering new details and building new theories about what actually is behind all of these ideas.Thank you, Ken levine. A must-have masterpiece, still there is nothing perfect.

												This will be a rare instance that I brand something my 'favorite'.  NO spoilers. TL;DR at the bottom. This story will break your brain, and make you cry. The writing in this game is phenomenal to a point that if you have never played this game before, you are doing yourself a discredit. Don't look it up, don't watch some autaud play it on youtube, just play it through for yourself. I personally promise you that it lives to all the hype and accolades it received when it came out in 2013. I haven't loved, like actually feel fuzzy for a game, a game since the original Bioshock (2 was ok). This being my second play through (first played on PS3) and the -SPOILER- still had a big impact on me. The world is gorgeous, and fun to explore, and each area feels distinct even though it's all in one big city. The set pieces are amazing, and I found myself just staring at stuff in game, admiring the super vibrant decor, posters, etc. Everything looks and feels alive. Visually and audibly, it's simply amazing. have I said that already? It's amazing.The core game play while fun and engaging, at points can border on tedium (it IS an fps after all). There aren't many enemy types, and for the most part are just squishy humans. Save for the 'Handymen', and the steampunk nightmare fuel that are the 'Patriots'. Luckily you get those nifty Vigors to spice things up. By that I mean, Setting dudes on fire. Or sending crows to peck their eyes out. Or any number of combinations you find more amusing. My personal favorite is launching people off the side and wondering if they landed in some poor NPCs living room, 20,000 feet below. ...heh.While the main purpose of re-buying the game was for the DLC campaigns, which I didn't have on PS3. I have yet to complete them yet so I wont get into them here. I just know that going back to Rapture is gonna be, and I quote, 'SIIIIIIIICK!' 1999 mode is also something I never really played, so I'll have to make a point to do so.TL;DRThis is the best game I've personally ever played. And I play a lot of f**king games, bro. As it stands nearly 3 years after it's initial release, it still has enough power to put me in existential crisis. Also Elizabeth is hot, and I feel terrible for saying that, all things considered....

Posted: July 28, 2013
												Bioshock Infinite is the BEST first person shooter I have played in quite a while.  Gameplay is super fluid and never ceases to make you feel powerful.  Combat really is comprised of four different facets. Gunplay which is interesting on its own and has many different weapons to try out. Vigors (a return of plasmid like powers from the first game) that give you incredible powers that let you be more creative with your approach on combat and the enviroment. Skyhooks (the most awesome gameplay addition in my opinion) allow you to move through a battle with ease and strike down foes from above. Lastly, are Elizabeths powers to create tears which open up things like turrets, hooks, cover, or many other items or combat options which can help change the tide of a battle.  These main facets to gameplay make the game feel fresh and fun.  Everytime you aproach a group of bad guys gives you a new opportunity to experiment with the myriad of options to take out your foes.The thing of course that makes Infinite interesting is its world and story.  Columbia is a very interesting place to visit with many beautiful views and interesting characters all around.  Booker and Elizabeth have a very interesting connection ,not as deep as Joel and Ellie in The Last of Us per se ,but still great enough to keep the story interesting.Bioshock Infinite is one of those games that will be remembered for quite a while just like the first Bioshock. It's definentley a great game to close out this generation along with The Last of Us and GTAV. Bioshock Infintite 9.7/10

												My personal game of the year, maybe my favorite game this generation. Amazing story, probably the best ever told in videogames, paced perfectly with interesting characters that interact in ways that tend to feel more genuine than most games. Drew Holems and Ken Levine wrote a masterpiece here, fleshed out by flawless performances from Troy Baker and Courtney Draper, and bolstered by often times frantic, highly kenetic, chaotic combat that plays like no other first person shooter.What you have here are genuinely intimidating heavy hitter boss fights, especially on the higher dificulty settings. content:
Posted: September 15, 2015
												Out of the two Bioshock games, Infinite has over thrown over the original Bioshock just by the skin of its teeth.(Yes I said two. That God awful game called Bioshock 2 does not count.) The thing that caught my attention immediately was the atmosphere and look of Infinite. It was an alien to the series, not just because it wasn't under water anymore but with the colors, the atmosphere and THE COLORS. The city of Rapture had a feeling of isolation and despair to its world. It had the colors of a dying rainbow, dont get me wrong I loved that about it. I thought that was a key feature for the series, but I was wrong. Columbia was a "happier" place to be in. It was bright, colorful and the old American feel to it was outstanding as well. Columbia was just a better world to roam around than Rapture. Because it has that open feel to it that the tubes of Rapture failed to  give, thus I found myself covering every inch of the world. A big factor I noticed in Infinite Vigors (Plasmids in the old Bioshock) was not an actual highlight to the story. There is no build up to it you just literally pick it up and drink it. That was an odd thing for me. Enough about the world time for the characters.Bioshock Infinte produced a handful of memorable character compared to the first one. Your character Booker Dewitt actually talks often so it just gives him more character than just another generic piece of meat that you control. He is further highlighted by his sidekick whom I think is the star of the game. Elizabeth the girl nextdoor type or rather the girl next to a cage(I laughed at my joke more than I should.). She's smart and has a lovely feel. It's an odd feeling to see someone so happy in a game that you actually feel happy for them. Play the game and you'll know what I mean. Sadly her character development was altered faster than expected maybe it was because of the things that happening in the story. I hoped for more dialogue between Dewitt and Elizabeth because it was charming and funny how they spoke to each other. The Lutece siblings were terrific. They added a depth to the pool of characters in the game. Maybe because they were british? A game is only as good as its gameplay and Infinite's gameplay is what won me over. The added sky line feature was a major touch to it. It just adds that momentum feel to it, rather than just running around, it different I can tell you that. The Vigors available in the game worked perfectly together and was fun to think of new combos that would destroy your enemies. Weapons were abundant but I just used 3-4. There is no more hacking in the game which for was a good thing. I was never really a fan of that. Now you just have to find lockpicks for Elizabeth to use. Oh and Elizabeth is an amazing sidekick. she is actually useful. The game is now a "loot fest" as you can pick up a lot of things for your health, vigor and ammo. You dont have health kits anymore you need to pick up a lot of things to regenerate your health(Which I like). The enemies are'nt that memorable because they're just normal people so you'll probably miss the good old splicers. It's still a solid FPS game. My finaly Verdict is that Bioshock is a soild 9/10 game. Now I say 8 because the story is an odd one. Not that I dont get it I played the game twice just to see that I actually got it being that Im an idiot. Sadly it feels that it tried so hard to shove the story down your throat. The last 25 minutes of the game is where all of it actually makes sense rather than just spread the story through out the game so that player would slowly "decode" it and form their own theories as they are playing the game so that the plot twist would have been a bigger shocker. Saddly it was not as good as the first Bioshock. It had way to much sub-plots that makes you lose sight of the main story. A shame really, if only the plots intertwined as good as I hoped them to be. non the less its a good game I recommend you buying it. Just wait for sales though I noticed that this game is almost free when it goes on sale so keep that in mind. or just buy the trilogy the down side is you'll get Bioshock 2. (Sorry for some of my grammar this is my first review and English is not my mother tounge.)

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
This is a long review so if you just want a brief summary of why I recommend BioShock Infinite then skip to Results and read from there.Irrational Games takes what 2K started did and pushes it above and beyond reality. One cannot come to words for how to describe BioShock Infinite as there are no words that possibly capture its essence. Story:As you sit in your little office you are given an offer, one that will allow you to be free of all that you owe. Two people, a man and a woman, provide you with an ultimatum with you accept. You are given the opportunity to go to a world in the clouds and retrieve a girl. As you push through your mission you will learn more about yourself than you ever wanted to know. Campaign:BioShock Infinite campaign is of decent length. Depending on the difficulty you chose and your play-style you get through this game from anywhere between 10-16 hours. I would recommend taking your time as this game is more about the story than the gameplay and missing the smallest element can result in a completely different understanding. The campaign is divvied up across 40-chapters, all varying in length, some take only a minute, while others you’ll be wondering for at-least an hour. An interesting element in Infinite is that almost all of the cinematics involve player interaction. You control basic camera elements, as well as in some scenes interaction with the environment. This provides a more immersive campaign than traditional games. Gameplay:BioShock Infinite does away with tonics, ADAM, and limited weapon upgrades. Instead of Plasmids you use Vigors, which are essentially the same thing with a different name. The only currency in the game is Silver Eagles, most likely based on the US Silver Dollar and Half-Dollar. You can use this money to buy weapon upgrades, Vigor upgrades, and ammo/health/salts. Unlike in the first two you no longer need to acquire Adam to get Vigor upgrades, which means you can customize your gameplay based on what you plan to use more. I was weapon intensive so I spent all my cash on weapon upgrades, and only upgraded on Vigor for the achievement. You also don’t buy Vigors instead you unlock them for free throughout the campaign which means you will have every single one by the end of the game. There are 14-weapons that you will find throughout the campaign: Sky-Hook, Broadsider Pistol, China Boom Shotgun, Triple R Machine Gun, Huntsman Carbine, Bird’s Eye Sniper Rifle, Paddywhacker Hand Cannon, Peppermill Crank Gun, Pig Flak Volley Gun, Heater, Burstgun, Repeater, and Hail Fire. So you won’t feel limited in this game by your weapon choice, as you have more than you can ever imagine. Although despite all these choices you can only ever carry two-weapons at one time. So you will more than likely stick to what you like, as you may not get it back for a while if you let it go. A new feature to the series is Infusions; infusions are vials found throughout the campaign that allow you to increase your health, shield, or salts (mana). Depending on your play-style you may find more or less of these throughout the campaign, but you will probably not find them all. Some are in secret areas, while others are right infront of your very eyes. Infusions allow you to customize yourself without limiting your capital.Results:BioShock Infinite is an amazingly beautiful game that is aweing and terrifying at the same time. Like all BioShocks you will enter confused and cautious, but as the game unfolds you will never want to put it down. The story is beautiful, the gameplay is fantastic, the music is breathtaking, and the environment is inspirational. As you play you will learn more about yourself that you can imagine through even the simplest choices, heads or tails?Pros:+Amazing story, amazing doesn’t even breach how brilliant it is.+Beautiful environment, you will stand there just to look at how beautiful the architecture is, how elegant the people are, how clean the world is.+Amazing music, the music is simple but rather still brings much depth to the game. Even the combat music draws shivers up your spine.+Great graphics engine, as well as a fantastic optimization tool. +Awesome boss battles, which keep you on your toesCons:-The enemies are kind of lacking (Most of them are the same enemy with a different gun)-The combat AI is rather limited, I found myself taking advantage of how stupid they were on many occasions.-They got rid of the manual saves (if you have a busy schedule you sometimes don’t have time to find a checkpoint).

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
												It’s old, it’s been covered, the plot has been spoiled and the DLC produced, yet somehow I never got caught in the media blaze that was hailing Bioshock Infinite for being one of the best narratives in gaming. In fact, I actually managed to play it completely blind well over two years after it’s release in 2013. So here’s my verdict for this once near-idolized FPS RPG: Eh it’s a pretty good game I guess.I remember the ravings and the discussions over just how mind blowing the story was and how everyone just melted into an ooze of wonder when they hit the big plot twist, but it was just good. I think whoever wrote the story did a great job and I hope they were well commended for it, but the game on the whole was nothing revolutionary. The formula was refined but essentially handled like the other BioShock titles. The gunplay wasn’t weak but certainly didn’t carry much weight. The vigors even lacked depth; I found myself only ever really using the shock/fireball/charm vigors, and I only fired the shield and tentacle one just to say I tried. If there is anything to praise about BioShock Infinite, it’s Elizabeth. No not because her “story is so fantastic” and the narrative she delivers is “mind-bending”. Honestly, she could have had next to no involvement in the plot and I would have still been blown away simply for the fact that I did not hate every single action she took. I have not seen an AI companion in a game be this not-terrible since Half Life. Every game that ever wants to do AI companions or even escort missions needs to take a good hard look at how Elizabeth behaves both in and out of combat. She never gets stuck, never halts progression, never runs into a hail of bullets to find cover behind a nearby piece of paper, doesn’t require you to hold her hand through every single encounter and in fact reliably keeps you in relatively good shape during combat by tossing you ammo, health and salts.BioShock Infinite is alright, well worth picking it up on sale for 10 or 15 bucks, but in my mind the most amazing thing about it is that someone finally made an AI companion that wasn’t the absolute worst thing on the face of the earth.

												Os gráficos e o gameplay são muito bons, mas onde o jogo realmente brilha é em sua história. É muito difícil não sentir algum tipo de empatia por Elizabeth durante o jogo. A cidade de Columbia é belissíma, apesar de não possuir o mesmo impacto que Rapture tinha nos dois primeiros jogos, e há uma boa variedade de inimigos pra derrotar com seus plasmids. O sistema de vida é uma mistura do clássico healthpack misturado com o autoheal de uma forma que dá certo. A movimentacão flui muito bem apesar de ocasionais travadas quando se pula do chão para as skylines do jogo, o que pode ser especialmente frustrante em situações de combate.As DLCs são excelente, sendo basicamente jogos completamente novos, com uma nova história e um gameplay diferenciado da campanha principal, mais voltado para o stealth, o que pode ser meio estranho no começo, mas a adaptação se dá rapidamente. Vale a pena comentar também como a DLC serviu para amarrar a história do primeiro Bioshock com esse de uma forma interessante ( ainda que um tanto forçada) enquanto concluia o arco de Elizabeth e Booker.

content:
Posted: March 23, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is firstly a first person shooter, and secondly an entry in the Bioshock series. This makes the game feel different from previous titles in  the series, in both positive and negative ways. It has a similar feel to it aesthetic-wise, there are various audio logs in the game, you go from place to place while given various directives, and the whole thing is rather linear. You are accompanied through most of the game with your companinon Elizabeth, who thankfully cannot be damaged by enemies, or the game's difficulty would be (pardon the pun) Infintely harder. The story of the game is  questionable however, it is not difficult to understand for the most part, except the last part of the game which leaves me wondering "what the heck just happened?" I was shocked when I beat this game not because I was particularly blown away, but it was a sense of anger instead. I just went through all that to be given such a dissatistfying ending. I felt cheated. I probably wouldn't playthrough the game again, but it was still a half decent experience to go through. The environments and the overall feel of the game is very enjoyable, and the new sky combat which the game boasts is very fun and fast, through on ground combat is nothing short of the typical first person shooter action. I have not played the DLC's yet, nor do I intend to, as my values dictate that DLC are something to be avoided if at all possible.I'd recommend this game if you are a fan of first person shooters, and if you played the other bioshock games you might have a decent time, but find yourself wishing that your were playing Bioshock 1 again.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2013
												Bioshock Infinite is the BEST first person shooter I have played in quite a while.  Gameplay is super fluid and never ceases to make you feel powerful.  Combat really is comprised of four different facets. Gunplay which is interesting on its own and has many different weapons to try out. Vigors (a return of plasmid like powers from the first game) that give you incredible powers that let you be more creative with your approach on combat and the enviroment. Skyhooks (the most awesome gameplay addition in my opinion) allow you to move through a battle with ease and strike down foes from above. Lastly, are Elizabeths powers to create tears which open up things like turrets, hooks, cover, or many other items or combat options which can help change the tide of a battle.  These main facets to gameplay make the game feel fresh and fun.  Everytime you aproach a group of bad guys gives you a new opportunity to experiment with the myriad of options to take out your foes.The thing of course that makes Infinite interesting is its world and story.  Columbia is a very interesting place to visit with many beautiful views and interesting characters all around.  Booker and Elizabeth have a very interesting connection ,not as deep as Joel and Ellie in The Last of Us per se ,but still great enough to keep the story interesting.Bioshock Infinite is one of those games that will be remembered for quite a while just like the first Bioshock. It's definentley a great game to close out this generation along with The Last of Us and GTAV. Bioshock Infintite 9.7/10

												I can proudly say that this is the best game that I have in my library and I will be very surprised if I find something that I love more. Bioshock Infinite, the sequal of the hit 2008 game Bioshock (and no I don't count Bioshock 2 because of obviouse reasons), is a thrilling game that runs buttery smooth and offers an experience like no other, allowing the player to gun down enemies by the boat-load all the while flying through the sky via an easy-to-use grapple system (it involves a track and a thing on your arm that doubles as a tool and a weapon).Not only does the game look and play great, the charaters you meet along the way are very engaging and it'll be a long time before I forget any of them, especially an entertaining pair of ginger scientists. But most importantly, you will never grow tired of your companion Elizabeth, who will always provide you with intriguing dialogue and the unique ability of picking up useful items and throwing them to you, a mechanic that has saved my♥♥♥♥♥more than once.On the whole, this is a game that you need to play at least once in your life. With excellent writing, setting, characters and gameplay, Bioshock Infinite is deffinatly a game that leaves you satisfied yet perplexed when you see the ending credits roll.

												I love this game, it has it all really in terms of single player; Story, interesting characters, unique interesting guns, acrobats, and to me it is far better than Bioshock 2, which I found to be slow and clumsy in control in comparison to the original Bioshock. Posted: August 18, 2014
												One of the most influential and satisfying experiences I have had in a game to date. I consider myself a big fan of the Bioshock series, and Infinite did not dissapoint or seem to water down my expectations and anticipation for the game. It really is the greatest. Sure, there are its points of contention that result in controversy, the inventory system and the excess amount of combat, I hear about the most. However, the lack of excessive cinematics and promotion of great atmospheric detail give this game a life of its own, as the surroundings certainly tell a great deal of the story itself. You play as Booker DeWitt, a man who- well, you should just try it out for yourself, the story gets a bit complex.If you look for a game with intense atmosphere, a compelling and dominant storyline, with a dash of nostalgia, Bioshock Infinite is a great buy.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Bioshock Infinite is visually different from its predecessors, full of bright colors with considerably less water. Even though it's not a direct sequel to other Bioshocks, it's still somehow the same and has that particular "Bioshock" feel. The core mechanics remain the same, and even players who have never played any FPS games should be able to enjoy this. The stunning design of the entire game just took my breath away. The storyline is simply fantastic (I would not expect anything less from this franchise) and truly worth experiencing. Bioshock Infinite's take on religion, politics, science, and history in general will blow your mind. I expected a lot from this game. It delivered so much more. Also, Elizabeth rocks. 9,5/10.Edit: I finally bought the Season Pass and it was worth every penny. The DLCs are simply fantastic, they further the story of the entire Bioshock series (not just Bioshock Infinite) and really bring back some of the old Bioshock vibe, along with your favorite characters. A perfect ending to a perfect game.

												Bioshock Infinite is a definitive graphical improvement when compared to its predecessors, a game whose story its not passed in Rapture but rather in another city, a flying one by the name of Columbia.The combat system is slighty improved, the gameplay keeps the basics but adds new elements for the player to interact and also new enemies and a brand new storyline which can be very confusing at times.All in all, i had a great experience exploring every little spot of the map looking for all the recordings and listening to every bit of info that i could get my hands on. Booker and Elizabeth were interesting main characters with good enough villains to back them up. Its a good buy if you have the money for it.8,5/10. If you are a fan of the Bioshock series, you should get this game and dont listen to the negative reviews, play it for yourself and enjoy the experience.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Might as well call the game "Micheal Bay's generic video game Infinite" as you just run around like a jackass killing everyone in sight with little to no story telling or character development.I personally find this the most over rated game of the year. Combat is far from fun with 40% of the game being a rail shooter with a few fetch quests & “puzzles”, however, calling them “puzzles” is a far stretch as a 3 year old could figure them out. The other 60% of the game is pressing f (pick-up/grab key) on everything that glows thanks to small ammo pool for each weapon.Combat is so basic and boring you can literally head shot everyone with out popping your shields and boss fights are the same thing over and over again regardless of the difficulty. Later in the game enemies basically become bullet sponges and running out of ammo is not due to poor aim or bad decision making but more so that the game is forcing you to pick-up random weapons for no reason to acquire more ammo and add some depth to the combat.Characters are dull with no depth and the game aims to tackle a lot of “hot topics” like religion, slavery, capitalism, revolution, etc... making it feel very pretensions while expressing nothing of importance. The story is so childish you could basically play the whole game with out knowing what's going on and understand everything at the end.I find it hard to really give this game a positive score however the gorgeous environment & character models does make the game a joy to look at, but this quickly becomes over looked as the entire game's environments are the same and nothing encourages you to look for none traditional story telling within the environments.I give BioShock Infinite a 6/10 and that's pushing it; Story, combat & characters leave much to be desired but the game runs well with no bugs/glitches, the game feels like a solid PC port from console and the environments are amazing making it hard to give it anything below 6/10 (as I consider games under 5/10 broken and unplayable).Should you play BioShock? No.“Pro” Tip:Carbine + Machine Gun + Electric Salt = Cruise control

												This game is a miracle. From the moment you see the Columbia for the first time, you will feel what imagination is capable of. The moment you see the Columbia in all it's glory, the moment you hear the piano strings, game will make you fall in love with  it. You will feel like a little boy who comes to an amusement park for the first time in his life. The people, the buildings, the atmosphere will feel so peaceful, you'll be in a mood where you'd just choose to roleplay in Columbia instead of shooting people. But you know what you gotta do, you gotta kill. Vigors are good enough for it and weapon carry limit doesn't ruin your fun. Only bad thing about weapons is that they don't have interesting upgrades like magnetic drill upgrade in Bioshock 2. The items you find in the game doesn't differ much from each other and a bit useless. Graphics can be messed up from time to time but in general they can be described with these two words:pure awesomeness. Story is mindblowing, but you won't probably notice this until the very ending of game. If you ask about the length, it's much better that other shooter games in these days.(You can complete the game in about 13-15 hours) It's highly replayable with it's 1999 difficulty mode which unlocks when you enter a cheat code or finish the game. That's all I gotta say, buy it and you won't regret   neither forget it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												BioShock Infinite could make you feel uncomfortable. If you adhere to religious faith, or celebrate American idealism, this game may invite introspection or even anger. BioShock Infinite isn't afraid to magnify the way religious and racial extremism inform our culture and change lives. It isn't afraid to depict a less-than-holy trinity diseased by power, deception, and manipulation. As the story circles back on itself, you're left wondering whether redemption cleanses us of our atrocities, or simply invites us to commit greater ones. Once the finale comes, you will want to play again, watching each event and image through the lens of information you can never un-know. BioShock Infinite is more than just a quality game: it's an important one.

Plus, BioShock Infinite's story is VERY short.  Not saying I want tedious bits just to kill time, but somehow this short game still had those parts anyway.  What was the deal with this game allegedly having "Hollywood-level" writing?  Is that supposed to be a positive thing?The gameplay is nearly identical to BioShock 2, save for it's more dumbed down and includes two extra forced mechanics that are rarely helpful/needed (rifts and skyhook if you need to know).  It isn't like I expect a completely different formula for a sequel, but I also don't expect practically the same.  The corridor shooter is getting stale.  What's even sadder is Doom has more enemy variety than this game.The graphics and soundtrack are cool, but if I wanted to look at pretty pictures and listen to good music I would just do that.  This is a non-point.I seriously felt like I was robbed for buying this game when it came out.  There is no replayability save for an extra difficulty unlocked after beating the game once and the overpriced DLC (which, believe me, is overpriced for what it is).  Rent this game for console or just wait for when Steam allows friends to lend it to you.  It is a big waste of money to buy.  I'm just glad I got RNGCOM: Enemy Unknown through Steam's pre-order rewards.Alternatively, check out the System Shock series.B-B-B-B-B-B-B-BAZINGA

content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												It's a game about infinite possibilities and how everything really is of no consequence. Your enjoyment of this game will hinge largely on your ability to suspend your disbelieve and to not think too much about the mechanics or interactions of/with the game world. Hopefully you also have a very strong believe that “it’s about the journey, not the destination” (which I can’t explain further because of spoilers). This game wants you to think about its ending and the impactions ONLY, and not too much about the game itself.The gameplay is fairly average, competent but not engaging. Gunplay feels very limited despite the large selection of guns due to the player’s inability to hold more than 2 guns at a time and limited resources mean that you’ll only get to upgrade certain weapons. The fun of using vigors wear thin after a while and combat just becomes a chore as you mow down waves of enemies to get to the next plot point. The Skylines are the only fun mechanic in the game but isn’t prevalent enough to make a significant difference to the overall combat experience. Overall, gameplay doesn’t feel quite satisfying enough to justify a recommendation. It’s not terrible, but since combat is the only gameplay mechanic other than savaging for resources, its mediocrity is pretty detrimental to the overall experience of the game.The story is smart and complex but suffers from pacing issues. Most of the plot bookends the game, sandwiching several hours of boring filler where little to nothing of consequence occurs. And although the game’s twist is lauded by many to be the best in recent memory, it’s honestly not that surprising when you discover the game’s themes, nor is it very unique or unexpected for a sci-fi fantasy plot. The game is also very linear, where you basically follow the plot railroad from point to point. There is little consequence to any of your actions or choices in the game and the player has absolutely no influence on the plot.Overall the story had very little impact on me, and even though there were several emotional moments near the end of the game, the story ultimately feels meaningless and empty, neither happy or sad, nor triumphant or disappointing. It’s still a very smart story but fails to connect with me on any emotional level.The game’s environments are beautiful and striking, but since the same can be said about most AAA titles nowadays, so such praise is entirely superfluous and entirely dependent on the player. It’s neither the most aesthetically impressive nor the most technically impressive game I’ve seen.Ultimately, I feel that the game is an interesting thought exercise packaged in a fairly mediocre game. It was a game created to service a story, and to me, it sacrificed too much gameplay to achieve it. The story would have been much better conveyed in a movie/series/comic/book.

												BioShock Infinite could make you feel uncomfortable. If you adhere to religious faith, or celebrate American idealism, this game may invite introspection or even anger. BioShock Infinite isn't afraid to magnify the way religious and racial extremism inform our culture and change lives. It isn't afraid to depict a less-than-holy trinity diseased by power, deception, and manipulation. As the story circles back on itself, you're left wondering whether redemption cleanses us of our atrocities, or simply invites us to commit greater ones. Once the finale comes, you will want to play again, watching each event and image through the lens of information you can never un-know. BioShock Infinite is more than just a quality game: it's an important one.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												Have you ever really spoilt a child? What happened afterwards? Were they somewhat thankless? Did they not appreciate the effort that you went through? To some degree this game really goes out to spoil you as a gamer. It spoils you with high definition graphics and art, it spoils you with a over the top music score and sound effects. Everything in the game is large, loud, vibrant and explosive. However all this spoiling has a downside too, the worst part is that it spoils you with giving you way too much advantage. The high graded weapons are too powerful, the various clothes you can wear have added perks which make the game too easy and the plasmids/infusions you get throughout the game make the difficulty of the game pretty much a no brainer. This game is so easy thanks to things like 'winter shield' I hardly found it challenging at all with the exception of the end. Seriously. Me. The guy who can't play csgo if his life depended on it, the guy who begins to weep openly when those front doors of tf2 open up, the guy who completely soils his pants everytime he sees a child in 'no more room in hell', me the guy who practically moans in every review that the game is too hard. Yes that guy, found this game soooooooooooo easy, that i was seriously yawning at parts as I ran ahead just pulling the trigger.Is the game scary? Hell no. The infusions make you so powerful, who even needs to hide in the game? Just sprint forward and kill everything. There is no need to stealth, no sneaking around required because there is a formidable opponent just around the corner waiting for you, because lets face it, if there is, he is the one in trouble, not you.The game is designed by these people... http://irrationalgames.com/ and as you are all probably aware the Bio-shock franchise was largely inspired by this golden nugget found here  . However no matter how hard they try, none of the Bioshock games quite match the same level of brilliance as 'System Shock 2' which is where the true inspiration of the game originates from.This is the third game in the series continuing from Bio-shock and Bio-shock 2, but instead of calling it Bio-shock 3 they have opted for the tag infinite. This is largely because the game plays around with the notion of alternate parralel universes especially in the contingency of the Bio-shock realm which has already been introduced in the previous two games. The problem with writing about quantum hypotheticals is that you can pretty much come up with any mumbo jumbo and they just about have.According to the alternate realities theory. Any action you do will automatically spawn another alternate universe where the opposite action/reaction was performed. For instance if you choose not to marry a certain girl in this universe, another version of you in another universe does marry that girl, which then plays out another scenario where you can have children or do not have children. Every decision/action made branches a new universe. Hence infinite possibilties, infinite universes, infinite you.The game begins with you Mr Booker De Witt discovering that you have a specialised mission to 'bring us the girl to wipe away the debt', other than that you have very little recollection of anything else previously. Ofcourse this raises a number of questions, who is the girl? Why do i have to bring her? What is the debt? Who am i? Why can't I remember anything? Eventually as you progress you discover that the girl your looking for is Elizabeth who has the special power of opening up tears where you can travel to other alternate parrarel realities. You also find out that she is locked up in large tower by a feared and yet revered guy known as Komstock who has advertised to all his flock that a false shephard will arrive to take away the girl and that the false shepherd has a mark on the back of his hand consisting of two letters A.D. Other than warning all his flock to be on the look out for the 'False Shepherd' he has also devised a mechanical monster known as the 'songbird' inspired in creation from the 'Big Daddys' in the previous two games, two protect the girl and keep her locked up in the tower.The biggest problem with the alternate universe theory is that there really is NO official time line. EVERY decision and action will branch a new reality. The game tries to fix this by getting you to follow the official timeline of the 123rd Booker De Witt where something different happens in comparison to the 122 Booker De Witts before namely that he survives a digested potion. From this point on your creating NEW ground where every action and decision again creates another hypothetical alternate reality. To further add to this confusion is that with the power of Elizabeth you can jump about through all these alternate realities influencing them too. By the end of it all you will be spoilt with the back stories of Elizabeth, Komstock, Columbia in the sky, the song bird and the list goes on spelling out everything and nicely tying up any loose ends made in the previous games. To tell you the truth the writers did a pretty superb job in solving pretty much everything, but it does not mean that this in fact works. IT DOESN'T. There are so many loopholes in this story that one could still write a book about it.(Serious Spoilers below)For instance during the game you will work out that your opting out of baptism created a completely different character in comparison to the guy who went through it. At the end the only solution presented to you is that you must be killed so that no more Booker De Witts get created. You pretty much stand there and accept this fatality as a noble and essential happening to save mankind in general. In truth there are so many more ways the problem could have been solved. The only reason why you seek baptism is because of an attrocity you commited in the battle of 'wonded knee' therefore if you simply pulled out a gun and shot yourself in the foot before the battle began you still would have saved all mankind and yourself as well. But alas you never take such things into account and accept death. Ofcourse the fact that someone kills you in this reality automatically means that in another reality someone does not and hence the story continues infinitely.(end of spoilers)Is the game violent? The first encounter you have against hostiles is pretty much the worst when it comes to violence. You start off required to rotate a saw blade through the head of a few police and there is no way to really get around that, but it is short and before you know it your presented with a gun where you can shoot them all from a distance. As you power up the weapons though you can pretty much explode your enemies too, so keep that in mind.After all said and done, there is enough graphically and story wise to give this a solid thumbs up, however the gamers are spoilt ridiculously with having too much at their disposal. There is no horror survival, no stealth, no rationing your ammo needed here. I highly recommend you play the first two games before attempting this, I also highly recommend that you place this game on the hardest difficulty before you embark on the adventure so that you really get the most out of it. For most people the eyecandy alone will be enough for them, for other the simple fact that you get to shoot things and make things go BOOM would be another reason to love the game. However for the gamers looking for something really challenging do not get your hopes up. There is a LOT of hype with this game. Its a good game, but its by no means the GREATEST game ever.

												Might as well call the game "Micheal Bay's generic video game Infinite" as you just run around like a jackass killing everyone in sight with little to no story telling or character development.I personally find this the most over rated game of the year. Combat is far from fun with 40% of the game being a rail shooter with a few fetch quests & “puzzles”, however, calling them “puzzles” is a far stretch as a 3 year old could figure them out. The other 60% of the game is pressing f (pick-up/grab key) on everything that glows thanks to small ammo pool for each weapon.Combat is so basic and boring you can literally head shot everyone with out popping your shields and boss fights are the same thing over and over again regardless of the difficulty. Later in the game enemies basically become bullet sponges and running out of ammo is not due to poor aim or bad decision making but more so that the game is forcing you to pick-up random weapons for no reason to acquire more ammo and add some depth to the combat.Characters are dull with no depth and the game aims to tackle a lot of “hot topics” like religion, slavery, capitalism, revolution, etc... making it feel very pretensions while expressing nothing of importance. The story is so childish you could basically play the whole game with out knowing what's going on and understand everything at the end.I find it hard to really give this game a positive score however the gorgeous environment & character models does make the game a joy to look at, but this quickly becomes over looked as the entire game's environments are the same and nothing encourages you to look for none traditional story telling within the environments.I give BioShock Infinite a 6/10 and that's pushing it; Story, combat & characters leave much to be desired but the game runs well with no bugs/glitches, the game feels like a solid PC port from console and the environments are amazing making it hard to give it anything below 6/10 (as I consider games under 5/10 broken and unplayable).Should you play BioShock? No.“Pro” Tip:Carbine + Machine Gun + Electric Salt = Cruise control

Just like old Bioshock games. This time, exploring some areas can be different. Like in Bioshock 2, you might need a key or a decoder to acess a certain secret. Witch is okay to me, since the secrets in this areas helps a lot.The game runs pretty fine. Honestly. Even in the highest settings. Controls respond with no problem and auto-aim can help anyone who doesn't have experience with FPS games.If i can say something bad about this game is the IA. Not that they are stupid or something, but i started on hard and din't have one single death until now. I din't beat the game yet but already had some mini boss fights and...They weren't a big of a deal. I guess i was expecting a challenge like i had on Bioshock 1 (That game was hard for me). I think the shield thing let the game a bit easier for gamers of the new generation. Meh...What can i do about it?At least hardcore players should've been given the option to turn the shield off, just my opinion. I miss the times of carrying med packs and always struggling for life while fighting big dads and sentrys. That's the only feel that Infinite couldn't gave me.That said. I really recomend this game. It's awesome in many ways, mainly for it's art style and nice story.But for Bioshock fans: Watch out, you're walking in a whole new thing. Some fans may don't like what they see. Or even think that the game isn't challenging enough. If you walk in this game in a open mid, taking it like a spinoff or even a reboot, you can make your way to like it.

												Welp, Bioshock Infinite, A frustratingly fun game that isn't as good as the original. Why isn't it as good? Well, it's the ending and sort of the story to really. It's like they teased you with a little bit of story at the beggining, got hung up with creating the game, then loudly exclaimed. "Oh ♥♥♥♥! John, we forgot that whole story thing in the middle. Should we just add it all in the end? Yeah, just put all the rest of the story into some sort of semi-interactive Cinematic piece thing?. Yes i'm sure it'll work. Alright we'll do it." And so they did that and no, it doesn't work. It is a good story once you fully understand it (lots of googling) and it's a neat concept, but compaed to the original, it's lacking. Ssort of dissapointing too to find out that your choices in the game ultimately don't matter unlike in the first one where if you decided to set up your daddy-day-care-esk nursery for the little sisters then you got rewarded and got a different ending. And the patriot fights are nowhere's near as butt-clenchingly exciting as the Big Daddy fights in the original, nor are the weapons as creative as in the original. The scenery is awesome and you'll be impressed when you first begin, but it grows dull after a while. It suffers from spouts of genericitis, much like my reviews and daily meals.If you're going into this game expecting it to be better or just as good as the original, then it's a dissapointed 6/10. If not, maybe a 8/10, why no 9/10? Because holy ♥♥♥♥ is shooting the same enemies over and over ever repetative, even on medium difficulty, you litterally have to go into full grind mode just to get through some areas. Though you will be happily entertained through the game otherwise. Get it when it's bellow $10, possibly $20 if you really, really want to play it, that's what it feels like it's worth to me.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Hello boys and girls, step right up and experience Bioshock Infinite - The one and only video game to feature graphics that appear more stunning than the graphics in real life! That's right graphics-obsessed mainstream gamer crowd, get your salivary glands as hyped up as the fanboys of this here game, because you're in for the ride of your lives through the first literal shooter on rails!Yes, you heard me right - this game is the first shooter on rails to actually involve shooting while on rails! As you glide gracefully through the air without ever fearing for your life, you will find yourself pitted against fellow rail-riders that will also be firing at you as you fire at them. But don't worry! This game is more than ready to account for your lack of an attention span, and will gladly reduce the odds of you getting shot while riding on these rails to next to zero!Be prepared to be awed by this game's incredible involvement of the theory of relativity, which will leave you, like many fanboys, baffled and confused with its remarkable ending that completely forgets the grandfather paradox! But don't question the lack of thought put into its use of time and space, nor how people can live in a floating city like this without passing out from low oxygen! None of this should matter when you're rapidly firing a rocket launcher, and being hit in the head with a wrench by a girl you just saved!But graphics aren't all this game features, it also boasts amazing features never seen before in video game history! Features, such as; Racism, skyhook assassinations, firefights on rails (as mentioned before, but it's worth repeating!), classical music, crazy religious people, and most of all: Elizabeth's magical ability to pull weapons and money from thin air!Mainstream shooter fans rejoice! This game, unlike the others in the franchise, realizes that you're too simple-minded to possibly keep up with multiple weapons, and so it limits you to only two at once! Don't worry about figuring out which two weapons you like - they've gone out of their way to make sure that only a small portion of the handful of weapons available are actually useful in the game, so you'll be just fine!So throw your science book out the window, forget Einstein existed, and prepare to enter the floating city of Columbia through the eyes of Booker Dewitt, he's just your average ex-military gun-wielding father who is able to immediately go from retrieving a girl for a 100% legit client, to taking on an entire army of soldiers! Become immersed in his epic tale, as he rescues a Paris-obsessed girl named Elizabeth, who shows absolutely no respect for our clearly trustworthy protagonist, and will not think twice about running away, or otherwise physically harming him, despite the fact that he is the only reason she ever escaped at all!So join the hype train, and buy Bioshock Infinite - your eyes will not regret it, but your mind might!

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												Visually intriguing, but otherwise a generic shooter, with cliched writing. The game has a few good concepts, but it never truly utilizes either of them, or in some cases, they just fall too short of being interesting. The world is set up to be big and explorable, but then changes direction, and ends up being a literal horde fest, with little to no user interaction. You can collect things, and that's about it. Most of the weapons are horrible, and you'll find yourself constanly looking for ammo. Even though you're able to buy them from dispensers, It's just never enough, and you end up running back and forth in search for it.Because of this, and the linear 'hit-n-run' objectives, the gameplay quickly becomes boring and repetitive. The game tells you at the start, that it's not always the best option to fight, however, you can't do much else, seeing how sneaking is either practically impossible, or it goes overboard and your enemies won't notice you, even after you repetadly stab them in the back.The 'Story Rich' tag is ridiculous, as the whole plot can be summed up within 2 sentences. Character development is forced, and badly timed, with idiotic symbolism, that just feels out of place. An example would be making a character randomly cut her hair, for the sake of showing a personal 'change', which is laughable and weak. A woman won't suddenly become more masculine and reliable from a change in hair style, nor will that show any determination. It's also painfully obvious, that the inclusion of such and similar tropes were for fetishistic reasons, and lazy writing. The creators tried to justify all this with a wannabe 'artistic' ending, with make-belief deepness, which ends up being half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥and totally out of place.All in all, it's clear that this was made for a more casual, and child like audience, who's only reference for comparison is COD.##############################UPDATE#############################So I came back to this game after half a year, and replayed it, thinking that I might have been too harsh on it. What I came to find, wasn't that big of a difference.The thin plot not only makes me cringe, but manages to have more holes in it than an empty shopping cart. There's numerous things that don't even make sense, I bet the lead writer just thought, that using transdimensional time traveling will just 'fix itself', and 'oh well but it's just a different dimension' will be a good enough excuse for bad writing. Albeit I have to admit that one or two supporting characters are indeed interesting. The  guns aren't as horrible as I remembered, but they're definetaly bad. It doesn't help that the game misleads you either, it constantly reminds you that short bursts are more accurate, and effective against enemies, which is not true at all. If you've ever played any FPS games, you would think like that statement, and would certainly approve it, but in this game, that's not happening. Simply because there's literary no recoil on anything, and it doesn't matter how you use your weapons, the accuracy will be the exact same thing. Using small amounts of bursts against multiple 'tanks' is practically suicide in most cases, it's a lot more effective to just camp and hold down your fire button, and spam your enemy with bullets. So yeah, go and trust the game, and you'll be constantly seeing the revive animation.Vigors help you a lot, but again, the game eats your ammo as fast as a Mortal Kombat arcade machine. There are instances where it's impossible to even stock up on any ammo for any weapon, and you'll be facing a horde of enemies without any. Relying solely on your generic 'melee'' attack, makes surviving a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ I tell ya. It also doesn't help that you sometimes can get stuck in an object lying on the ground, or hear enemies, but can't see them, until you use bucking bronco, pushing them afloat in the air, because they decided to bug into the ground. In some cases, the amount of projectile, and effects makes it literary impossible to see anything, rendering you practically blind, until you somehow manage to get onto a skyline, or in a safe cover. Civillians also just randomly disappear most of the time, but I guess that's just me nitpicking too much. Oh yes, shout out to the people claiming that BI is ballsy for having 3 instances (literary that many sentences) of reference to racism: It's not.I wouldn't say it's a bad game, it's decent, and somewhat replayable, with an interesting world concept, but there's a lot of room for improvement, especially with the combat system, so my review stays negative. It could have been easily better with a coherent writer, and some gameplay elements could still be post-fixed with a patch, but I don't see that ever happening.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Though not as solid and near-perfect as the first BioShock, a superb game. Beautiful to look at, smooth gameplay, fun, clever AI, no fall damage and even one-click-away-navigational-help for us with orientation difficulties.There's a difficulty spike by the end fight though which is unwarranted and makes that fight repetetive and boring rather than challenging and thrilling. There are also some sound issues where the sound completely cuts off unless you stand exactly at the source of it which takes you out of the game a bit. Also very few character models, which makes the whole city of Columbia seems like one big bunch of inbreeds, but perhaps that can be worked into a point with the racism overtones. It can also be frustrating making out where you are being shot from at times.Overall though, the positives far outweighed the negatives. I particularly enjoy the enviromental narratives, music cues when all the enemies in a wave has been taken care of, Elizabeth as a companion being useful and invulnerable during the ingame fights, though she did block my path at a handful of times for just a short moment, but that's being extremely nitpicky. The enviroments are breathtakingly beautiful many times, and swinging on and from the sky hooks is a blast, just as is using this games versions of plasmids. Voice acting is also great, and I thought it was fun to have female enemies for variation and not only male ones, just like in the previous BioShocks.*MINOR SPOILERS* I personally had no issues with the ending, but then I usually don't have issues with leaving some things to be interpreted and/or left unsaid, though I can see why people like their endings neatly wrapped up. *SPOILERS END*
