content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												If you are anything like me - you would of... Hang on - we are alike! Didn't we pass each other at the near end of the game when you went into your own lighthouse in the middle of the sea ala Bioshock? I was trying to come towards you and say hello but Elizabeth was forging another path for me.Or maybe we did not meet. Because you died - or maybe I died - maybe I finished the adventure you could not because you ran out of ammo. Maybe you took on the baton after I dropped it in the mental asylum having not concentrated at all on melee combat and paid a heavy price.If you are anything like me - you would be a father, perhaps have children - this game is perfect for you, perfect .I was going to write a partly negative review of this one - but I waited until I completed the game and have changed my mind a bit.This game is an average shooter - but amazing, incredible gaming experience.Firstly - let me say I have played System Shock, still have my System Shock 2 CDs and also played Bioshock 1 and 2.My biggest regret about this franchise is how it has been moving from FPS/RPG hybrid adventure type to pure FPS . Having said that - the shooter aspect has never been one of its strengths, okay by my standards, but really they have been about storytelling, imagination, creating worlds, the experience.Bioshock Infinite has dumbed down a bit - probably to accommodate the console crowd - Consolisation is happening, below is partly why:I did not like you could only carry two weapons, could only scroll through two rigours, could only have ONE save at a time?Say if my son wanted to play the game as well - he might have played on an easier mode - his saved game would have wiped out mine - now come on - what is the point of that?I found the keyboard layout a nightmare and would have liked the melee option a bit easier to use. Press V to hit with a weapon? What a daft choice!I found the use of rigours difficult - often the game would have to remind me to use them - I could have gone most of the game without them. The game interface did not help - often I could not find the right vigour for the situation. Why not tab, choose vigour option?I have never really liked the way the designers hide a lot of the backstory with the audio logs - this should be improved in future games -Plus - if you moved from the spot once turning one of these machines on - often you missed what was being said due to some other game words/text cutting through it - I would have liked to have the option to read the text on the machines. Can you press tab/ escape and read the logs all over again? Why not?It means after you played the game you need to go across the internet to find out what the hell was happening - otherwise the game can come across as lame and boring, a standard shooter, actually not even that.The using of tears (to another dimension) facility was a bit useless, Singularity did it better - and that is not saying much. It seems the designers found it quite hard to incorporate that part of the game properly. They mostly felt contrived and enforced onto the gamer.A lot more negatives by the way - don't get me started on the pants and hats and little missions to find a key to open a chest. More and more besides that...Now that stuff is out of the way - the game ended up being AMAZING, probably the most effective gaming EXPERIENCE I have ever had.The Elizabeth character - wow - completely amazing - you meet her about a quarter way in - do the whole "I'm here to rescue you" and most of the remaining game is in her company. I must say the designers found a winning formula here - totally brilliant. When you lose her at a key moment and try and go back and save her - can't describe how I felt - but it did feel very personal and ominous - genuinely like you did not want to let her down - genuinely concerned - she was just not another game character - the designers got that spot on. Due to the relationship build up with her beforehand, when you lose her and fail, yes, YOU FAIL, it feels quite real actually, Had a lump in my front and part of that was not knowing what the hell was going on..The relationship between your character and Elizabeth IS THE GAME, give it time, don't give up on it - the rewards come late on but will totally thrill you, haunt you and question the nature of all games.The shooter bit - this one was a bit unusual in that sometimes I could not get my bearings and find out where the shots were coming from. I thought this was a bit naff - but I am going to give the designers a bit of credit here - that was probably because your opponents could be in front, behind, above, below, to the left, to the right etc. Enemies could stand on flying ships that are above, below, left, to the right (you get the picture). The City in the Clouds combat was okay actually - will be interesting to see if anyone else comes and does it better.The graphics - simply gorgeous at key points, especially at the beginning when you enter a bright and colourful city in the clouds -  and then some other amazing graphic moments. No one creates a graphics style better - totally original and believable.So, if you are anything like me - games such as Skyrim, Oblivion, Morrowind and Daggerfall are the best games you ever played. System Shock 2 comes quite high on your list. Deep down, you know games will never be like that again - it's all about the graphics. Story telling either created by you or set by a games design are mostly too complicated to produce.So, if you are anything like me, you will immensely enjoy this unique gaming experience and afterwards wish you had someone to talk to about your feelings and thoughts about it. Thanks for taking on the baton after I fell.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
 A rare, beautiful, exciting and one of Gamings Shining MomentsQuite simply the best single player story driven game ever made in my opinion. It wasnt until I found myself lacking a great single player experience to be had in the past year or so that I decided to repurchase Bioshock Infinite on Steam and see how it held up. It held up great, but even moreso the gameplay, story, and experience still outshines its peers.Here is just a few things that make this game so great     It has an absolutely brilliant story! I cant say enough about how cohesive, thought out, and realized this story is. The thing that sticks out the most to me is that this game has some absolutely insane huge twists, yet your too wrapped up in the whats happening now with your character and Elizabeth that you never see it coming.Gameplay that is unrivaled. Its a first person shooter that executes well, it does this because it doesnt try to be something its not, and knows what type of experience they want you to have. You have one arm that is designated for weapons (Brutally easy to swap) and the other hand is for your vigors (powers)  that you pick up along the way. Using both of these together and often is so seamless. The game has light RPG elements only in the sense that you have to choose what weapons and vigors (powers) to upgrade with your hard earned coins you pick up. That suits this style of game lovely, as you dont stay away from the story very long flopping through in menu screens.Graphics are still really polished and do no injustice to this game what so ever. The whole art style is fantastic. It plays out like a city built in the sky to resemble Heaven and Americana Circa 1940s. The music is beautiful, and accompanies it well.The game genre I guess would be Science Fiction FPS/Adventure. The thing that makes it so hard to put this game into this category is that there are some genuinely spooky moments, some genuinely Tony Hawk and now Sunset Overdrive style gameplay flying around on Rails, and genuinely just an amazing adventure game.The Rapture DLC is a real treat for all of those who missed being in Rapture, the story is quite awesome as well. Highly Recomend it.Ok I know Im gushing here, but this game ladies and gents, is quite frankly a very rare gem. It should be had by all. I think of it as the Shawshank Redemption, Michael Jordan Game Six, Eminem the Marshall Mathers LP of video games. ** Note this is my second purchase of this game, and fourth to fifth playthrough.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2016
												A short summary of Bioshock Infinite from my point of view. The game was entertaining but not as captivating as I thought it would be. Don’t get me wrong, I loved the art style of the game, the story is superb, and combat can get pretty gritty when mixing powers+guns+melee attacks. On the same note, combat in Bioshock Infinite felt kind of repetitive and unnecessary at times I found myself losing interest in the overall game. There are times were combat is amazing and you are jumping from hook to hook or traveling on rails to get the jump on some enemies and you really feel like a character on a mission of retribution .  However in between these moments there are sequences where it is basically, enter area, lots of enemies spawn, kill enemies, move on, repeat. Though I did say the story is superb like combat it also has these moments where you don’t get any new character development or plot revelation and again kind of dragged down my interest.All that being said, the game is relatively long and the DLC burial at sea sets up the story for the original Bioshock nicely. So is it worth the non-sale price that is currently on steam? ($29.99 or $49.99+season pass) that is a hard question for me to answer. For just Bioshock Infinite I’d say $29.99 is definitely worth it because the main game content is definitely worth the asking price. However, the season pass is still a bit pricy and the dlc Burial at Sea episode 1 and 2 are really the only thing you actually might want (the other stuff is just something to help you upgrade your character).

There are times were combat is amazing and you are jumping from hook to hook or traveling on rails to get the jump on some enemies and you really feel like a character on a mission of retribution .  However in between these moments there are sequences where it is basically, enter area, lots of enemies spawn, kill enemies, move on, repeat. Though I did say the story is superb like combat it also has these moments where you don’t get any new character development or plot revelation and again kind of dragged down my interest.All that being said, the game is relatively long and the DLC burial at sea sets up the story for the original Bioshock nicely. So is it worth the non-sale price that is currently on steam? ($29.99 or $49.99+season pass) that is a hard question for me to answer. For just Bioshock Infinite I’d say $29.99 is definitely worth it because the main game content is definitely worth the asking price. However, the season pass is still a bit pricy and the dlc Burial at Sea episode 1 and 2 are really the only thing you actually might want (the other stuff is just something to help you upgrade your character).

Posted: March 12, 2016
 A rare, beautiful, exciting and one of Gamings Shining MomentsQuite simply the best single player story driven game ever made in my opinion. It wasnt until I found myself lacking a great single player experience to be had in the past year or so that I decided to repurchase Bioshock Infinite on Steam and see how it held up. It held up great, but even moreso the gameplay, story, and experience still outshines its peers.Here is just a few things that make this game so great     It has an absolutely brilliant story! I cant say enough about how cohesive, thought out, and realized this story is. The thing that sticks out the most to me is that this game has some absolutely insane huge twists, yet your too wrapped up in the whats happening now with your character and Elizabeth that you never see it coming.Gameplay that is unrivaled. Its a first person shooter that executes well, it does this because it doesnt try to be something its not, and knows what type of experience they want you to have. You have one arm that is designated for weapons (Brutally easy to swap) and the other hand is for your vigors (powers)  that you pick up along the way. Using both of these together and often is so seamless. The game has light RPG elements only in the sense that you have to choose what weapons and vigors (powers) to upgrade with your hard earned coins you pick up. That suits this style of game lovely, as you dont stay away from the story very long flopping through in menu screens.Graphics are still really polished and do no injustice to this game what so ever. The whole art style is fantastic. It plays out like a city built in the sky to resemble Heaven and Americana Circa 1940s. The music is beautiful, and accompanies it well.The game genre I guess would be Science Fiction FPS/Adventure. The thing that makes it so hard to put this game into this category is that there are some genuinely spooky moments, some genuinely Tony Hawk and now Sunset Overdrive style gameplay flying around on Rails, and genuinely just an amazing adventure game.The Rapture DLC is a real treat for all of those who missed being in Rapture, the story is quite awesome as well. Highly Recomend it.Ok I know Im gushing here, but this game ladies and gents, is quite frankly a very rare gem. It should be had by all. I think of it as the Shawshank Redemption, Michael Jordan Game Six, Eminem the Marshall Mathers LP of video games. ** Note this is my second purchase of this game, and fourth to fifth playthrough.

 “Bring us the girl and wipe away the debt”Bioshock Infinite is the final game in its trilogy, but can frankly stand out as its own due to its original story. The story, the art style and the characters manage to charm the player from the first glance and keep them immersed in its universe.You follow the steps of Booker Dewitt, an american citizen with a mysterious that has been given a task to retrieve a girl that resides in a city in the clouds AKA Columbia. It may have seem as your everyday rescue mission, but the second he arrives to said city things take a little twist and the story will only become more and more complex as you make progress. One of the things I loved the most is your partner Elizabeth which, unlike many other companions, you don’t feel the burden to protect her all the time or just forget about her in the middle of a battle but will actually step out and help you with health, ammo and salts without having (while this can save you on many tricky situations you can’t by any means abuse that and have her carrying you over), later on she’ll learn to control an ability that allows to pull out certain elements to aid you further in combat. Whenever you’re out of combat and just exploring the corners of Columbia, let it be a side quest, looking for special gear or infusions to upgrade, you’ll notice that she’ll let you know about certain goodies that the player might miss out (lockpicks, a certain clue or money) proving that she’s far superior than most AI companions and personally I think that the developers just made a great job with her; you feel sympathy for her to the point that you form that special bond that not many characters can evoke.The soundtrack is one of the best I’ve seen in a long time, it combines some past era music with original scores that just blend beautifully in the atmosphere. One thing that I have seen many people doing is to compare this game to its previous installments, and I consider that if you want to get the best experience of it is to try to avoid that. While they may be in the same universe they are definitely not story related and the gameplay does changes a bit (nothing groundbreaking in my opinion though). Something that I would like to point out is that this is one of the best optimized games I’ve ever seen, I’ve had the opportunity of playing it in a laptop with the lowest graphics cards, if you can call it that (obviously the settings were in no way maxed butl medium to high) and it ran smoothly for most of the game.

												One of my favorite games of all time. Probably my favorite FPS. The art style, combat/gameplay, score, story, characters and themes are all so perfect. It does everything the previous BioShock games did but perhaps even better (in my opinion). The way the story unfolds really makes you care about Booker and Elizabeth's fates. The combat is so varied and full of options and the gun mechanics themselves feel so nice and smooth. The soundtrack adds a lot of tension in fights when needed or adds a lot of atmosphere in cut-scenes. Columbia is no Rapture, but it looks beautiful in its own right and fits the general aesthetic of 1912 America. Last but not least, this game tackles a lot of turn of the century themes of poverty, divided classes, segregation and racism that a lot of other games wouldn't because they don't have the balls. The only minor issue I see is that the game loses focus about halfway through and the story progresses through a bit of Deus Ex machina. 9/10. My only regret is not being able to experience the game for the first time again.

												Hello boys and girls, step right up and experience Bioshock Infinite - The one and only video game to feature graphics that appear more stunning than the graphics in real life! That's right graphics-obsessed mainstream gamer crowd, get your salivary glands as hyped up as the fanboys of this here game, because you're in for the ride of your lives through the first literal shooter on rails!Yes, you heard me right - this game is the first shooter on rails to actually involve shooting while on rails! As you glide gracefully through the air without ever fearing for your life, you will find yourself pitted against fellow rail-riders that will also be firing at you as you fire at them. But don't worry! This game is more than ready to account for your lack of an attention span, and will gladly reduce the odds of you getting shot while riding on these rails to next to zero!Be prepared to be awed by this game's incredible involvement of the theory of relativity, which will leave you, like many fanboys, baffled and confused with its remarkable ending that completely forgets the grandfather paradox! But don't question the lack of thought put into its use of time and space, nor how people can live in a floating city like this without passing out from low oxygen! None of this should matter when you're rapidly firing a rocket launcher, and being hit in the head with a wrench by a girl you just saved!But graphics aren't all this game features, it also boasts amazing features never seen before in video game history! Features, such as; Racism, skyhook assassinations, firefights on rails (as mentioned before, but it's worth repeating!), classical music, crazy religious people, and most of all: Elizabeth's magical ability to pull weapons and money from thin air!Mainstream shooter fans rejoice! This game, unlike the others in the franchise, realizes that you're too simple-minded to possibly keep up with multiple weapons, and so it limits you to only two at once! Don't worry about figuring out which two weapons you like - they've gone out of their way to make sure that only a small portion of the handful of weapons available are actually useful in the game, so you'll be just fine!So throw your science book out the window, forget Einstein existed, and prepare to enter the floating city of Columbia through the eyes of Booker Dewitt, he's just your average ex-military gun-wielding father who is able to immediately go from retrieving a girl for a 100% legit client, to taking on an entire army of soldiers! Become immersed in his epic tale, as he rescues a Paris-obsessed girl named Elizabeth, who shows absolutely no respect for our clearly trustworthy protagonist, and will not think twice about running away, or otherwise physically harming him, despite the fact that he is the only reason she ever escaped at all!So join the hype train, and buy Bioshock Infinite - your eyes will not regret it, but your mind might!

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Having just completed this game, I feel it's time to recommend it to other people, point out why, and also point out the flaws you should be aware of before you take to the forums.I erect raise a wall of text in memory of my recent playthrough. Scroll right to the bottom for TL;DR version.Bioshock Infinite is an impressive, immersive world with a story that will swallow you in and ultimately decrease your productivity at work/college. Although it can suck you in, play-time is relatively short, as I completed it in 18 hours (two days of gameplay) - and that's with me going to explore and check out the obscure areas (and waiting at an "Arrival/Departure" sign for about half an hour lol).Not long after you start this game, about the time you end up in Columbia, you're met with a feeling of euphoria and you find yourself exploring, asking questions like "Where does this path lead?", "Can I talk to this guy?" and "Who on Earth keeps a pear inside a cash register?".Combat is great, and despite being a story-driven game the action is constant and exciting. Enemies die - they don't flop and hit the ground like in some games. You hear a sort of epic-orchestra-hit when you kill someone from a headshot (this is amazing during a certain fight in the Shantytown when you're popping head after head as you lea---). Sorry, spoiler police.You'll find yourself seamlessly ducking in and out of cover, shooting faces, throwing enemies off the edge, speeding across skylines, diving through the air, and lots of other cool stuff you can't do in real life or Call of Duty.Though this game isn't without its flaws - my major beef being with the rushed finish. About halfway through the game, you begin to notice repeated textures, chalkboards with the exact same combinations of formulae you've saw in a hundred other places (fellow engineering graduates - you'll notice this instantly), as if this one scientist works for all of Columbia.Choices don't make much difference, and while we should be glad that the story is kept on the rails at all times, it would be nice to have a more interactive world - maybe with some distractions from the story, some immersive side-quests, some random people we can empathise with (preferably who don't all look exactly the same). Maybe I'm asking this game to be something it's not - but you DID get my hopes up at the beginning.Special tip for the best experience: Don't play through this game in two days like I did. Space it out. The environment can get repetitive.Now for the TL;DR version...Good: Epic story, beautiful environment, accurate portrayal of historical attitudes and events, action-packed, fast-paced combat, fitting soundtrack, fair balance between players freedom and integrity of storyline, female companion to ease loneliness of sitting in front of your computer all day.Bad: Noticeable repitition of mid-priority textures (i.e. chalkboards, picture frames, decorations), leaves you with the cold realisation that you were playing a game all this time.I rate this game 9/10 and implore you to play it - whether you liked the first two or not, this is an amazing game.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2015
												My opinion for this game is a... complicated one, so if you don't care for specifics, just take it as positive.As someone that has been a diehard fan of the Bioshock series ever since its conception, I can't consider this game an addition to the series, and not because it's not (primarily) set in Rapture, but because it doesn't hold any common ground with any game containing "shock" that was headed by Ken Levine.The weapons, unlike its predecessors, are lackluster and dull, with the majority of them being useless, or phased out by far more viable guns (try finding some footage of this game where somebody isn't just using the carbine and hand cannon).The "tonics" by far feel like the weakest thing about the game, with all but 2-3 of them feeling worthless, and unlike the other games, the use for them to access secret areas containing additional audio logs and loot are very sparse.Now, for the additional game mechanics.The lockpick "system" (if you can bare over glorifying this poorly-implemented gimmick to call it that) is atrocious, and because they couldn't be ♥♥♥♥ed to think of a new hacking minigame, they just added the occasional safe or door that requires the use of your precious and rare "lockpicks" to find out whether or not you just got screwed over because you spent all of them opening a door to reveal some ammo that you already maxxed out on, you may see a safe up ahead that requires only 2 and without a shadow of a doubt holds some of the best loot in the game. All in all, barely thought-out and dissapointing.The Elizabeth system is trivial and dumb, and they only put it in to make the game not seem like an escort quest. The level design could have been exactly the same and it would've been fine if they just implemented the occasional hook every here-and-there, and would actually encourage the player to fan out further in order to find supplies.Sidequests- eh.The skyrails were very well done, but incredibly underused, and just came across as another gimmick to be used in a level every now-and-then.The story? Alot of people harp on about how this game has an excellent tale, with a strong supporting lore, but I would heavily disagree, even the background story provided through audio logs in Bioshock 2 (The strongest and most underrated aspect of that game, by the way) is more solid and integral than that of this game. The multi-dimensional aspect of the story is mind-mushingly simple, especially considering what they could've done with it, and I feel that it is an insult to the saga, and a disappointment after Minerva's Den for 2. Another nitpick is that when Elizabeth is supposedly depressed and undergoing complete psychological trauma, she still has it in her to yell a whimsical comment as she throws you some ammo or picks a lock. The alleged and critically acclaimed "twists" in it feel incredibly predictible.Character Progression- Tonics get really dull and uninteresting upgrades. There is no system similar to that of the Little Sisters. The weapon upgrades dullness is second only to that of the weapons themselves. You can only hold 2 weapons. The only remnants of the moral choice system showcased in the original display of the early version of this game is at the very beginning, and has no impact at all.As much as I've been harping on it, this is still a good game. Just not a good -----Shock game. Although many of these issues are fixed the Burial at Sea expansion pack, they still aren't part of the base game, which is by far what really counts. I thoroughly recommend this game, though you may want to pick it up at a discount...

Posted: December 30, 2013
												I love the original Bioshock; I played the original one on the Xbox 360, and it was one of the best single player game I have ever played. It was so cleverly made... the morality elements and story was the most compelling part about it. In Bioshock Infinite, they refreshed these factors very well much like the original (I haven't played Bioshock II yet). This game feels very, very much like the original Bioshock, but at the same time, it feels like a different game. The team that made Infinite completely redesigned the game; goodbye plasmids, we now have Vigors. No more "hacking", but there's possession, which does something similar. No more carrying an armory of weapons (Which kind of saddens me; you can now only carry 2 guns now), but you have an amazing partner (Elizabeth) that tosses you ammo, health, and salts (Which replaces EVE and powers vigors) when you need it. The story is very indepth, even more so than the original. I would highly recommend taking you're time while playing this game; If you just rush through it like a regular shooters game, you are TOTALLY missing the point of Bioshock. The audio logs and story just makes this game feels so complete. Not just that, the combat mechanism is fun as well and balanced. If you really enjoyed the original Bioshock, then this game will not disappoint you. PS. Elizabeth is the best NPC I have played with in a game... I think I'm in love with her.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												While my feelings for Bioshock: Infinite are a bit mixed I do recommend that you check this game out.Compared to Bioshock (1) the Vigors (plasmids) and weapons don't feel nearly as inspired.  There are less overall Vigors than in 1 and they seemed all around less useful than the plasmids of Bioshock.  The effects are minimal and I never felt like they contributed much in combat aside from minor effects like stunning an enemy or increasing how much damage the baddies took, which is a shame really.  Elsewhere, there are more types of guns but the amount of customization is much more limited.  There are no longer multiple ammo types and the weapon mods (upgrades) are very strict: each gun has 4 unique upgrades that unlock as you progress through the game but must be purchased.  Finally, tonics are mostly replaced by a new mechanic called Gear.  Gear can be changed at any time and confers similar effects to tonics.  Four pieces of gear can be worn at one time, but these pieces fill specific slots (hat body legs boots).  The effects of gear seemed to be expanded upon past the tonics of Bioshock.As a warning this game is very story heavy.  The pacing is much slower at the start than it is in Bioshock and this is both good and bad.  I didn't feel like I was playing a game for a long time, and even after I was the actual gameplay was so divided by long story segments that I wondered if the gameplay was getting in the way of the story that Infinite wanteed to tell.  This clears up about a third to halfway into the game but that's a long time before it actually happens.That being said I did enjoy the story even if it did get a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ty near the end.  While it's not the most original I applaud that the themes and ideas present were used in a video game, at least until the very end.  Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the ending but it seemed a bit contrived, defying sense and logic.  It did make me want to go replay the game and understand the significance of everything, but eh, lazy.  Ah, and the characters are fantastic as are there interactions.Combat is more or less the same as it was in Bioshock: you shoot things and then they die.  The enemy that replaced the Big Daddy is terrifying but it also only shows up a few times within the story.  Normal enemies make a lot more sense in Infinite than they did in Bioshock.  I understood why I was fighting what I was and why they were there/attacking me in 1 but the enemies in Infinite just fit a lot better.  Later "normal" enemies infuriated me at times because they would take more than an entire clip to their face at point blank before they would go down, but whatever, you get over it.The sky line system is interesting but I would have liked to see it expanded a bit more as it rarely comes into play.  Sure, in some combat situations it opens up the battlefield a lot and creates for some cool moments but I never felt like the sky lines were fully implemented.  That is to say, they felt out of place in their own game: their existence in a lot of places didn't make a lot of sense and from a story point they didn't seem to frequent or connect enough areas.  Early on you use them to move from one area to another but after that they mostly stay confined to a battle arena.  Shame, really.Oh, and the game is gorgeous.  The setting is ok; if it had been more open I would have received it better than I did, but you're never really given an opportunity to explore.  Everything is linear and you see exactly what the developers want you to.  Because of the linearity I didn't feel like I was exploring a city in the clouds so much.  In fact, I felt more confined in Infinite than I ever did in Bioshock, though maybe that is partially due to the ability to backtrack.  Ah well.Yeah, Bioshock is a good game, possibily even great, but it's not without flaws.  You should almost certainly check it out and it's definitely a game that's worth talking about.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												I came onto BioShock Infinite fresh after making a final run at the second in the series, and was not entirely sure what to expect with this new outing.  I knew the setting had changed, but a number of the core gameplay mechanics had made the jump from the first two games. What greeted me though was something a bit different than I could have anticipated, in ways that grew on me very quickly.  The first impression was holy crap wow this is a beautiful game.  The first two were interesting, visually, more for their art stylings than actual tech, but they never really blew me away.  Within the first 5 minutes of infinite with all the settings 'turned to 11' so to speak, my jaw was pretty much on the floor.  Its not that they are technically doing something wholly new I haven't seen before, but that what they are doing is just simply done out and out superlatively.  The lighting mixed with the beautiful texturing, mixed with the motion of the air city all around you just really scratched a visual itch in a way that say, Far Cry 2, and Fl0wer for the ps3 had previously.  Just really high on the wow factor.Beyond the sheer visuals though, I was immediately and pleasantly surprised by how 'tight' the controlls felt.  One of the bigger criticisms of the first two BioShock games is that they were 'console first' designs with controls clearly meant for a gamepad, and they felt sluggish and un-responsive to a seasoned mouse and keyboard user.  Infinite could not be further from that, and it was immediately noticable.  The mouse was perfectly smooth and responsive in the way the top tier valve titles tend to be, and things coming over from consoles really never seem to hit.This also ties in very well with much *much* tighter combat.   The weapons feel powerful and generally satisfying, you are limited halo-like to only having two around at a time, so you generally have to think ahead.  Do you really want to walk into a giant mansion with tons of tight corridors and rooms with a sniper rifle, or would it maybe make more sense to swap it out for something a little faster and more mobile first?The 'powers' (aka magic sparkles that fly out of your hand and into an enemies face) take something of a back-seat this time compared to gun play, and I appreciated the changes.  The fighting in rapture in the original games felt more like a game of tic-tac-toe than actual combat.  You had to zap the right enemies with the right magic in the right order then shoot them.  Sans magic you might as well have been firing rubber bullets.  You can make it though a signigicant part of this game barely using the powers at all, or you can use them more tactically, augmenting your fighting style in appreciable and welcome ways, vs out-right dictating it to you.Also for once, your 'escort mission' is the *best* part of the game, not the worst.  Its almost cliche at this point that you have to do x and y and protect the girl or you lose and its game over would you like to retry and maybe take more of the bullets this time so your npc can skip through unscathed... and yeah.. not here, not at all.  It feels like working *with* someone, not for them, and they are wholly capable of managing themselves, and maybe even getting you the extra cover you need, etc.  The only remaining question is why has it taken 15 years for the 'gaming world' to get it this right?There are in the end a few rough edges, sometimes you can feel a little directionless, there is always a helpful arrow to show you where you 'should' go, and you can of course follow it to the end, but theres so much more going on in the game, and the levels are so huge at times that you just sort of feel helpless trying to complete all the little side quests and secrets.  a 'second playthrough' sort of 'new game plus' option would have been pretty welcome here too, as no matter *how* good you are, you are never going to be able to earn/buy/achieve everything on a single play-through.  Those are quibbles tho, a rough plastic seam on a brand new toy, annoying, but no deal breakers by any means.(9.5/10)

												First off. The gameplay felt like Halo 1- Which would be good, except that it isnt Halo..... and also none of the previous games limited your number of weapons and tactical versatility. The fights were all about the same and the game was too easy, even on the hardest difficulty.Next. The art style. While steampunk is pretty cool, these guys look like they were ripped from some anime instead of a mysterious unseen part of the world. I mean, who the hell hauls around a coffin on his back while trying to engage in melee? (It would have made so much sense if that were a machinegun with the ammo belt feeding into it.)Which brings me to the next point- weapons. Submachine guns werent even invented in the time period this game takes place in. The sky hook somehow allows one to leap like a (anime) ninja and somehow has the horsepower to pull off some guy's head. Though i will give a little leeway to those because a fair deal of technology in this we don't even have a grasp of today. Though as far as the advancements in tech go....THIS GAME DUN' GOOFED.OK. How are you able to just change your genetic code so easily? In Bioshock 1, it was EXTENSIVELY detailed about how ADAM adds volatile extra code to your genes for you to add plasmids onto. For infinite. No sir. And what makes plasmids so magical in 1960 when we have had "vigors" all this time? Don't give me "quantum science"as an answer because that is as good as saying, "magic". "Magic is why" also seems to be the reason I can do bonus damage on headshots because I put on a new pair of pants. When did bioshock become TF2? At the very least. TF2 doesn't strive to be more than a fun game. BS Infinite seems to be trying to push some abstract political agenda towards us while clutching at straws trying to be as deep or phillosophical as its predecessors. The characters had sketchy backstories and Booker was abrasive, making it rather hard for me to like him and making it that much harder to enjoy when I am portraying a guy that is kind of a♥♥♥♥♥♥ Elizabeth seems to sometimes put up with him- at the very least helping out in combat and providing a deus ex machina every time you are out of ammo or near death- until Booker messes up again and does something that pisses the girl off. She has this Mary Sue power to open portals to almost anything and anywhere but never has the guts to go through them. She never gets injured and always has some reason to come back to Booker in spite of the obviously selfish intent he has.All in all. This is not the genetically enhanced shooter like from 2007. It is sadly quite overrated. Say what you will, critics have gone soft these days, man up. I havent much else more.

Posted: January 22, 2014
												First off. The gameplay felt like Halo 1- Which would be good, except that it isnt Halo..... and also none of the previous games limited your number of weapons and tactical versatility. The fights were all about the same and the game was too easy, even on the hardest difficulty.Next. The art style. While steampunk is pretty cool, these guys look like they were ripped from some anime instead of a mysterious unseen part of the world. I mean, who the hell hauls around a coffin on his back while trying to engage in melee? (It would have made so much sense if that were a machinegun with the ammo belt feeding into it.)Which brings me to the next point- weapons. Submachine guns werent even invented in the time period this game takes place in. The sky hook somehow allows one to leap like a (anime) ninja and somehow has the horsepower to pull off some guy's head. Though i will give a little leeway to those because a fair deal of technology in this we don't even have a grasp of today. Though as far as the advancements in tech go....THIS GAME DUN' GOOFED.OK. How are you able to just change your genetic code so easily? In Bioshock 1, it was EXTENSIVELY detailed about how ADAM adds volatile extra code to your genes for you to add plasmids onto. For infinite. No sir. And what makes plasmids so magical in 1960 when we have had "vigors" all this time? Don't give me "quantum science"as an answer because that is as good as saying, "magic". "Magic is why" also seems to be the reason I can do bonus damage on headshots because I put on a new pair of pants. When did bioshock become TF2? At the very least. TF2 doesn't strive to be more than a fun game. BS Infinite seems to be trying to push some abstract political agenda towards us while clutching at straws trying to be as deep or phillosophical as its predecessors. The characters had sketchy backstories and Booker was abrasive, making it rather hard for me to like him and making it that much harder to enjoy when I am portraying a guy that is kind of a♥♥♥♥♥♥ Elizabeth seems to sometimes put up with him- at the very least helping out in combat and providing a deus ex machina every time you are out of ammo or near death- until Booker messes up again and does something that pisses the girl off. She has this Mary Sue power to open portals to almost anything and anywhere but never has the guts to go through them. She never gets injured and always has some reason to come back to Booker in spite of the obviously selfish intent he has.All in all. This is not the genetically enhanced shooter like from 2007. It is sadly quite overrated. Say what you will, critics have gone soft these days, man up. I havent much else more.

Posted: February 15, 2014
												I've played all of the BioShock series leading up to this and I don't know what this is.  It seems that some BioShock elements were used to develop a limited, hokey shooter with silly elements added to it that have nothing to do with BioShock 1 and 2.  Furthermore, the context of the story is unnecessary, unappreciated and quite distasteful (racism...really?).  I found it sheds some negative light on our Founding Fathers, early 20th Century American society and the history of the United States albeit in some "attempted" humorous fashion.  I'm sure this will prove enormously entertaining to the console kiddies (hence the good reviews) with all the flashy bloom lighting effects and roller-coaster rides through the sky; but for any seasoned gamers looking for an experience anywhere near BioShock 1 and 2...forget it.  The content is just not there. I'm starting to get a bit leery of 2K Games releases.To sum it all up; if you're looking for a continuation of the epic BioShock 1 and 2 series, this isn't it.  It's a rip-off from the coattails of the former two; much like a horrible "part 3" of an otherwise fantastic movie series that wasn't written or directed by the team of the first two.  The only reason I'm playing through this is because I bought it...thankfully on sale.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												I came onto BioShock Infinite fresh after making a final run at the second in the series, and was not entirely sure what to expect with this new outing.  I knew the setting had changed, but a number of the core gameplay mechanics had made the jump from the first two games. What greeted me though was something a bit different than I could have anticipated, in ways that grew on me very quickly.  The first impression was holy crap wow this is a beautiful game.  The first two were interesting, visually, more for their art stylings than actual tech, but they never really blew me away.  Within the first 5 minutes of infinite with all the settings 'turned to 11' so to speak, my jaw was pretty much on the floor.  Its not that they are technically doing something wholly new I haven't seen before, but that what they are doing is just simply done out and out superlatively.  The lighting mixed with the beautiful texturing, mixed with the motion of the air city all around you just really scratched a visual itch in a way that say, Far Cry 2, and Fl0wer for the ps3 had previously.  Just really high on the wow factor.Beyond the sheer visuals though, I was immediately and pleasantly surprised by how 'tight' the controlls felt.  One of the bigger criticisms of the first two BioShock games is that they were 'console first' designs with controls clearly meant for a gamepad, and they felt sluggish and un-responsive to a seasoned mouse and keyboard user.  Infinite could not be further from that, and it was immediately noticable.  The mouse was perfectly smooth and responsive in the way the top tier valve titles tend to be, and things coming over from consoles really never seem to hit.This also ties in very well with much *much* tighter combat.   The weapons feel powerful and generally satisfying, you are limited halo-like to only having two around at a time, so you generally have to think ahead.  Do you really want to walk into a giant mansion with tons of tight corridors and rooms with a sniper rifle, or would it maybe make more sense to swap it out for something a little faster and more mobile first?The 'powers' (aka magic sparkles that fly out of your hand and into an enemies face) take something of a back-seat this time compared to gun play, and I appreciated the changes.  The fighting in rapture in the original games felt more like a game of tic-tac-toe than actual combat.  You had to zap the right enemies with the right magic in the right order then shoot them.  Sans magic you might as well have been firing rubber bullets.  You can make it though a signigicant part of this game barely using the powers at all, or you can use them more tactically, augmenting your fighting style in appreciable and welcome ways, vs out-right dictating it to you.Also for once, your 'escort mission' is the *best* part of the game, not the worst.  Its almost cliche at this point that you have to do x and y and protect the girl or you lose and its game over would you like to retry and maybe take more of the bullets this time so your npc can skip through unscathed... and yeah.. not here, not at all.  It feels like working *with* someone, not for them, and they are wholly capable of managing themselves, and maybe even getting you the extra cover you need, etc.  The only remaining question is why has it taken 15 years for the 'gaming world' to get it this right?There are in the end a few rough edges, sometimes you can feel a little directionless, there is always a helpful arrow to show you where you 'should' go, and you can of course follow it to the end, but theres so much more going on in the game, and the levels are so huge at times that you just sort of feel helpless trying to complete all the little side quests and secrets.  a 'second playthrough' sort of 'new game plus' option would have been pretty welcome here too, as no matter *how* good you are, you are never going to be able to earn/buy/achieve everything on a single play-through.  Those are quibbles tho, a rough plastic seam on a brand new toy, annoying, but no deal breakers by any means.(9.5/10)

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												While my feelings for Bioshock: Infinite are a bit mixed I do recommend that you check this game out.Compared to Bioshock (1) the Vigors (plasmids) and weapons don't feel nearly as inspired.  There are less overall Vigors than in 1 and they seemed all around less useful than the plasmids of Bioshock.  The effects are minimal and I never felt like they contributed much in combat aside from minor effects like stunning an enemy or increasing how much damage the baddies took, which is a shame really.  Elsewhere, there are more types of guns but the amount of customization is much more limited.  There are no longer multiple ammo types and the weapon mods (upgrades) are very strict: each gun has 4 unique upgrades that unlock as you progress through the game but must be purchased.  Finally, tonics are mostly replaced by a new mechanic called Gear.  Gear can be changed at any time and confers similar effects to tonics.  Four pieces of gear can be worn at one time, but these pieces fill specific slots (hat body legs boots).  The effects of gear seemed to be expanded upon past the tonics of Bioshock.As a warning this game is very story heavy.  The pacing is much slower at the start than it is in Bioshock and this is both good and bad.  I didn't feel like I was playing a game for a long time, and even after I was the actual gameplay was so divided by long story segments that I wondered if the gameplay was getting in the way of the story that Infinite wanteed to tell.  This clears up about a third to halfway into the game but that's a long time before it actually happens.That being said I did enjoy the story even if it did get a little ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ty near the end.  While it's not the most original I applaud that the themes and ideas present were used in a video game, at least until the very end.  Don't get me wrong, I enjoyed the ending but it seemed a bit contrived, defying sense and logic.  It did make me want to go replay the game and understand the significance of everything, but eh, lazy.  Ah, and the characters are fantastic as are there interactions.Combat is more or less the same as it was in Bioshock: you shoot things and then they die.  The enemy that replaced the Big Daddy is terrifying but it also only shows up a few times within the story.  Normal enemies make a lot more sense in Infinite than they did in Bioshock.  I understood why I was fighting what I was and why they were there/attacking me in 1 but the enemies in Infinite just fit a lot better.  Later "normal" enemies infuriated me at times because they would take more than an entire clip to their face at point blank before they would go down, but whatever, you get over it.The sky line system is interesting but I would have liked to see it expanded a bit more as it rarely comes into play.  Sure, in some combat situations it opens up the battlefield a lot and creates for some cool moments but I never felt like the sky lines were fully implemented.  That is to say, they felt out of place in their own game: their existence in a lot of places didn't make a lot of sense and from a story point they didn't seem to frequent or connect enough areas.  Early on you use them to move from one area to another but after that they mostly stay confined to a battle arena.  Shame, really.Oh, and the game is gorgeous.  The setting is ok; if it had been more open I would have received it better than I did, but you're never really given an opportunity to explore.  Everything is linear and you see exactly what the developers want you to.  Because of the linearity I didn't feel like I was exploring a city in the clouds so much.  In fact, I felt more confined in Infinite than I ever did in Bioshock, though maybe that is partially due to the ability to backtrack.  Ah well.Yeah, Bioshock is a good game, possibily even great, but it's not without flaws.  You should almost certainly check it out and it's definitely a game that's worth talking about.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												I went into this with high expectations from what I've heard.  The visual design, the story, the graphics, the soundtrack, dialogue/voice acting, the atmosphere are all 10/10.  As a cinematic experience, it's unforgettable and top notch.  When I started playing it, I remember reading that a lot of people saw the game as a huge anti-Mormon/LDS experience & that came back.  The game takes place in 1912, in the floating city of Columbia.  Post Civil War America is a growing super power, heavy themes of racism, worker oppression, big business, anti-foreigner & religious revivalism are going on with some elements of Greek mythology like the first 2 Bioshocks.  The main villain is 1/2 Joseph Smith & 1/2 Brigham Young.The actual gameplay is solid, nothing spectacular or amazing.  I played through on 1999 mode and barely used the vigors which is supposed to be a big draw in the Bioshock world.  I used Shock Jockey for stun, but everything else is basically worthless.  Then you get to the final boss fight & HAVE to use a lot of vigors, so my build made it really hard.  I like the damage numbers & critical strikes popping up on enemies like in Borderlands to see how much HP they have though.  1999 mode wasn't really that hard except for about 2 parts.  There is a recycled boss fight 3 times and a lot of Handyman (read: Big Daddy) fights, the gameplay didn't innovate much and was as long as it was for the sake of story, not because they had that many gameplay ideas.For the Season Pass, Clash in the Clouds is just a boring challenge map DLC.  It's just waves of enemies & blue ribbon challenges.  Only play it if you care about achievements.  Burial at Sea is a 2 hour story campaign that ties into the main game, but takes you to 1958 Rapture, just before the events of Bioshock 1.  It actually adds a lot to the story & is very worth playing.  As of now, I know they're coming out with Burial at Sea part 2, but I don't know if anything else is coming for it or not.Of the 3 Bioshocks, Infinite definitely has the best story & art design, but Bioshock 2 was the most fun for me.  I can appreciate Infinite tying into the previous stories in a unique way & the DLC adds to the story more.Final Verdict: 8.5/10  Definitely worth playing through, but just a bit over rated for average gameplay.

												[Comrade's 2013 Experience of the Year]After playing the game through its entirety, I was left in awe.Both this game's setting and story are simply amazing, however the only actual negative was some of the gameplay itself. The environments were great, of course, but the actual weapons felt... weak and enemies became too bullet-spongy later on in the game. Elizabeth is a pretty interesting addition, as she runs around looking for stuff you're running low on in the middle of combat which saved my♥♥♥♥♥plenty of times. Though interesting she's almost the only actual face-to-face interaction you get beyond a few non-combat areas. And the vigors were... well they were alright but mostly ripped from the previous Bioshock. It was the gun-play which was really disappointing. Things like only being able to carry two weapons pretty much forces you to carry a gun and a heavy weapon. Plus weapons have very little kick and the bulletspongy enemies make it feel like you're using a toy gun. At the end of the game ammo is very scarce and there are no vendors you can get ammo from at all. And really, it just felt terrible at points, I found myself wanting to just get combat over with just to get back to the amazing story.I'd say its definitely worth a buy, as this is easily among the best stories ever told in a game. However in itself, not a good game. So I'd advise you play it on easy to get to the story bits faster.Story: 10/10 (amazing)Enviroment/World: 9/10 (awe-inspiring)Combat: 3/10 (far too generic and far too much of it shoved in for a story-centric game)

												Apparently... after blowing up a beautiful city flying because of a miracle of physics, kidnapping and seducing a young girl, and killing everyone in the process... I am still the good guy... This game was quite an interesting go on parallel universes. I have to admit I did not fully understand every thing but I think I got the big picture. One of the interesting parts for me was the ego view, in which your character still talks. you don't get much of a say in it.You may do some minor decisions, but still I don't think anything really changes, no matter what you do.After a while the battles got a little boring for me... you either are slaughtering them all in the numbers... or you are a two shot for the bigger ones. But that may be the case, because I played on the highest difficulty. Some enemies, like the "Handyman" are quite frustrating in the case, that even their weakspot takes more ammo than you can carry around. And if you die ones they get healed by even more. Yet it stayed challenging and the enemies make the game really atmospheric. I won't compare it to the other parts, because for me the charm of Bioshock 1 & 2 was the dark, theme, everything was in some tight spot and there was no airway to the destination, while in Bioshpock infinite everything was way more open and you felt more free overall.Last to be said I really missed the Big Daddies, but the one thing that tends to satisfy me more on this game is that you finally are meeting people, instead of talking to them over the radio.Took 12 hours for the main campaign, I will play the DLCs next and refer to them in an extra review.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												Personal Rating: 9.5 of 10Bioshock series is like a perfect piece of dessert/pie/cake, made with the finest ingredients all blend together to create a perfect little masterpiece just right for the taste bud and each series is simply the same good ol' masterpiece offered in different flavour. Alas, each game will leave a strong after taste.For a FPS game, Bioshock Infinite surely doesn't fix what is not broken. Meaning you will easily get used to everything this game has to offer and feel really comfortable to play. The visual style is vibrant yet pleasant and beautiful presented with its alluring composed score makes this game a delight to play.The game is a semi-opened area where you can explore certain locations if not proceed directly to the designated locations but exploring is nonetheless rewarding. Each area will present itself with threats and ridding of those you can freely explore the area. Sounds repetitive? Not when the game offers series of powers and weapons with ever changing scenary with a strong storyline to backed it. You will never really feel bored and thats the best part. Everything the game has to offer are done so moderately even the "Sky Rail" which is why I mentioned it is well balanced.The game really captures your gaming experience by putting you in the world with the intense fight and the minor details they did with the environment and dialogues of NPCs.The DLCs are similar to the likes of Dishonored with 2 of them offering chunky story based content and 1 challenge pack. The story DLCs are in my opinion worth every penny as it features new locations, powers and weapons even playstyle. The challenge pack can be rather frustrating if you are trying to collect all the achievements but you get to have a museum. Like the main game, you need to collect money and upgrade your arsenal and powers but these are tracked as you can save your progress in your profile. The latter DLC is simply provides a little edge to the main game such as arsenal upgrades (which you have to pay for) and also some money, addtional gears (clothing that gives you perk) and upgrades which is really nice to have.Needless to say, as a First Person Shooter genre and Bioshock fanatic, this game is a must have.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2013
												I avoided the two+ years of previews, announcements, E3 demos, trailers, and everything else hundreds of millions of dollars in advertising buys for this game. Had no clue what it was going to be about other than "the new Bioshock game from the makers of the original one." That's probably why I'm so impressed by it.Though I usually play games on Normal mode, I played through this one on Hard and feel like that's absolutely the way to do it. (Only 13% of players seem to have followed suit.) This isn't the sort of on-rails "carnival ride" that's become synonymous with "AAA" gaming.  Most sequences aren't scripted, and fights generally take place in open areas with lots of approaches. You'll be backtracking for health and ammo (which is often scarce), so the fact that there's a significant amount of optional story/upgrade content revealed for exploration makes you look forward to doing so. In fact, a lot of those battleground spots are wide open enough that you don't get to really see it all until after the music calms down to denote "everyone around is dead."Unlike Borderlands, if you're playing a recording and someone starts to talk, the recording mutes for the talking. You can't cancel out the "this will only be said once" dialogue so easily, and you can replay all the past recordings. Note: the "Gameplay" menu it keeps talking about is NOT the "Gameplay" menu that appears when you hit Escape. Press "O." That was dumb of them, to have two sub-screens with the same name. But that'll let you replay all past recordings, check your objectives, and change your gear (items that confer passive effects, many of which are quite good).Like the first Bioshock, you can only carry two weapons at a time. You can only quick toggle between two powers at once as well, though the game will pause if you want to select a new ability. Between this and the upgrade system, there's little incentive to diversify your loadout. Especially when re-enacting the Hitchcock 3D horror movie is so effective; upgrade that so it creates traps if you kill someone affected by it and you will be a BEAST. On the subject of traps: USE THEM. There are sections of the game that are intentionally quite difficult without them, and in Platinum Games fashion these are meant to be "gates." As in, the developers figure "the player should really use this if they wish to proceed past this point." Unfortunately, as is also Platinum Games fashion, almost everyone playing did not figure this out because there is no gameplay tip displayed on screen or character verbally telling you "you probably want to try this now." Sure, you're informed traps exist each time you get a new ability, but it's up to you to figure out to use them. Global Achievement stats tell the story: 58.1% of Bioshock Infinite owners beat the game (13% on Hard). Only 25% bothered to even USE the traps. This is why you hear people SUPER♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off at the "boss" encounters, saying "Irrational, you done effed it up!" Those people opted to brute force respawn through tough encounters. Don't do this. USE THE TRAPS. If you walk into an area and see enemies unaware? SET TRAPS. You will save many, many bullets. To not do so is to resign yourself to a cyclical fate of respawning with not enough ammo.Bioshock Infinite is a damned good *game*. I'm not slogging through it just for its story and characters (both of which are also quite good). We live in a world where lots of people think "oh, I'll just watch a Youtube video of someone playing it, because I want to treat games the same way that I treat film and television [also, I don't want to devote the money/time myself]." The people who do that are doing the medium a disservice and only perpetuating the on-rails uber-linearity of "AAA" games. I say nuts to that. I say murder a bunch of dudes, then zoom the camera super close to their awesomely mutilated bodies and take screenshots.  Why, I took several hundred for this game alone!

												TITLE : BIOSHOCK INFINITE + Season PassDATE : 26-Apr-2017 (Completed main + extras)SETUP : Windows 10 64-Bit, MSI GT80 (980M SLI) Laptop, Logitech F710 GamepadRATING (rated as if released in 2017) Optimization : AStorytelling : AGraphics : ASound : AControl : AFun Factor : AValue : AGreat storytelling, memorable characters, good voice acting. The story keeps you guessing until the end although I have to say that the plot twist is rather cliche and I can smell it miles away. And at the end, there still things left unexplained. Visually, the game world look stunning with beautiful designs and great details. Unlike the previous dark and claustrophobic world of BioShock 1 and 2, BioShock Infinite feels more open and sunny and happy, it's like you're playing shooting game in an amusement park built above the clouds. The music is great and really help getting you immersed into this 1912 steampunk fantasy world. Combat system is fun and controlling your character in combat is smooth. I really had fun playing this game. The only thing I dislike is that this game doesn't have "New Game Plus". After spending time exploring every corners on every levels to find upgrades and collectibles, I really wish I can start over with all the upgrades and collectibles intact. For me, current normal price is still too high for a game released 4 years ago, so if you can find this game at a discounted price, I definitely recommend it for grab.

												В 1900 году Америка, находясь на пике технологического развития, построила огромный высокотехнологичный летающий город Колумбию, который должен был стать гордостью американской нации и невозможным чудом среди творений человека. Однако, через некоторое время, Колумбия вышла из-под контроля и исчезла из поля зрения. Главным героем является бывший сотрудник «Детективного агентства Пинкертона», Букер ДеВитт. В 1912 году к нему обращается некий человек, знающий местоположение Колумбии. Под предлогом списания с него долгов просит освободить оттуда девушку по имени Элизабет. Начинается всё очень безобидно, мило и невинно, однако во что всё это потом выходит? Игра восхитительна, графически красивый шутер с интересным сюжетом, запутанным и сложным (если в целом говорить). Интрига сохраняется до самого конца, если кто-нибудь не "наспойлерил". Общая стилистика игры отличная, но главная фишка Bioshock Infinite, Элизабет! Элизабет действительно оказалась очень милой девушкой. Элизабет обращает внимание на любую мелочь! Очень реалистично проработанный напарник, скорее почти настоящий человек. В течении всей игры, её эмоции отображались у неё лице (радость, страх, злость и т.д). P.S: Главная суть игры: существуют тысячи параллельных измерений, где один и тот-же человек, или предмет могут находится в разных ситуациях и состояниях. Оценка: Гениально 10/10. Кооператива нет, что немного огорчает

												I found BioShock Infinite to be another good game in the series. After tweaking a few keybindings, the game's controls felt very comfortable and I was able to enjoy the fast paced combat to its fullest. One of the strongest aspects of this game is the storyline. It keeps a decent pace and gets you emotionally connected to your companion, a peculiar girl whose manerisms and bright eyes personality make her difficult not to like. She also adds a handful of interesting mechanics that prevent her from being a random NPC who follows you.

												One of the greatest games I have played in a long while. I am not traditionally a FPS gamer but was sucked in by the very excellent storyline. I've played it through too many times now and always find something new. The graphics are stunning and is well thought out in terms of game play. Really, who can pass up the chance to play a game set in a steampunk city in the sky. So much fun. So many hotdogs in drawers. I have recommended this game to all my game loving friends. Even if you don't like shooter games you'll like this as the story and visuals are the most compelling element. Just play this game already.
